module.description: This PrepTest contains three scored LSAT sections  plus an additional section to simulate the unscored section in a real LSAT administration. Practice as if taking an actual test by following the test-taking instructions and timing yourself.

sections.directions: Directions: Each set of questions in this section is based on a single passage or a pair of passages. The questions are to be answered on the basis of what is stated or implied in the passage or pair of passages. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText:
A major problem facing industrial societies is their exponentially increasing production of toxic waste. Environmental regulations and expenses for landfills and incinerators have increased significantly in recent years. In an effort to save time and money, many industries have turned to alternative methods of hazardous-waste disposal, including increased use of deep-well injection. In this method, wells are drilled into porous and permeable rock strata that are already saturated with salt water. Liquid wastes are then injected into the rock strata. Most of these wells are drilled to a depth of at least 300 meters—the minimum depth that generally puts the injected waste at a safe distance below any aquifer, in this case a rock stratum containing drinkable water. Such wells are rarely deeper than 1,800 meters, because below this depth it is more cost-effective to consider an alternative method of disposal. Deep-well injection, which has been used to some extent since the 1930s, has become a matter of controversy as growing numbers of communities come to rely on underground sources of drinking water. The controversy arises because there are three serious problems with this method of waste disposal.

Under the best conditions, wastes are injected into rock strata saturated with salt water and separated by impermeable rock strata from aquifers containing drinkable water. However, injection wells may leak, allowing significant amounts of noxious chemicals to mix with supplies of drinking water. In other cases, mistakes by personnel working on the wells may lead to the pollution of aquifers. In one such case, workers installing a 500-meter-deep well left a gap along approximately 30 meters of its steel casing. This allowed waste to escape at a depth of only 200 meters, threatening a regional aquifer supplying water to 100,000 people. Because such accidents take place deep within the earth, people may be exposed to dangerous levels of waste materials for long periods of time before the problem is even discovered.

The third problem associated with deep-well injection arises from the fact that it is nearly impossible to predict how the injected wastes will be acted on by the geological features of the injection area. Unlike surface water, the water in underground rock strata does not flow entirely under the influence of gravity. Moving along subterranean pressure gradients, it can flow in any direction and, in some cases, can be transported thousands of meters per year through geologic faults, porous rock, or other geologic formations.

The significant uncertainty about where injected wastes will flow, along with the possibilities of mechanical failure and human error, makes deep-well injection a risky means of managing hazardous wastes. Unfortunately, as societies produce more toxic waste, industry will rely increasingly upon this relatively cheap, efficient means of disposal.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately states the main point of the passage?

options.optionContent: Deep-well injection of hazardous wastes is unsafe when expensive precautionary measures are not taken.
Although deep-well injection of hazardous wastes can be unsafe, it is generally safe when proper procedures are followed and sites are carefully selected.
Because of the high costs and extensive regulations associated with other methods, deep-well injection has wholly supplanted alternative methods of hazardous-waste disposal.
The increasing use of deep-well injection as a method of hazardous-waste disposal is seriously problematic.
Careful design and location of deep-well-injection facilities is important because communities commonly rely on groundwater for drinking.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Main Point questions are reliably anticipatable, so we should simply compare our anticipation to each answer choice until we find one that lines up. Does this answer choice sound like, “The increasing use of deep-well injection of hazardous waste presents a risk of severe water contamination due to mechanical failure, human error, and significant uncertainty about where the injected waste will flow”? Not quite. This answer choice says deep-well injection is a problem “when expensive precautionary measures are not taken.” But this author never discussed “expensive precautionary measures.” In fact, the author suggests certain issues — like the unpredictable flow of underground water — may exist irrespective of any precautionary measures. So this answer choice mischaracterizes the main point, and it should be eliminated.

Main Point questions are reliably anticipatable, so we should simply compare our anticipation to each answer choice until we find one that lines up. Does this answer choice sound like, “The increasing use of deep-well injection of hazardous waste presents a risk of severe water contamination due to mechanical failure, human error, and significant uncertainty about where the injected waste will flow”? Not at all. An efficient test-taker would eliminate this upon reading “generally safe.” This is the exact opposite point that the author repeatedly made in this passage. The author doesn't think that “proper procedures” and “careful” site selection will eliminate the risk of deep-well injection, so this answer choice mischaracterizes the main point.

Main Point questions are reliably anticipatable, so we should simply compare our anticipation to each answer choice until we find one that lines up. Does this answer choice sound like, “The increasing use of deep-well injection of hazardous waste presents a risk of severe water contamination due to mechanical failure, human error, and significant uncertainty about where the injected waste will flow”? Nope. This answer choice just conveys the idea that deep-well injection is popular. The author mentions this a few times (P1, S3; P4, S2), but the author was primarily concerned with showing why deep-well injection is dangerous. This answer choice doesn't even hint at the danger involved, so it cannot accurately state the main point. Moreover, there's a factual issue in this answer choice. The passage never states that deep-well injection has “wholly supplanted” (completely replaced) other waste disposal methods. The passage only states that the use of deep-well injection has recently “increased” (P1, S3; P4, S2). Either one of these issues is enough to sink (C).

Main Point questions are reliably anticipatable, so we should simply compare our anticipation to each answer choice until we find one that lines up. Does this answer choice sound like, “The increasing use of deep-well injection of hazardous waste presents a risk of severe water contamination due to mechanical failure, human error, and significant uncertainty about where the injected waste will flow”? Yes, it does! It doesn't mention the author's specific issues, so it's a little more generalized than our anticipation. But that's OK, as this answer choice expresses the same ideas that the author conveys in the main point. Therefore, we can select it confidently.

Main Point questions are reliably anticipatable, so we should simply compare our anticipation to each answer choice until we find one that lines up. Does this answer choice sound like, “The increasing use of deep-well injection of hazardous waste presents a risk of severe water contamination due to mechanical failure, human error, and significant uncertainty about where the injected waste will flow”? An experienced test-taker would answer that with a resounding, “No.” Like (A) and (B), this answer choice suggests that the passage's main point is focused on avoiding the dangers associated with deep-well injection of hazardous waste. However, the author in this passage was primarily concerned with describing why deep-well injection of hazardous waste is dangerous. For this reason, (E) mischaracterizes the main point and can be eliminated.

items.questionType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes
items.displayType: Identifying Main Points and Primary Purposes

items.stemText: The passage most strongly suggests that which one of the following is true?

options.optionContent: The use of landfills and incinerators for the disposal of hazardous wastes is no longer considered safe.
Injection of hazardous wastes at depths of more than 1,800 meters is less expensive but more dangerous than injection of such wastes at 300 meters.
Deep-well injection of hazardous wastes can contaminate aquifers of drinking water that are great distances from the deep-well-injection site.
Disposal of hazardous wastes in landfills involves various risks, but—unlike deep-well injection—it does not involve the risk of contaminating groundwater.
Drinking-water wells are usually deeper than the wells that are drilled for deep-well injection of hazardous wastes.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Do you recall reading about how safe “the use of landfill and incinerators” is? Probably not. An efficient test-taker would probably table or eliminate this answer choice and move on to the next one. If we decided we needed to review the passage for any mention of “the use of landfill and incinerators,” we could find the only reference to landfills and incinerators. This reference appears in the first paragraph. The author doesn't say that landfills and incinerators are no longer considered safe. Instead, the author just says that they are subject to increased regulations and expenses (P1, S2). Therefore, (A) is not supported.

Do you recall reading about how safe or expensive it is to inject wastes at 1,800 meters versus 300 meters? Possibly. If you cannot recall whether this claim is supported, we can consider whether it is consistent with the main point. The main point asserted that deep-well injection is dangerous. The claim that injecting waste at more than 1,800 meters is “more dangerous” than at 300 meters is consistent with that main point, so this answer choice may bear closer scrutiny. Checking the passage for the reference to 1,800 meters would lead us to the sixth and seventh sentences of the first paragraph. In those lines, the author says that injecting waste at less than 300 meters is more dangerous than injecting waste at more than 300 meters. The author also says that injecting waste more than 1,800 meters underground isn't cost-effective. So, this answer choice gets things backward. It is less dangerous but more expensive to deposit waste at 1,800 meters. So, checking the passage confirms that this answer choice is not correct.

Do you recall reading about whether hazardous waste can contaminate water that is very far from the deep-well injection site? Probably, since this was the general idea put forth by the third paragraph. If you cannot recall whether this claim is supported, we can consider whether it is consistent with the main point. The main point asserted that deep-well injection is dangerous due to mechanical failure, human errors, and the unpredictable flow of underground water. This answer choice is consistent with that main point — particularly the part about the unpredictable flow of underground water. Therefore, this answer choice warrants a closer look, even if we didn't remember reading about this specific idea. We can find the support in the third paragraph. There, the author says that underground water can sometimes “be transported thousands of meters per year through geologic faults, porous rock, or other geologic formations” (P3, S3). “Thousands of meters” would certainly qualify as a “great distance.” Therefore, this part of the passage supports the possibility that deep-well injection can contaminate drinking waters great distances from the injection site.

Do you recall reading about the risks of disposing of hazardous waste in “landfills”? Probably not. An expedient test-taker would probably table or eliminate this answer choice and move on to the next one. If we decided we needed to review the passage for any mention of disposing of hazardous waste in “landfills,” we could find the only reference to landfills. This reference appears in the first paragraph. The author doesn't say that landfills involve risks or that landfills cannot contaminate groundwater. Instead, the author just says that landfills are subject to increased regulations and expenses (P1, S2). Therefore, (D) is not supported.

Do you recall reading about “drinking-water wells”? Probably not. An experienced test-taker would likely table or eliminate this answer choice and move on to the next one. If we decided we needed to review the passage for any mention of “drinking-water wells,” we could search for “well” or “drinking water.” Doing so would confirm that no reference to “wells” ever mentions that the well was drilled to provide access to “drinking water.” Further, it would confirm that no reference to “drinking water” ever specifies that the water came from a well. Therefore, we can conclude that “drinking-water wells” are not mentioned in this passage, and the passage provides no textual support for (E).

items.stemText: Which one of the following would, if true, most strengthen the author's position regarding the risks of deep-well injection of hazardous wastes?

options.optionContent: Few of the rock formations that industries consider suitable for deep-well injection of hazardous wastes are adjacent to or connected to sources of drinkable groundwater.
Few of the toxic substances that are commonly disposed of through deep-well injection have been thoroughly tested for their effects on nonhuman organisms.
Many of the sites at which hazardous-waste-injection wells are drilled are many miles from the industrial facilities that use them for waste disposal.
The movement of underground water is even more rapid and less predictable than most geologists believe.
Methods of predicting and monitoring the movement of underground water have significantly improved in the time since the author gathered data.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this make the risk of water contamination from deep-well injection more likely? Suppose that almost all the sites for deep-well injection were far away from sources of drinkable water. Wouldn't that make you feel less concerned about the risk of water contamination? Of course, the author notes that the hazardous waste could contaminate groundwater "thousands of meters" away (P3, S3), so this wouldn't guarantee clean drinking water. Still, it would probably reduce the likelihood of contamination, weakening the author's argument.

Does this make the risk of water contamination from deep-well injection more likely? If we haven't tested the hazardous waste for its effect on “nonhuman organisms,” we don't know whether it's toxic to these organisms. It could be toxic. It could be safe. So, this answer choice doesn't add any definitive information that makes contamination more or less likely, so this has no effect on the argument. Further, the author's issues center on how water contamination would affect humans. (“Deep-well injection ... has become a matter of controversy as growing numbers of communities come to rely on underground sources of drinking water” (P1, S8). “This allows waste to escape ... threatening a regional aquifer supplying water to 100,000 people” (P2, S5). “[P]eople may be exposed to dangerous levels of waste materials” (P2, S6).) We assume the author would prefer we didn't poison animals and other organisms, but that position was never explicitly advanced. For that reason, (B) doesn't address the author's position at all.

Does this make the risk of water contamination from deep-well injection more likely? This tells us that the deep-well injection sites aren't close to the industrial facilities, but that doesn't address whether the deep-well injection sites were close to drinkable water sources. Some test-takers assume that moving the waste from the industrial facility to the injection site may increase the chance of mechanical error with the transportation system, but the passage never discusses whether mechanical errors could exist anywhere other than in the well itself. Plus, even if this type of error occurred, we still don't know whether the leakage would pose any risk of contaminating a water source. For these reasons, (C) has no effect on the author's position.

Does this make the risk of water contamination from deep-well injection more likely? Yes! The author cautioned that the unpredictable flow of underground water makes it very hard to anticipate where the injected waste will go (P3, S1-3). According to the author, this makes deep-well injection risky. (D) shows the author was not mistaken or overstating that risk! In fact, (D) shows that this unpredictability is even more significant than the author led us to believe. So, the waste mixed with underground salt water in deep-well injection sites can move more unpredictably and more quickly than the author thought, making it even more probable that water sources will be contaminated.

Does this make the risk of water contamination from deep-well injection more likely? The author claimed the unpredictable flow of underground water was one reason why deep-well injection was so risky. This answer choice shows that the author was overstating how unpredictable that flow is. If we are better at anticipating and tracking this flow of water, we might be able to monitor where the waste leakage is headed and halt its progress. This makes the risk of water contamination less likely, which weakens the author's position.

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

items.stemText: According to the passage, which one of the following is true of underground water?

options.optionContent: It can be suitable as a source of public drinking water even when contaminated by low levels of deep-well-injected wastes.
It can seldom be found at depths of less than 200 meters in regions in which deep-well injection is practiced.
It can seldom be used as a source of water for industrial processes.
It can contain a high concentration of salt as a result of contamination by deep-well-injected wastes.
It can move from one underground formation to another due to factors other than gravity.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Do you recall reading about how “low levels of deep-well-injected wastes” in drinking water is safe? Probably not. In fact, this conflicts with the author's main point, which was all about the dangers of deep-well-injected wastes. An experienced test-taker would probably eliminate this answer choice outright since it contravenes the main point. If we decided we needed to review the passage, we'd realize that the author never brings up “low levels” of hazardous waste. The author only discusses “significant” (P2, S2) or “dangerous” (P2, S6) levels. So, the author never clarifies whether a small amount of hazardous waste is safe, so this answer choice is unsupported.

Do you recall reading about how underground water is rarely found less than 200 meters deep? Possibly. The author mentions this depth in the second paragraph. However, an efficient test-taker would probably not check the passage if they didn't remember what was said about this depth. Instead, they'd punt on this answer choice and move on to the next one. If you did review the second paragraph for the reference to 200 meters, you'd find it near the middle of the second paragraph. There, the author explains that leakage from a well escaped at a “depth of only 200 meters,” which threatened “a regional aquifer supplying water to 100,000 people” (P2, S5). So the passage tells us there's at least one water source around 200 meters deep. Plus, in the first paragraph, the author claimed that deep-well injection sites are generally lower than 300 meters to put the sites beneath “any aquifer” (P1, S6). Both imply the existence of underground water sources less than 200 meters deep.

Do you recall reading about using underground water for industrial processes? If not, it's probably not worth it to check the passage. Instead, table this answer choice and move on to the next one. If you did review the passage, you wouldn't find anything explicitly discussing the water used for “industrial processes.” However, the first paragraph reveals that deep-well injection involves the injection of waste into “rock strata that are already saturated with salt water” (P1, S4). So, apparently, water is used for one industrial process: deep-well injection of industrial waste. That means this answer choice is provably false.

Do you recall reading about concentrations of salt? Probably not. Decisive test-takers would probably not check the passage if they didn't remember reading about this. Instead, they'd defer on selecting this answer choice and move on to the next one, or they'd eliminate it. If you did review the passage, you wouldn't find any support for the claim that underground water contains a lot of salt due to contamination from deep-well-injection waste. In fact, the only references to salt in the passage assert that the water in deep-well injection sites is already salty, not made saltier by the wastes. So, this answer choice is not necessarily true.

We predicted that the correct answer would say that the flow of water underground isn't just affected by gravity, so it flows through geological formations unpredictably. And this answer choice says exactly that. This answer choice is explicitly supported by the third paragraph, and it is correct.

items.stemText: Based on the passage, which one of the following most accurately states the purpose of deep-well injection of hazardous waste?

options.optionContent: It serves as a short-term storage method for wastes while their toxicity is neutralized.
It makes aboveground hazardous-waste disposal methods obsolete.
It contains hazardous wastes in saltwater-saturated underground areas.
It creates underground pools of waste that can easily be continuously and reliably monitored.
It recycles certain low-toxicity wastes.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We're looking for an answer choice that says the purpose of deep-well injection is to dispose of hazardous waste in rock strata saturated in salt water. Does this say that? Nope. Don't even worry if the passage mentioned whether this is a “short-term” solution or whether the toxicity will ever be “neutralized.” On questions for which we can form precise anticipations that are directly supported by the passage, we can eliminate anything that doesn't match our anticipation. If we did check the passage to assess (A), we'd realize that the passage never said that injection of waste in deep wells was only a short-term solution, or that there would be any attempts made to “neutralize” the waste's toxicity. In fact, the author takes issue with this method of waste disposal because the waste stays toxic and can spread far and wide due to human or mechanical error (P4, S1). Thus, this choice is unsupported.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the purpose of deep-well injection is to dispose of hazardous waste in rock strata saturated in salt water. Does this say that? Not in the slightest. So don't worry about checking the passage to see whether it said that “aboveground” waste disposal will be obsolete. We can eliminate anything that doesn't match our anticipation on questions that allow us to formulate precise anticipations. If we checked the passage, we wouldn't find evidence that aboveground waste disposal is becoming obsolete. The passage just says that environmental regulations and expenses for such disposal have increased, leading industries to “increase” the use of deep-well injection (P1, S2-3). So, the purpose of deep-well injection isn't to completely replace aboveground disposal — just to provide a cheaper alternative. There's no need to review the passage to determine why this is wrong, but such a review will show that this choice is incorrect.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the purpose of deep-well injection is to dispose of hazardous waste in rock strata saturated in salt water. Does this say that? Almost verbatim. The first paragraph explicitly supports this statement, so this answer choice is correct.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the purpose of deep-well injection is to dispose of hazardous waste in rock strata saturated in salt water. Does this say that? Not quite. Deep-well injection creates “underground pools of waste,” but there's no suggestion that these pools can be continuously or reliably monitored. In fact, this chafes against part of the author's main point — that the unpredictable movement of underground water makes it difficult to know where these pools may flow (P4, S1). Assuming they didn't already select (C) and move on, efficient test-takers would eliminate this because it conflicts with the author's main point.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the purpose of deep-well injection is to dispose of hazardous waste in rock strata saturated in salt water. Does this say that? Not at all. So don't worry about checking the passage to see whether it said that “recycles” waste that is “low-toxic.” We can eliminate answer choices as soon as we recognize that they don't match our anticipation on questions that allow us to make precise anticipations. If we checked the passage, we wouldn't find any references to “low-toxicity waste” or recycling. The passage doesn't mention these topics, so this cannot be the purpose of deep-well injection. We don't need to review the passage to determine why an answer choice like this is wrong, but such a review confirms that it is incorrect.

In this method, wells are drilled into porous and permeable rock strata that are already saturated with salt water. Liquid wastes are then injected into the rock strata. Most of these wells are drilled to a depth of at least 300 meters—the minimum depth that generally puts the injected waste at a safe distance below any aquifer, in this case a rock stratum containing drinkable water. Such wells are rarely deeper than 1,800 meters, because below this depth it is more cost-effective to consider an alternative method of disposal. Deep-well injection, which has been used to some extent since the 1930s, has become a matter of controversy as growing numbers of communities come to rely on underground sources of drinking water. The controversy arises because there are three serious problems with this method of waste disposal.

Under the best conditions, wastes are injected into rock strata saturated with salt water and separated by impermeable rock strata from aquifers containing drinkable water. However, injection wells may leak, allowing significant amounts of noxious chemicals to mix with supplies of drinking water. In other cases, mistakes by personnel working on the wells may lead to the pollution of aquifers. In one such case, workers installing a 500-meter-deep well left a gap along approximately 30 meters of its steel casing. This allowed waste to escape at a depth of only 200 meters, threatening a regional aquifer supplying water to 100,000 people. Because such accidents take place deep within the earth, people may be exposed to dangerous levels of waste materials for long periods of time before the problem is even discovered.

The third problem associated with deep-well injection arises from the fact that it is nearly impossible to predict how the injected wastes will be acted on by the geological features of the injection area. Unlike surface water, the water in underground rock strata does not flow entirely under the influence of gravity. Moving along subterranean pressure gradients, it can flow in any direction and, in some cases, can be transported thousands of meters per year through geologic faults, porous rock, or other geologic formations.

The significant uncertainty about where injected wastes will flow, along with the possibilities of mechanical failure and human error, makes deep-well injection a risky means of managing hazardous wastes. Unfortunately, as societies produce more toxic waste, industry will rely increasingly upon this relatively cheap, efficient means of disposal.
items.stemText: According to the passage, deep-well injection of hazardous wastes has become

options.optionContent: more controversial because of an increased dependence on underground sources of drinking water
more controversial because of an increase in toxin-related illnesses near deep-well-injection areas
more widely accepted because newly developed alternatives are more expensive than deep-well injection
more widely accepted because of increasing public awareness of environmental issues
more widely accepted because of relatively high toxicity of wastes that are disposed of by deep-well injection

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We are looking for an answer choice that says deep-well injection has become more common or controversial. This answer choice says the latter, so it is correct. This assertion is directly supported by the eighth sentence in the first paragraph, which states that deep-well injection has become more controversial as more communities rely on underground drinking water. This answer choice also relates to the “Problem” central to this passage's Meta-Structure, so it should be familiar to any test-taker who took the time to reflect on this passage's overarching structure. Because this answer choice is a dead-ringer for our anticipation and is intimately tied to the passage's Meta-Structure, we would be justified in selecting it.

We are looking for an answer choice that says deep-well injection has become more common or controversial. This says that deep-well injection has become more controversial, which might make it an attractive answer choice for some test-takers. Although this answer choice begins promisingly, it mischaracterizes why deep-well injection has become more controversial. According to the passage, the controversy is related to communities' dependence on drinking water (P1, S8) and the three dangers associated with deep-well injection (P1, S9). In discussing these problems, the author never claims that more people have succumbed to “toxin-related illnesses.” For that reason, this answer choice is unsupported.

We are looking for an answer choice that says deep-well injection has become more common or controversial. This says that deep-well injection has become more widely accepted, which is the opposite of controversial. For that reason, we could quickly eliminate this answer choice. If we assume that by “widely accepted” this answer choice means that deep-well injection has become more widely accepted by industries, this answer might be consistent with the claim that deep-well injection is more common. And this might make (C) an attractive answer choice. Deep-well injection has indeed become more “widely accepted” (at least among waste-producing industries) (P1, S3). However, this acceptance didn't arise “because newly developed alternatives” are more expensive. This acceptance arose because the old alternatives — landfills and incinerators — became more expensive (P1, S2). As worded, this answer choice does not accurately convey why deep-well injection has become more widely accepted among industries.

We are looking for an answer choice that says deep-well injection has become more common or controversial. Like (C), (D) says that deep-well injection is now more widely accepted, which is the opposite of controversial. For that reason, we could quickly eliminate this answer choice. On the other hand, some may assume that “widely accepted” means that industries are more commonly using this practice to dispose toxic waste. This interpretation may make (D) tempting. Still, this is incorrect. Although deep-well injection became more “widely accepted” (among waste-producing industries) (P1, S3), it wasn't because the public became increasingly aware of environmental issues. In fact, the public apparently became more aware of environmental problems with deep-well injection because the practice became more common (P1, S8). So, the passage suggests that the cause-and-effect relationship runs in the opposite direction. This makes (D) incorrect, even under the alternative interpretation.

We are looking for an answer choice that says deep-well injection has become more common or controversial. Yet again, this answer choice is “more widely accepted,” which is the opposite of controversial. Again, this allows us to quickly eliminate this answer choice. However, some may assume this answer choice is saying that the practice has become more “widely accepted” by industries that need to dispose of toxic waste. Even under that interpretation, (E) is wrong. Deep-well injection has indeed become more “widely accepted” (at least among waste-producing industries) (P1, S3). But this acceptance isn't the result of the high toxicity levels of the waste the industries are injecting into the wells. This acceptance arose because the other ways to eliminate high-toxicity waste — such as landfills and incinerators — have become more expensive and regulated (P1, S2). So, this answer choice misstates this fact, and is incorrect.

items.stimulusText:
A major problem facing industrial societies is their exponentially increasing production of toxic waste. Environmental regulations and expenses for landfills and incinerators have increased significantly in recent years. In an effort to save time and money, many industries have turned to alternative methods of hazardous-waste disposal, including increased use of deep-well injection. In this method, wells are drilled into porous and permeable rock strata that are already saturated with salt water. Liquid wastes are then injected into the rock strata. Most of these wells are drilled to a depth of at least 300 meters—the minimum depth that generally puts the injected waste at a safe distance below any aquifer, in this case a rock stratum containing drinkable water. Such wells are rarely deeper than 1,800 meters, because below this depth it is more cost-effective to consider an alternative method of disposal. Deep-well injection, which has been used to some extent since the 1930s, has become a matter of controversy as growing numbers of communities come to rely on underground sources of drinking water. The controversy arises because there are three serious problems with this method of waste disposal.

Under the best conditions, wastes are injected into rock strata saturated with salt water and separated by impermeable rock strata from aquifers containing drinkable water. However, injection wells may leak, allowing significant amounts of noxious chemicals to mix with supplies of drinking water. In other cases, mistakes by personnel working on the wells may lead to the pollution of aquifers. In one such case, workers installing a 500-meter-deep well left a gap along approximately 30 meters of its steel casing. This allowed waste to escape at a depth of only 200 meters, threatening a regional aquifer supplying water to 100,000 people. Because such accidents take place deep within the earth, people may be exposed to dangerous levels of waste materials for long periods of time before the problem is even discovered.

The third problem associated with deep-well injection arises from the fact that it is nearly impossible to predict how the injected wastes will be acted on by the geological features of the injection area. Unlike surface water, the water in underground rock strata does not flow entirely under the influence of gravity. Moving along subterranean pressure gradients, it can flow in any direction and, in some cases, can be transported thousands of meters per year through geologic faults, porous rock, or other geologic formations.

The significant uncertainty about where injected wastes will flow, along with the possibilities of mechanical failure and human error, makes deep-well injection a risky means of managing hazardous wastes. Unfortunately, as societies produce more toxic waste, industry will rely increasingly upon this relatively cheap, efficient means of disposal.
items.stemText: Based on the passage, which one of the following most accurately describes the ideal characteristics of an underground area suitable for the deep-well injection of hazardous wastes?

options.optionContent: At 300 meters or more below the surface, the area contains a layer of impermeable rock below which there are no permeable layers.
At 300 meters or more below the surface, the area contains a layer of permeable rock above which there is a layer of impermeable rock.
The area contains one or more layers of impermeable rock extending from near the surface to a depth of at least 300 meters.
At a depth of 300 meters or less, the area contains an aquifer into which water flows.
The area contains a layer of impermeable rock overlain by a layer of permeable rock at a depth of 1,800 meters or more.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We are looking for an answer choice that describes this arrangement, in order from top to bottom: (1) Surface; (2) (300 meters); (3) Impermeable rock; (4) WELL: Permeable rock strata with salt water; (5) (1,800 meters). This answer choice is hard to follow, but does it describe that? Let's break it down. This answer choice says it should be 300 meters or more beneath the surface, so elements (1) and (2) are met. It then says there's a layer of impermeable rock “below which there are no permeable layers.” This mixes up elements (3) and (4). We know element (4), permeable rock, is beneath element (3), impermeable rock. So, there does have to be a permeable rock layer beneath the impermeable layer.

We are looking for an answer choice that describes this arrangement, in order from top to bottom: (1) Surface; (2) (300 meters); (3) Impermeable rock; (4) WELL: Permeable rock strata with salt water; (5) (1,800 meters). This answer choice is hard to follow, but does it describe that? Let's break it down. This answer choice says the site should be 300 meters or more beneath the surface, so it satisfies elements (1) and (2). It also says the well should be in a layer of permeable rock. This satisfies element (4). And it says there should be a layer of impermeable above the layer of permeable rock, so element (3) is also met. This answer choice doesn't specify that the site should be no deeper than 1,800 meters, but the description is otherwise spot on. Therefore, this is the correct answer.

We are looking for an answer choice that describes this arrangement, in order from top to bottom: (1) Surface; (2) (300 meters); (3) Impermeable rock; (4) WELL: Permeable rock strata with salt water; (5) (1,800 meters). Does this answer choice describe that? Nope. This answer choice says that the area is well will contain rock strata that extend from the surface to a depth of 300 meters. So, this doesn't satisfy element (2) — we know the well will need to be lower than 300 meters. It also doesn't satisfy element (4), as we know the site will need to contain permeable — not impermeable rock strata. These issues make (C) incorrect.

We are looking for an answer choice that describes this arrangement, in order from top to bottom: (1) Surface; (2) (300 meters); (3) Impermeable rock; (4) WELL: Permeable rock strata with salt water; (5) (1,800 meters). Does this answer choice describe that? No. This answer choice says the site is less than 300 meters deep, violating element (2). According to the passage, the well will need to be lower than 300 meters so the waste won't touch any aquifers.

We are looking for an answer choice that describes this arrangement, in order from top to bottom: (1) Surface; (2) (300 meters); (3) Impermeable rock; (4) WELL: Permeable rock strata with salt water; (5) (1,800 meters). Does this answer choice describe that? Not at all. This answer choice says the site will be more than 1,800 meters deep, violating element (5). The passage states that the well should be less than 1,800 meters deep. Therefore, this answer choice is incorrect.

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

items.stimulusText:
Native American stories often feature a character called the trickster, a comic figure who has both mortal weaknesses and supernatural powers. Recently, the term "trickster" has also appeared in criticism of sixteenth- and seventeenth-century European literature, particularly in reference to the picaresque novel and its central character, the picaro (Spanish for "rogue"): both the picaro and the trickster are heroes of episodic adventures, and both live on the peripheries of society and are morally flawed.

Yet closer examination reveals that applying the term "trickster" to both characters obscures essential differences between them. The picaro—typically a male character—operates primarily as an agent of satire. Most commonly, the picaro's adventures begin when he spontaneously yields to his own roguish, though innocent, impulses. The picaro indulges in vices and follies with relish and freedom, much to the outrage of other members of society, who often secretly indulge in similar pastimes out of a habitual compulsion. Thus the picaro's authenticity serves as a foil to the perceived hypocrisy of conventional society. To such a society, the picaro can represent a dangerous, disruptive freedom, and it reacts by marginalizing him. It is in that distance—between the ostensibly disreputable freedom of the picaro and the hypocrisy of the safely ensconced social being—that the satire occurs.

But the trickster, usually an animal acting as a human agent, does not serve a satiric function. For while the picaresque novel takes place in and satirizes human society, the trickster operates in the ahistorical world of myth; where the targets of the picaresque novel are the idiosyncrasies and inconsistencies of a historical human society, trickster stories seek, using the trickster's negative example, to instruct listeners about moral behavior of individuals. In fact, whatever flaws the trickster reveals are thoroughly the trickster's own. They are not a foil to a corrupt society; they are instead essential to who the trickster is. The trickster is a comic figure precisely because of these somewhat irrational, compulsive, and foolish—in short, mortal—actions. Similarly, the trickster is a socially peripheral character not by being forced to the periphery by a hypocritical society, but rather because the trickster's thoroughly flawed character makes the trickster fundamentally antisocial, even anarchic, all the while helping listeners to avoid these flaws.

It is this combination of mythic setting and mortal weakness that determines the particular targets of the trickster's comic high jinks: the eternal and unchanging foibles of mortal beings. In one story, for example, a coyote trickster falls in love with a star. The trickster is quite tenacious and human, even though the object of desire is beyond reasonable mortal possibility. In the end the star takes the trickster up into the sky, only to let the trickster fall back to Earth; the story's listeners realize that the trickster has gotten a comeuppance for reaching beyond proper limits, but all the while they recognize in themselves the trickster's extravagant hopes.
items.stemText: The passage provides the most support for inferring that conventional society as portrayed in picaresque novels perceives the picaro as representing a dangerous, disruptive freedom for which one of the following reasons?

options.optionContent: The picaro has the potential to inflict physical injury on society members.
The picaro threatens to upset long-standing political structures.
The picaro has been marginalized by conventional society.
The picaro threatens to force society to face its hypocrisy.
The picaro suffers no consequences for indulging in his vices.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this answer choice say that members of society believe the picaro's freedom risks exposing their hypocrisy or the fact they indulge in similar vices? Nope. For that reason, efficient test-takers would table or eliminate this answer choice, without unnecessarily taking the time to review the passage to confirm that (A) is incorrect. If we needed to review the passage to eliminate (A), we wouldn't find any support for the claim that the picaro might inflict physical injury on society. Just because society views the picaro's freedom as “dangerous” does mean that the danger involves physical injury. In fact, the author claims the picaro's impulses are “innocent” (P2, S3), suggesting that the picaro isn't at risk of injuring anyone.

Does this answer choice say that members of society believe the picaro's freedom risks exposing their hypocrisy or the fact they indulge in similar vices? Negative. So, experienced test-takers would table or eliminate this answer choice, not waste time reviewing the passage to see if “political structures” were mentioned. If we had to research the passage, we'd find that the second paragraph never mentions “political structures” or anything like that. The only reasons given for society's perception of the picaro are the picaro's open indulgences and society's hypocrisy. That means the passage doesn't provide any support for (B).

Does this answer choice say that members of society believe the picaro's freedom risks exposing their hypocrisy or the fact they indulge in similar vices? Again, no. So, expert test-takers would table or eliminate this answer choice rather than spend time reviewing the passage to see if (C) is supported. Still, many test-takers choose (C) — especially those who simply review the sentence in which “dangerous, disruptive freedom” is mentioned without considering what this question stem is asking. This sentence describes marginalizing the picaro from conventional society (P2, S6). However, it says society marginalizes the picaro because it views the picaro's freedom as dangerous and disruptive. (C) implies that society views the picaro's freedom as dangerous and disruptive because it marginalized the picaro. Therefore, (C) reverses the cause-and-effect relationship stated by the passage. So, (C) is factually untrue, meaning it doesn't state not why society views the picaro's freedom as dangerous and disruptive.

Does this answer choice say that members of society believe the picaro's freedom risks exposing their hypocrisy or the fact they indulge in similar vices? Yes! It says that the picaro forces society to face its hypocrisy, which is very similar to “risk exposing” society's hypocrisy. Well-prepared test-takers would quickly select this one. Some may even opt to pass over (E) and move to Question 9 since this closely matches their anticipation.

Does this answer choice say that members of society believe the picaro's freedom risks exposing their hypocrisy or the fact they indulge in similar vices? Yet again, no. Assuming they hadn't already selected (D), experienced test-takers would table or eliminate this answer choice rather than spend time reviewing the passage to see if (E) is supported. If we had to check the passage to confirm that (E) is incorrect, we'd see that this answer choice is factually untrue. The picaro does suffer consequences for indulging in his vices — he's marginalized from society (P2, S6)! Some test-takers choose (E), assuming that the picaro's indulging in vices “with relish and freedom” (P2, S4) means the picaro doesn't suffer any consequences. While this inference is tempting, it's directly contradicted by the text in the passage. Because (E) is factually untrue, we can't say it's why society views the picaro's freedom as dangerous and disruptive.

items.stimulusText:

Recently, the term "trickster" has also appeared in criticism of sixteenth- and seventeenth-century European literature, particularly in reference to the picaresque novel and its central character, the picaro (Spanish for "rogue"): both the picaro and the trickster are heroes of episodic adventures, and both live on the peripheries of society and are morally flawed.

But the trickster, usually an animal acting as a human agent, does not serve a satiric function. In fact, whatever flaws the trickster reveals are thoroughly the trickster's own. They are not a foil to a corrupt society; they are instead essential to who the trickster is. The trickster is a comic figure precisely because of these somewhat irrational, compulsive, and foolish—in short, mortal—actions. Similarly, the trickster is a socially peripheral character not by being forced to the periphery by a hypocritical society, but rather because the trickster's thoroughly flawed character makes the trickster fundamentally antisocial, even anarchic, all the while helping listeners to avoid these flaws.

It is this combination of mythic setting and mortal weakness that determines the particular targets of the trickster's comic high jinks: the eternal and unchanging foibles of mortal beings. In one story, for example, a coyote trickster falls in love with a star. The trickster is quite tenacious and human, even though the object of desire is beyond reasonable mortal possibility. items.stemText: Based on the author's view in the passage, applying the term "trickster" to the character of the picaro is most similar to which one of the following?

options.optionContent: claiming that someone supports an extreme political view when it is clear that the person supports a centrist view
characterizing the panda as a bear based on superficial similarities when a deeper understanding shows it to be related instead to the raccoon
calling a court decision a milestone as a way of suggesting metaphorically that the decision is significant
classifying a species of pine tree as an evergreen even though many of its needles turn brown and fall off during certain seasons
describing a common weed as aggressive because it outcompetes certain garden flowers for sun and water

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does (A) describe a situation in which a term is applied to something similar, but the use of that term hides significant differences between the two entities? Not really. An “extreme political view” isn't ostensibly similar to a “centrist political view,” in the way that “trickster” and “picaro” are seemingly alike. (A) more accurately describes a direct mischaracterization, rather than the use of a comparable term that ultimately disguises key differences.

Does (B) describe a situation in which a term is applied to something similar, but the use of that term hides significant differences between the two entities? Yes! The term “bear” is used because pandas and bears possess “superficial similarities.” This is similar to the superficial similarities the “trickster” and “picaro” share. Both are flawed heroes of episodic adventures who live on the outskirts of society (P1, S2). However, the use of the term “bear” hides key differences between pandas and bears — namely, that pandas are more closely related to raccoons. This is similar to the key differences between the “picaro” and “trickster” (such as their distinct purposes). An expert test-taker would be satisfied that (B) is correct and would take an at-most cursory glance at (C)-(E).

Does (C) describe a situation in which a term is applied to something similar, but the use of that term hides significant differences between the two entities? Nope. In this case, the term “milestone” is used as a metaphor. (A quick review on “metaphor” for those who want it: A metaphor is a word or phrase that is applied to an entity to which that word is not literally applicable but nonetheless figuratively describes that entity. Obviously, a judicial decision isn't a stone and doesn't mark miles on a road. But, if you think that significant judicial decisions mark essential moments on the “road” of history, the word “milestone” fits.) The author never suggests that the term “trickster” is used as a metaphor for picaros. “trickster” could be a word that literally applies to picaros — had there not been essentially differences between the two. (C) doesn't describe any “essential differences” hidden by the term “milestone”, so it doesn't capture the author's view.

Does (D) describe a situation in which a term is applied to something similar, but the use of that term hides significant differences between the two entities? Not really, although many test-takers understandably select (D). (D) focuses on the essential differences between pine trees and evergreens. Pine trees are not, literally speaking, “evergreen” if their needles sometimes turn brown. However, (D) doesn't provide any reason to believe that pine trees and evergreens are superficially similar. Sure, they're both tree species. But the trickster and picaro had more superficial similarities than just both being literary figures. They were both flawed heroes of episodic adventures who lived on the outskirts of society (P1, S2). Like (A), this answer choice describes a mischaracterization, not the use of a similar term that ultimately disguises crucial differences.

Does (E) describe a situation in which a term is applied to something similar, but the use of that term hides significant differences between the two entities? Nope. (E) doesn't describe any significant differences between the term “aggressive” and the weed the term describes. Perhaps there's some anthropomorphizing here, but the author's issue wasn't that the term “trickster” is a human word used to describe a non-human. (In fact, the trickster was the animal spirit, while the picaro was the human character (P3, S1-2).) For this reason, (E) does not capture the author's view on the use of the word “trickster” to describe the “picaro.”

items.stemText: The author of the passage states that the flaws of the trickster are not a foil to a corrupt society (middle of the third paragraph) primarily in order to

options.optionContent: demonstrate that the trickster is a comic figure with supernatural powers
allude to the functional similarities between the trickster and the picaro
contrast the role of the trickster with that of the picaro
illustrate how the trickster is used to engage in social commentary
emphasize the disruptive, anarchic character of the trickster

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We're looking for an answer choice that says the author included this detail to reveal how the trickster is different from the picaro. Does (A) convey that purpose? Nope. Expert test-takers would eliminate this answer choice simply because it didn't match their anticipation. If we needed to take more time to contemplate (A), we'd see that the author believes that the trickster is a comic figure because the trickster is filled with “irrational, compulsive—in short, mortal—actions” (P3, S5). This trickster comedy has very little to do with the fact the trickster is “not a foil to a corrupt society.” Moreover, the author never explicitly claims the trickster has supernatural powers in the third paragraph (although this fact is stated in the first paragraph and implied by the coyote example in the fourth paragraph).

We're looking for an answer choice that says the author included this detail to reveal how the trickster is different from the picaro. Does (B) convey that purpose? Nope. (B) says the opposite of what we're looking for. We can confidently eliminate this answer choice simply because it contradicts our anticipation.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the author included this detail to reveal how the trickster is different from the picaro. Does (C) convey that purpose? Yes, it does! “Contrast the role of the trickster with that of the picaro” perfectly describes the role of the third paragraph — and thus the role of this particular detail. In fact, this matches our anticipation so closely that we'd be justified in selecting (C) and moving directly to Question 11.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the author included this detail to reveal how the trickster is different from the picaro. Does (D) convey that purpose? Nope. Experienced test-takers would eliminate (D) simply because it didn't match their anticipation, assuming they hadn't already selected (C) and moved on. If we needed to review (D), we'd see that it's factually untrue. The trickster does not satirize or comment on society —the picaro does (P3, S2). Because (D) is untrue, it cannot convey why the author included the detail in question.

We're looking for an answer choice that says the author included this detail to reveal how the trickster is different from the picaro. Does (E) convey that purpose? Nope. Well-prepared test-takers would cross off (E) once they realized it didn't match their anticipation, assuming they hadn't already selected (C) and moved on. If we had to examine (E) more closely, we'd see that the author believes the trickster is disruptive and anarchic because the trickster is flawed (P3, S6). The author doesn't think the trickster's disruptive, anarchic character results from the fact that the trickster is not a foil to a corrupt society. Since (E) misstates the author's view, it cannot accurately convey the author's purpose.

items.stimulusText:
Native American stories often feature a character called the trickster, a comic figure who has both mortal weaknesses and supernatural powers. Recently, the term "trickster" has also appeared in criticism of sixteenth- and seventeenth-century European literature, particularly in reference to the picaresque novel and its central character, the picaro (Spanish for "rogue"): both the picaro and the trickster are heroes of episodic adventures, and both live on the peripheries of society and are morally flawed.

Yet closer examination reveals that applying the term "trickster" to both characters obscures essential differences between them. The picaro—typically a male character—operates primarily as an agent of satire. Most commonly, the picaro's adventures begin when he spontaneously yields to his own roguish, though innocent, impulses. The picaro indulges in vices and follies with relish and freedom, much to the outrage of other members of society, who often secretly indulge in similar pastimes out of a habitual compulsion. Thus the picaro's authenticity serves as a foil to the perceived hypocrisy of conventional society. To such a society, the picaro can represent a dangerous, disruptive freedom, and it reacts by marginalizing him. It is in that distance—between the ostensibly disreputable freedom of the picaro and the hypocrisy of the safely ensconced social being—that the satire occurs.

But the trickster, usually an animal acting as a human agent, does not serve a satiric function. For while the picaresque novel takes place in and satirizes human society, the trickster operates in the ahistorical world of myth; where the targets of the picaresque novel are the idiosyncrasies and inconsistencies of a historical human society, trickster stories seek, using the trickster's negative example, to instruct listeners about moral behavior of individuals. In fact, whatever flaws the trickster reveals are thoroughly the trickster's own. They are not a foil to a corrupt society; they are instead essential to who the trickster is. The trickster is a comic figure precisely because of these somewhat irrational, compulsive, and foolish—in short, mortal—actions. Similarly, the trickster is a socially peripheral character not by being forced to the periphery by a hypocritical society, but rather because the trickster's thoroughly flawed character makes the trickster fundamentally antisocial, even anarchic, all the while helping listeners to avoid these flaws.

It is this combination of mythic setting and mortal weakness that determines the particular targets of the trickster's comic high jinks: the eternal and unchanging foibles of mortal beings. In one story, for example, a coyote trickster falls in love with a star. The trickster is quite tenacious and human, even though the object of desire is beyond reasonable mortal possibility. In the end the star takes the trickster up into the sky, only to let the trickster fall back to Earth; the story's listeners realize that the trickster has gotten a comeuppance for reaching beyond proper limits, but all the while they recognize in themselves the trickster's extravagant hopes.
items.stemText: Based on the passage, the author would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements about the literary criticism mentioned in the second sentence of the first paragraph?

options.optionContent: It has systematically denigrated the literary traditions of Native Americans.
Its use of the trickster appellation has nothing to do with the Native American trickster character.
Its reading of picaresque novels is at odds with its reading of Native American trickster stories.
It reflects an attempt to be precise in the use of literary terminology.
It bases its analysis on an incomplete understanding of trickster stories.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this consistent with the author's main point that using the term trickster to describe the picaro hides the essential differences between the two literary figures? No, this is way too critical of the literary critics. The author argued that the literary critics might overlook important differences between the trickster and the picaro. But the author never said or suggested that these critics denigrate or diminish Native American literary traditions. Therefore, this is incorrect.

Is this consistent with the author's main point that using the term trickster to describe the picaro hides the essential differences between the two literary figures? Not quite. However, many test-takers may pause to mull this one over. In that case, the most efficient approach to this answer choice would be to refrain from checking the passage. Instead, keep (B) in contention but move on to the remaining answer choices to see if any are a better match for the main point. On the other hand, expert test-takers may feel more comfortable eliminating this since it uses very strong, difficult-to-support language (“nothing to do with”). A closer examination would reveal that (B), like (A), is too strong of a statement. Even the author concedes that the trickster and picaro share some similar characteristics. For instance, the author admits that the trickster and picaro are both “socially peripheral” characters (P3, S6). So the author wouldn't agree that the use of the trickster “appellation” (title) has nothing to do with the Native American trickster character.

Is this consistent with the author's main point that using the term trickster to describe the picaro hides the essential differences between the two literary figures? Not quite. Still, (C) entices some test-takers. If you were attracted to (C), you should note that it's close to but not entirely consistent with the main point. So, the most efficient approach to this answer choice would be to refrain from checking the passage to see if (C) is supported. Instead, keep it contention but move on to the remaining answer choices to see if any are a better match for the main point. A close examination of (C) would reveal that it's unsupported. The author never suggests that the literary critics have read Native American trickster stories — they may be entirely unaware of the trickster stories. (Additionally, note that the author calls the Native American stories “stories” and not literature or novels. Later, the author refers to the audience of these stories as “listeners” (P4, S4). So, the passage doesn't even claim that these stories are written — they are probably oral stories. Technically, the critics couldn't read these stories if the stories were not written.) Assuming they have read trickster stories, it's a bit too strong to suggest that the critics' readings of the two are “at odds.” The critics note similarities between the two figures — similarities that even the author acknowledges are present (P3, S6). So the author wouldn't agree that the literary critics are applying different, contradictory reading approaches to the two stories.

Is this consistent with the author's main point that using the term trickster to describe the picaro hides the essential differences between the two literary figures? Nope. The author never claims whether the critics are trying to be precise. (Although, regardless of their intent, the author certainly thinks the critics are imprecise when they use “trickster” to describe the picaro.) So, we can safely eliminate (D).

Is this consistent with the author's main point that using the term trickster to describe the picaro hides the essential differences between the two literary figures? It's close and thus may warrant a closer examination of the text. If the author thinks the critics ignore essential differences between the trickster and picaro, the author may believe that the critics lack a complete understanding of the trickster story. If we review the passage for the author's attitude (which shouldn't take too long if we highlighted or underlined the author's attitude), we could find some support. In the second paragraph, the author claims a “closer examination reveals” that the critics' use of “trickster” to describe the picaro “obscures essential differences between them” (P2, S1). This suggests the critics have not engaged in this close examination of the trickster stories and base their use on an incomplete understanding of trickster stories. So, (E) is best supported by the passage.

items.stemText: In the context of the passage, which one of the following most accurately captures the meaning of the term "authenticity" in the middle of the second paragraph?

options.optionContent: conforming to an original
having certain essential features
behaving as others do
inspiring absolute trust
following one's natural inclinations

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does “conforming to an original” seem related to the fact that the picaro engages in similar vices as members of society but does so openly and enthusiastically? Not really. Although this is a valid definition of “authenticity,” the author never says or implies that the picaro is an original. In fact, if the picaro enjoys similar indulgences as members of conventional society (P2, S4), the picaro isn't terribly original in his vices.

Does “having certain essential features” seem related to the fact that the picaro engages in similar vices as members of society but does so openly and enthusiastically? Not really. This description doesn't seem related to the picaro's free and enthusiastic behavior, and it doesn't really form a contrast with conventional society's hypocrisy. Besides, this isn't an accepted definition of “authentic,” which typically means genuine, original, or true.

Does “behaving as others do” seem related to the fact that the picaro engages in similar vices as members of society but does so openly and enthusiastically? It captures the first part but fails to describe the picaro's open and enthusiastic enjoyment of vices. Therefore, this description doesn't contrast with conventional society's hypocrisy. Moreover, this isn't an accepted definition of “authentic,” which typically means genuine, original, or true.

Does “inspiring absolute trust” seem related to the fact that the picaro engages in similar vices as members of society but does so openly and enthusiastically? Not at all. We can safely eliminate this one. Besides, this isn't an accepted definition of “authentic,” which typically means genuine, original, or true. (Although some would reasonably trust something “authentic,” that doesn't mean “authentic” necessarily refers to something that inspires absolute trust.)

Does “following one's natural inclinations” seem related to the fact that the picaro engages in similar vices as members of society but does so openly and enthusiastically? Yes, it does. If the picaro engages in the vices “with relish and freedom,” it certainly seems he follows his natural inclinations. This contrasts nicely with society's “hypocrisy,” since members of society feel compelled to hide their indulgences. Crucially, this is also an accepted definition of “authenticity,” particularly authenticity's denotement of genuineness.
