items.stemText: Suppose a corporation has for decades polluted a river on which a major city is located with toxic waste known to increase the incidence of certain forms of cancer. Which one of the following scenarios would most closely conform to the author's views regarding how corporate wrongdoing is most effectively addressed?

options.optionContent: In response to criminal prosecution of the corporation, several of the corporation's shareholders put pressure on the corporation's board of directors to ensure that the corporation will dispose of waste in an environmentally sound manner.
In order to assist in civil litigation against the corporation, the federal government moves to expand the use of enforcement powers traditionally reserved for criminal prosecution.
The corporation's largest shareholders are sued by several residents of the city who suffer from a form of cancer associated with the toxic waste dumped by the corporation.
The city prosecutes the corporation's top executives for violating several city ordinances when they ordered the dumping of toxic waste into the river.

The city government and several residents of the city hold a press conference in which they attempt to undermine the reputation of the corporation and thereby pressure the corporation to change its practices.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this answer choice involve the criminal prosecution of the corporation? Yes, it does! This adds some details, though. It says that in response to this criminal prosecution, the polluting corporation's shareholders pressure its board to dispose of waste in an environmentally sound manner. Is that consistent with the author's stance? It is! The author claimed that criminal prosecution of a corporation can “motivate shareholders to push for better corporate practices” (P4, S5). That is exactly what happened here. Because this matches our anticipation and what we know about the author's stance, we can select it and move on to the next question without reading the remaining answer choices. Skipping four answer choices can save us a lot of time on a question that features answer choices this lengthy.

Does this answer choice involve the criminal prosecution of the corporation? Nope. An experienced test-taker may not read past “civil litigation.” We know the author prefers criminal prosecution, so an answer choice that involves civil litigation isn't going to match the author's views — even if the federal government attempts to augment civil litigation with enforcement powers typically reserved for criminal prosecution.

Does this answer choice involve the criminal prosecution of the corporation? No. Expert test-takers might not read past “shareholders are sued by several residents.” Residents bringing a lawsuit against shareholders involves a civil suit against individuals within a corporation. That's quite different from the author's preferred system — criminal prosecution of the corporation itself.

Does this answer choice involve the criminal prosecution of the corporation? Nope. Decisive test-takers might not read past “corporation's top executives.” This answer choice at least involves criminal prosecution, unlike (B) and (C). However, this criminal action is brought against the individuals within the corporation rather than the corporation itself.

Does this answer choice involve the criminal prosecution of the corporation? Again, no. This doesn't involve legal action of any kind, so this doesn't describe the author's preferred method to deter corporate wrongdoing.

items.questionType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts
items.displayType: Applying the Argument to New Contexts

items.stimulusText:
The use of criminal sanctions against corporations is well established, but the practice has recently come under fire from legal theorists who maintain that corporations should be held civilly rather than criminally liable for wrongdoing. Civil liability, these theorists argue, shares important features with criminal liability: both impose punishment on a company, both aim at deterrence, and both degrade a company's reputation. Yet, they claim, civil liability is better able to determine appropriate levels of damages. Furthermore, because criminal liability causes a greater loss of reputation, its overall cost to corporations is far higher than that of civil liability; this additional cost is borne by society at large in the form of higher product prices. Finally, civil liability is also more cost-effective from the point of view of the government: the greater procedural protections of criminal law make deterrence through criminal prosecution extremely expensive.

Even if it is less economical, however, criminal liability is a much stronger deterrent. The considerable enforcement powers involved, including the ability to detain and question corporate officials, are themselves significant deterrents. Furthermore, the fact that private civil litigation requires an identifiable victim with the necessary resources to commence litigation weakens its deterrent impact. Most importantly, the main function of criminal law is to censure wrongdoing and to emphasize that society forcefully rejects such conduct. Civil liability is ill suited for this purpose.

Other legal theorists who do not object to criminal sanctions per se argue that individuals within corporations, rather than corporations themselves, are the appropriate target of criminal prosecution in cases involving corporate wrongdoing. They maintain that individuals within corporations are more responsive to deterrence because they generally fear prosecution and the loss of employment that can result from it. Additionally, they say, punishment of a corporation, in the form of a fine, essentially punishes shareholders, creditors, employees who may be laid off, and ultimately the public, which is forced to absorb higher prices.

However, this approach is also misguided. Corporations often bury responsibility within complex hierarchies, with the result that no individual responsible for corporate misdeeds can be identified. Another problem is that under this approach, a corporation will often find it cheaper to designate and compensate an internal scapegoat to face prosecution than to refrain from wrongdoing. The most effective way to ensure that corporations improve their practices is to hold corporations themselves criminally liable for their conduct. Indeed, criminal liability works on shareholders as well as corporate officers and employees: because criminal punishment of corporations decreases their wealth, it can motivate shareholders to push for better corporate practices. Arguments that shareholders and employees need economic protection are outweighed by the greater societal interest in ensuring the safety of employees, the public, and the environment.
items.stemText: The author would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements?

options.optionContent: In many instances, corporations that are not deterred by the threat of criminal sanctions would be deterred by the threat of civil sanctions.
The main function of civil liability is to punish harmful acts in cases where no individual responsible for corporate misdeeds can be identified.
Currently, corporations are more often subject to civil litigation than to criminal prosecution.
Many people who criticize the use of criminal sanctions to deter corporate wrongdoing believe that such wrongdoing seldom causes harm to individuals.
In a significant number of cases, corporations engage in wrongdoing that does not harm anyone with sufficient resources to sue.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Is this answer choice consistent with the author's main point or what you can recall about the author's views? This is inconsistent with the author's main point. The author believes that criminal sanctions are better at deterring corporate wrongdoing than civil sanctions. So the author certainly wouldn't agree with the claim that corporations would be deterred by the threat of civil sanctions when they're not deterred by the threat of criminal sanctions. We can safely eliminate this one without reviewing the passage.

Is this answer choice consistent with the author's main point or what you can recall about the author's views? It doesn't contradict the main point, so we can't eliminate it at this point. If we can't recall whether the author would agree with this, we should ask if we remember reading about the author's views on the “main function of civil liability.” If you don't remember reading this detail, it's best to table this answer choice and move on to the next one. If you remember reading about this detail, we can review the passage to determine whether the author would agree with it. Upon review, we would see that the author says that civil liability requires an “identifiable victim with the necessary resources to commence litigation” (P2, S3). If civil suits only apply to cases with an identifiable victim, then civil liability cannot punish harmful acts in cases with no identifiable victim. Therefore, the author definitely disagrees with this statement.

Is this answer choice consistent with the author's main point or what you can recall about the author's views? Our anticipated main point was, “Although some criticize the well-established use of criminal liability for corporations, it is the most effective way to deter illegal corporate activity.” If corporate criminal liability is “well-established,” then corporations must be more often subject to criminal prosecution. We can eliminate (C) because it conflicts with the main point.

Is this answer choice consistent with the author's main point or what you can recall about the author's views? This doesn't conflict with the main point. If we can't recall whether the author would agree with this, we should ask if we remember reading about the author's views on those who criticize the use of criminal sanctions. If you don't remember reading this, it's best to table this answer choice and move on to the next one. If you remember reading about this, we can review the passage to determine whether the author would agree with it. Since this asks about the author's views on those who criticize the use of criminal sanctions against corporations, the supporting text would have to be in the second paragraph. In that paragraph, the author never claims that the critics of criminal sanctions believe that corporate wrongdoing doesn't harm individuals. These critics didn't argue that corporate wrongdoing was victimless — they argued that criminal sanctions were too costly to society and the government (P1, S4-5). For this reason, we can't say the author would agree with (D).

Is this answer choice consistent with the author's main point or what you can recall about the author's views? This doesn't conflict with the main point. If we can recall reading about this detail, we can review the passage to see if it's supported. In the second paragraph, the author says an identifiable victim must have the necessary resources to sue before civil litigation can be brought against a corporation (P2, S3). The author says this requirement “weakens” civil liability's ability to deter corporate wrongdoing. How could this requirement weaken deterrence? The must be many cases of corporate misconduct in which there isn't an identifiable victim, or the victims lack the resources to bring a civil suit. Therefore, the author almost certainly agrees with (E), making it the correct answer.

content: Franchot Ballinger, "Ambigere: The Euro-American Picaro and the Native American Trickster" in MELUS. Copyright 1992 by the Society for the Study of the Multi-Ethnic Literature of the United States.
Christopher Ricks, "Plagiarism" in Plagiarism in Early Modern England. Edited by Paulina Kewes. Copyright 2003 by Christopher Ricks.
Paulina Kewes, "Historicizing Plagiarism" in Plagiarism in Early Modern England. Edited by Paulina Kewes. Copyright 2003 by Paulina Kewes.

sections.directions: Directions: Each question in this section is based on the reasoning presented in a brief passage. In answering the questions, you should not make assumptions that are by commonsense standards implausible, superfluous, or incompatible with the passage. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText: Many people who simply enjoy listening to popular music do not realize that it has been used to express religious and political messages. After all, popular music has repeatedly been adopted by social movements to express their viewpoints, since it has the potential to contribute to the "conversion" of nonmembers to the movement's position, as well as to raise the morale and to express the solidarity of the movement's participants.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion of the argument?

options.optionContent: Popular music accounts for the success of social movements.
Popular music's entertainment value has been overemphasized.
Popular music is the most effective way of converting people to social movements.
Popular music has purposes other than mere entertainment.
Popular music has a profound emotional impact on its listeners.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The correct answer to a Main Point question must meet two criteria. First, it must be true, based on the passage. Second, it must accurately express the same idea as the main conclusion. When assessing an answer choice to a Main Point question, we can first ask if the statement is even true.

The correct answer to a Main Point question must meet two criteria. First, it must be true, based on the passage. Second, it must accurately express the same idea as the main conclusion. When assessing an answer choice to a Main Point question, we can first ask if the statement is even true. So, does the author ever claim that pop music's entertainment value has been overemphasized? Nope. Although the author claims that pop music also can express social and religious messages, that doesn't imply that the author thinks the entertainment value is overemphasized. Everyone may appreciate pop music's entertainment value at the proper level while also failing to appreciate pop music's social and religious messages. So, this answer choice isn't even true and thus fails the first criterion for Main Point answer choices.

The correct answer to a Main Point question must meet two criteria. First, it must be true, based on the passage. Second, it must accurately express the same idea as the main conclusion. When assessing an answer choice to a Main Point question, we can first ask if the statement is even true. So, does the author ever claim that pop music is the best way to convert people to social movements? Nope. The author claims (as a premise) that it can convert people to social movements. But that doesn't imply that pop music is the best way to convert people to movements. So, this answer choice isn't even true and thus fails the first criterion for Main Point answer choices.

Some test-takers may take issue with the phrasing of this answer choice. But let's follow the two-part analysis of Main Point answer choices. First, the answer choice must be true, based on the passage. Does the author think pop music has purposes beyond “entertainment”? Yes! The author thinks pop music can express religious and political messages. That's definitely a non-entertainment purpose. Second, the answer choice must accurately express the same idea as the main conclusion. Does this answer choice get at the same idea as the conclusion? That pop music has been used to express religious and political messages? Also, yes! Although this is phrased in a much more general way than the argument, this answer choice describes a very similar idea as the argument's main conclusion. The argument's main conclusion asserts that some people who listen to pop music for entertainment value fail to recognize pop music's capacity to express religious and political messages. So the argument wants to convey the idea that pop music can be used for things other than pure entertainment. This passes both criteria for a Main Point answer choice and is therefore correct.

The correct answer to a Main Point question must meet two criteria. First, it must be true, based on the passage. Second, it must accurately express the same idea as the main conclusion. When assessing an answer choice to a Main Point question, we can first ask if the statement is even true. So, does the author ever claim that pop music has a profound emotional impact on its listeners? Not quite. The author says that pop music can raise listeners' “morale” and convert them to social movements, but that effect is never characterized as “profound.” Even ignoring that, the author conveys this idea as a premise, not as the argument's main point.

items.stimulusText: Council president: Councilmember Smith has proposed a new city ordinance prohibiting the use of the "bait-and-switch" sales tactic. Smith must have amnesia. Four years ago he owned an appliance store that was famous for its use of bait-and-switch. Clearly, Smith's proposed ordinance does not even merit consideration.
items.stemText: The council president's reasoning is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the president

options.optionContent: dismisses the proposed ordinance because of its source rather than because of its content
takes a single fact that is incompatible with a claim as enough to show that claim to be false
fails to make a needed distinction between deceptive sales tactics and legitimate methods of increasing sales
draws a conclusion that simply restates a claim presented in support of that conclusion
generalizes from a limited number of instances of a certain kind to all instances of that kind

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice describes an ad hominem flaw perfectly. Indeed, this president dismisses Smith's proposed ordinance because of its source (the hypocritical Councilmember Smith) rather than because of the proposal's content. The proposal could be fantastic, but the president wouldn't know due to this flawed reasoning.

This doesn't describe inherently flawed reasoning, much less flawed reasoning in the president's argument. It's sometimes OK to use a “single fact that is incompatible with a claim” as a way to show that the claim is false. If I claimed, “All dogs are the color orange,” presenting me with one non-orange dog would be a single fact that is enough to show my claim is false. Some test-takers may pause over this answer choice since it appears that the president may use something akin to a “single fact that is incompatible with a claim.” If we assume the “claim” is Smith's proposal, that would make Smith's past use of bait-and-switch tactics the “single fact” referenced by this answer choice. However, these two things aren't truly “incompatible.” Viewing bait-and-switch sales tactics as acceptable four years ago and viewing them as unacceptable today isn't a contradiction—it could just be evidence of changed beliefs.

When we see “fails to consider” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the author's argument if true?” Even if there were distinctions between “deceptive” and “legitimate” sales tactics, that wouldn't weaken the president's argument. And that's because the president's argument isn't about what's an acceptable or unacceptable sales tactic. It's about whether we should accept Smith's proposal despite Smith's past inconsistent behavior. Perhaps this answer choice would be correct if the president's dismissal of Smith's proposal relied on an unsubstantiated claim that “bait-and-switch” tactics were legitimate, but that's not at all how this president supports the conclusion.

This refers to circular reasoning, a flaw in which the conclusion merely restates a premise. That is not the case here, as the premise is about Smith's past behavior, and the conclusion is about Smith's current proposal.

Like many incorrect answer choices on Errors in Reasoning questions, this misconstrues the argument's conclusion. The conclusion did not generalize to “all instances” of proposals, sales tactics, or anything else. The conclusion was just about one proposal to ban bait-and-switch sales tactics. Because this answer choice doesn't even accurately describe the president's argument, it cannot accurately describe a flaw in the president's argument.

items.stimulusText: Bovine remains found in a certain region of Africa date back to a time when the climate was arid. While there were people in the region at this time, there were no other large mammals there. Any natural sources of water available to these bovines would have brought other large mammals to the area. Thus, these bovines had been domesticated and the people living in the region were no longer exclusively hunter-gatherers.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?

options.optionContent: Unless they are domesticated, bovines are unlikely to exist in a region where there are no natural sources of water available to them.
Domesticating animals is one of the first practices that a society must adopt in order to change from hunting and gathering to agriculture.
With the help of humans, other large mammals would have been able to inhabit this arid region.
No human culture obtains food both through agriculture and through hunting and gathering.
Domesticated animals of a given size do not need as much water as do wild animals of comparable size.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice addresses the gap between the lack of natural water sources and the bovine's domestication. We expected that the correct answer would say, “If bovines are present in a region with no natural water sources, those bovines are domesticated.” This answer choice essentially provides the contrapositive of that anticipation, “If bovines weren't domesticated, they probably wouldn't be in a region without a natural source of water.” Since the contrapositive and original statements are logically equivalent, this answer choice strengthens the argument by linking those two concepts. It establishes that the bovines in this region of Africa are probably domesticated by the people living there. Moreover, the negation test will confirm that this answer choice is necessary to the argument. Suppose bovines could live in an area without a natural water source, even if they weren't domesticated. Would that weaken this argument? Absolutely. In that case, the bovines could be in the region for reasons other than domestication. Therefore, this answer choice is necessary to the argument and is correct.

This answer choice links the two new ideas in the conclusion. However, that will not strengthen the argument. Even if it's true that domesticating animals is one of the first things a group will do following its hunger-gatherer phase, that doesn't mean the group mentioned in the passage were hunter-gatherers or bovine-domesticators. There's a reason we want to connect these new ideas to premises. To strengthen the argument, we need to connect the new idea to something we know to be true (a premise). We don't know whether either of the two new ideas in the conclusion is true, so linking them together won't strengthen the argument.

This may strengthen the argument. If other animals could have inhabited this region with humans' help, it seems more reasonable to conclude that the bovines may have also relied on humans' help through domestication. However, this isn't necessary to the argument. Even if other large mammals couldn’t inhabit this region with human help, it would still be possible that bovines could. Perhaps bovines possess some unique characteristic that allows them to inhabit the land. Because this answer choice is not necessary to draw the conclusion, it is incorrect.

This answer choice is far too strong to be necessary to draw this conclusion. Notice how the conclusion says the people in this region were “no longer exclusively hunter-gatherers.” That allows for the possibility that these people were engaging in both agriculture and hunting/gathering. Therefore, we don't need to know that “no human culture” acquires its food from agriculture and hunting and gathering.

This may strengthen the argument since it would make it easier for the human population to domesticate the bovines without a nearby natural water source. However, it isn't necessary to draw the argument's conclusion. Even if domesticated animals require just as much water as wild animals, the human population could have still domesticated these bovines. It may have been more difficult, but it could have nonetheless been possible.

items.stimulusText: Cerrato: Economists argue both that the higher turnover rate of part-time workers shows them to be much more likely to be dissatisfied with their jobs than full-time workers are and that lower-paid, part-time workers threaten to take jobs from full-time employees. But because job efficiency is positively correlated with job satisfaction, companies are unlikely to replace satisfied employees with dissatisfied ones. Therefore, _______.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most logically completes Cerrato's argument?

options.optionContent: full-time workers are likely to lose jobs to part-time workers
the companies earning the greatest profits tend to be those that pay their workers the highest wages
dissatisfied part-time workers are unlikely to threaten the jobs of full-time workers
the higher turnover rate of part-time workers is only partly caused by their greater job dissatisfaction
companies generally hire part-time workers only when they are unable to hire full-time ones

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is the opposite of what Cerrato believes to be true. Cerrato does not think companies will replace full-timers with less efficient, more dissatisfied part-timers.

Neither Cerrato nor the economist bring up anything about the companies “earning the greatest profits.” We have no idea what Cerrato thinks about such companies. Therefore, this would not be a valid conclusion that would complete this argument.
This is exactly what we're looking for. Therefore, it would be a reasonable and valid way to complete this argument, and it is correct.

The new facts Cerrato brings up are not about “the higher turnover rate of part-time workers.” They're instead about job efficiency and companies replacing employees. For this reason, a conclusion about part-time workers' turnover rate would be inappropriate and invalid.

This is a tempting answer choice. However, this changes the topic of Cerrato's argument slightly. Cerrato's argument is about replacing full-time workers with part-time workers. Cerrato thinks that probably doesn't occur. But this answer choice brings up hiring full-time and part-time workers. Even if Cerrato doesn't believe companies will replace full-time workers with part-timers, Cerrato may still believe that companies hire many part-timers even when they could hire full-time workers instead. That, technically, wouldn’t be “replacing” a full-time position with a part-timer. Perhaps many jobs are always intended to be part-time jobs. So, this answer choice would not be a valid conclusion if added to the argument, and it is incorrect.

items.stimulusText: On the plains where it lives, an individual zebra stands out because of its black-and-white stripes, which contrast with the green or brown of the surrounding vegetation. Yet zebras are a prey species, and the lions that hunt them can see stripes clearly. It seems surprising that zebras would survive with such vivid markings.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most adequately resolves the problem raised above?

options.optionContent: Because the vegetation on the open plains changes from green to brown as the season changes from wet to dry, true camouflage coloring for a prey species would have to change according to the seasons.
Zebras are able to judge from the demeanor of lions they see in the vicinity whether or not those lions are preparing to hunt, and the zebras ignore the lions that are not.

Lions that hunt zebras are themselves colored in a way that blends in with the brown color of dry vegetation, so that in the dry season, when prey is scarce, the lions can creep up on their prey to within a distance from which the lions have a favorable chance of succeeding in the hunt.
When lions hunt, the whole pride shares in the food obtained when a prey animal is successfully brought down by one of the hunting lions.
When zebras run in a group, as they generally do in response to danger, the stripe markings make it difficult for a predator pursuing a single individual to discern its outline.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Does this describe a benefit of zebra's stripes that will help zebras survive? No, so this does not resolve the paradox explained in the passage. A decisive and experienced test-taker would eliminate this answer choice without much consideration. If you'd like to undertake a more thorough analysis than would be necessary on test day, this answer choice just says that true camouflage in zebras' environment would have to change with the seasons. Of course, zebras' stripes do not change with the seasons. Really, this answer choice just points out something we already know—zebras' stripes stand in stark contrast to their environment. Rather than resolve the paradox, this simply reaffirms that the paradox exists.

Does this describe a benefit of zebra's stripes that will help zebras survive? Nope, so it will not resolve the paradox explained in the passage. A fast-moving test-taker would eliminate this answer choice without reservation. If you'd like to undertake a more thorough analysis, this answer choice just tells us that not all lions are immediate threats to zebras. However, it doesn't show how the zebras can survive when lions hunt zebras or how the zebras' stripes aid in their survival. So, this answer choice doesn't show how zebras survive despite their distinct, identifiable stripes. Rather, it shows that the stripes may not always present a problem.

Does this describe a benefit of zebra's stripes that will help zebras survive? Not at all, so it cannot resolve the paradox outlined by the passage. An efficient test-taker would cross this answer choice off without thinking twice. If you'd like to undertake a more thorough analysis, this answer choice doesn't address the paradox at all. The answer choice just tells us that lions use camouflage when hunting (at least during the dry season). But this can't explain why zebras' survive without traditional camouflage. If anything, by showing that animals in this region benefit from typical camouflage, this answer choice makes the paradox all the more inexplicable.

Does this show a benefit of zebra's stripes that will help zebras survive? Not in the slightest, so it does not resolve the paradox in the passage. Expedient test-takers would cross this answer choice off immediately. If you'd like to undertake a more thorough analysis than this choice may warrant, this answer choice doesn't tell us anything about zebras' stripes, so it doesn't address the paradox at all. Regardless of how the slain zebras are divvied up by lions, we still don't how the other zebras survive despite their vivid stripes.

Does this show a benefit of zebra's stripes that will help zebras survive? Finally, yes! This answer choice shows how at least many zebras can survive with their stripes. If the zebras flee from lions as a group, and their stripes make it difficult for the lions to see a single zebra's outline, it will be more difficult for the lion to attack and slay any given zebra. The lions see a giant mass of stripes rather than individual zebras it could pursue. Even if the lion tried to attack the giant mass of stripes, the zebras would blur together in the lion's vision, so the lion might miss completely!

items.stimulusText: Dark honey tends to have a higher antioxidant content than light-colored honey, and the most healthful strains of honey are all unusually high in antioxidants. However, certain strains of honey produced by bees harvesting primarily sage nectar are among the most healthful strains of honey, even though they are also among the lightest-colored strains of honey.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?

options.optionContent: Some strains of honey produced by bees harvesting sage nectar are unusually high in antioxidants.
Most plants produce nectar that, when harvested by bees, results in light-colored honey.
Light-colored honey tends to be more healthful than dark honey.
Certain strains of honey produced by bees harvesting primarily sage nectar are unusually low in antioxidants.
The strain of honey that has the highest antioxidant content is a light-colored honey.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice tells us that some types of honey made from sage nectar are unusually high in antioxidants. This is a valid conclusion that we can draw from the passage, and it is correct. Some test-takers may shy away from this choice since the terms may be in the opposite order that they anticipated. Many test-takers will anticipate the correct answer to say, “Some types of honey that are unusually high in antioxidants are made from sage nectar.” But it is equally valid to say, “Some types of honey that are made from sage nectar are unusually high in antioxidants.” And that is because “some” statements are reversible. Claiming that some types of honey that are unusually high in antioxidants are made from sage nectar is equivalent to saying there's at least one type of honey that is both high in antioxidants are made from sage nectar. If that's true, then it must also be true that there's at least one type of honey that is both made from sage nectar and high in antioxidants.

Is there anything in the passage that discusses the nectar produced from “most plants”? No. We don't know that most plants produce nectar, and we certainly don't know what colored honey the nectar from these plants would produce. We only know some plants that produce sage nectar, which results in light-colored honey when harvested. Therefore, we don't have any support to draw this conclusion, and this answer choice is incorrect.

We know that at least one type of light-colored honey is very healthful. But we can't use that single example to conclude that light-colored honey tends to be more healthful than dark-colored honey. That would be an unsupported generalization. (Experienced test-takers will recognize this as a sampling flaw.) In fact, we know that dark-colored honey tends to have more antioxidants than light-colored honey, which suggests (although not definitively) that the dark-colored varieties are generally more healthful than their light-colored counterparts.

We can validly conclude that some types of honey harvested from sage nectar are unusually high in antioxidants. But there are a few reasons why that does not imply that some of these types are unusually low in antioxidants. First, “some” statements do not exclude the possibility of “all.” Even though the passage just said “certain” strains of honey from sage nectar are healthful, and thus high in antioxidants, it could be the case that “all” strains of honey from sage nectar are healthful and thus high in antioxidants. Second, even if some strains of honey from sage nectar weren't high in antioxidants, that doesn't necessarily mean they must be unusually low in antioxidants. They could simply have an average or slightly below-average amount of antioxidants. (Experienced test-takers will recognize this as an exclusivity flaw.)

We can validly conclude that some light-colored types of honey are unusually high in antioxidants. But that doesn't imply that the type of honey with the most antioxidants is light-colored. The superlative language used by this answer choice is extremely difficult to support and, unsurprisingly, the passage doesn't provide the evidence to validly infer this claim.

items.stimulusText: Researcher: In a recent study of elementary school computers, we found that all keyboards and most monitors were positioned higher than recommended for children. Consequently, children were seated in ways that encouraged craned necks, awkwardly placed wrists, and other unhealthy postures. Evidently, most elementary school computers are installed without consideration of their effect on posture, and thus put children at the same risk for repetitive stress injuries as office workers.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the researcher's argument?

options.optionContent: The recommended height for computers is different for children than for adults.
Children spend more time working with computers at home than at school.
The greater suppleness of children's bodies makes them less susceptible than adults to repetitive stress injuries.
Office workers' keyboards and monitors are usually not at the recommended heights for healthy postures for adults.
Office workers are more likely to report injuries than children are.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Even if this is true, we still don't know that elementary school children are less likely to be injured by the computers' positioning. This answer choice could weaken the researcher's argument if said office workers' computers are positioned more out of line from their recommended height. But, as written, the answer choice provides no information about how office workers' computers are positioned relative to the recommendations.

This answer choice may tempt some test-takers, who assume that the computers schoolchildren use at home are not positioned awkwardly. However, that assumption is unfounded. It's possible that the home computers are also positioned much higher than the recommendations and that children maintain unhealthy postures on these computers too. Moreover, the conclusion is only about the school computers' effect on children. Any effect home computers have is irrelevant.

If we can get past the inherent ickiness of the phrase “suppleness,” we can see that this answer choice weakens the argument. It points out a relevant dissimilarity between schoolchildren and office workers that suggests schoolchildren are less likely to be injured by the computers. If schoolchildren are less susceptible to repetitive stress injury than adults, then the claim that children and adults are at the “same risk” of those injuries is questionable.

This strengthens the argument by presenting a similarity between the computers used by schoolchildren and office workers. If office workers' computers are also not set the recommended height, they may also adopt similarly harmful postures. This could make their risk of repetitive stress injuries comparable to the school children.

This conclusion is about whether schoolchildren are at the same risk of injury as adults. The likelihood that schoolchildren or adults report these injuries has no bearing on whether either will actually be injured. So this answer choice has no effect on the argument.

items.stimulusText: Sociologist: Some anthropologists claim that cultures can most effectively respond to the threat of cultural decay by replacing or abandoning many of their traditions so that other traditions may endure. But since each of its traditions is essential to a culture's identity, this strategy _______.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most logically completes the sociologist's argument?

options.optionContent: can save those cultures capable of reflecting on their customs and envisioning alternatives
will ensure the elimination of a culture rather than prevent its decay
can be implemented by all and only those cultures studied by anthropologists
constitutes the most effective response to the threat of cultural decay
can succeed if adopted by cultures whose traditions have been adopted only recently

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This sociologist does not think the anthropologists' strategy can “save” cultures. The sociologist claims that each culture's tradition is “essential” to the culture's identity. So even if the cultures can envision and implement alternative customs, the culture would still be chipping away at its identity by eliminating customs.

This might read as slightly over-the-top (even histrionic) to some, but it completes the sociologists' argument with a valid conclusion. After all, the sociologist claims that each culture's tradition is “essential” to the culture's identity. That means the sociologist thinks each tradition is necessary to maintain a culture's identity. In other words, the sociologist thinks a culture's identity will vanish after removing one of its traditions. So the sociologist must believe that the anthropologists' strategy of abandoning or replacing traditions will eliminate a culture rather than preserving it. Therefore, this is the correct answer.

The sociologist does not think the anthropologists' strategy should be adopted by any culture. Certainly, the sociologist wouldn't conclude that every culture studied by the anthropologists should adopt this strategy.

The sociologist disagrees with the anthropologists and does not believe their strategy is a viable solution to the threat of cultural decay. So, the sociologist definitely doesn't think that their strategy is the “most effective” solution.

The sociologist doesn't make any distinction between recent and long-standing traditions, so we have no reason to believe that sociologist thinks that the anthropologists' strategy could work for cultures with recently adopted traditions. Perhaps if the sociologist claimed that “each of its long-standing traditions is essential to a culture's identity,” this answer choice would be an apt conclusion. Instead, the sociologist said that each tradition—irrespective of its history—is essential to a culture's identity. Therefore, we must eliminate this answer choice.

items.stimulusText: Scholar: The purpose of a law is to deter certain actions by threatening to punish those performing the actions. This threat works only if potential violators believe that they are likely to be punished. But the likelihood that someone will be apprehended and punished for committing a prohibited act decreases as the number of types of prohibited actions increases. Therefore, a successful legal system prohibits only those few behaviors that citizens find absolutely intolerable.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the scholar's argument by the statement that the purpose of a law is to deter certain actions by threatening to punish those performing the actions?

options.optionContent: It is offered in support of the implicit conclusion that a legal system needs a significant number of police officers.
It is the conclusion of the argument.
It is a premise of the argument.
It is an intermediate conclusion.
It is the view that the argument as a whole is designed to discredit.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: There is no “implicit conclusion” that a legal system needs a significant number of police officers. Although the scholar notes that people will be deterred from committing crimes only if they think they'll be caught, the scholar's solution is not to increase the number of police. It's instead to limit the number of prohibited acts.
The last sentence is the main conclusion of the argument.
This is correct! The first sentence is a premise that supports the last sentence of this argument.

An intermediate (AKA subsidiary conclusion) is a statement that is supported by a premise, which in turn supports another conclusion. There is no intermediate (AKA subsidiary) conclusion in this argument. None of the premises in the first three sentences support one another. For instance, we don't need to know that threat of punishment is effective only if people think they'll be punished, or that people don't think they'll be punished when laws ban a ton of behaviors, to establish that the purpose of laws is to deter bad acts. So, each premise is an independent fact that directly supports the main conclusion.

The scholar is not trying to argue against the claim that the purpose of laws is to deter bad acts through the threat of punishment. In fact, the author needs to establish this to draw a conclusion about a “successful legal system.”

items.stimulusText: Historian: In the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries, the Swahili civilization of East Africa built tombs with large pillars and paneled facades. Such structures are widespread among the Oromo people of Somalia and Kenya, but are unknown among any other people with whom the Swahili civilization had contact. This indicates that Swahili culture was, to some extent, influenced by Oromo culture.
items.stemText: The historian's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it

options.optionContent: fails to address adequately the possibility that the Oromo people did not use the structures as tombs
concludes, simply because one event occurred earlier than another event, that the first event caused the second event
draws a restricted conclusion from premises that provide strong support for a much broader conclusion
takes for granted that there was no third civilization responsible for creating the first tombs of the kind found in both the Oromo and Swahili cultures
takes for granted that the Oromo people began constructing tombs with large pillars and paneled facades earlier than the Swahili civilization did

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: When we see “fails to address” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the conclusion if true?” This answer choice wouldn't weaken the conclusion. Even if the Omoro people did not use the large-pillared and paneled-facade structures as tombs, the style of these structures could have still influenced the Swahili culture. The historian's argument wasn't about the use of the structures influencing the Swahili culture; instead, it was about the style influencing the Swahili culture.

This answer choice gestures toward the temporal flaw, but it misdescribes how the argument is made. If an answer choice says a variation of, “Concludes, simply because ...” we need to make sure the claim that follows the “because” was a premise in the argument. But the premises never establish that “one event occurred earlier than another event in this argument.” In fact, the problem with this argument is that the historian never claimed that the Omoro people began constructing these tombs before the Swahili people. So, this answer choice misdescribes what the premises assert in this argument, making this answer choice incorrect.

It's not a flaw to “draw a restricted conclusion” even if your premises support “a much broader conclusion.” If the premises suggested that every African civilization in the fourteenth and fifteenth century built tombs with large pillars and paneled facades, we could certainly conclude the Swahili civilization built such tombs, even though the premises would support a more expansive conclusion.

When we see “takes for granted” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the questions we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” We don't have any evidence that the historian believes there wasn't a third civilization that first created the tombs found in the Oromo and Swahili cultures. The historian thinks that the Oromo people built these tombs first and influenced the Swahili tombs. But the historian may think another civilization constructed these tombs before the Oromo people and influenced the Oromo tombs. Remember, the historian just concludes that Oromo people influenced Swahili culture. The historian didn't conclude that the Oromo people originated this style. For this reason, this answer choice is incorrect.

This answer choice perfectly describes the historian's assumption. If you didn't anticipate this, and needed to assess this answer choice, you could simply ask yourself, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” The historian definitely believes the Oromo people began constructing this style of tomb first. Otherwise, the historian's conclusion that the Oromo culture influenced the Swahili culture wouldn't make any sense. And the Oromo people producing this style of tomb first would strengthen the argument, by eliminating the alternative explanation that the Swahili culture influenced the Oromo culture. Therefore, this answer choice is correct.

items.stimulusText: The chorus in a play, like a narrator in a novel, introduces a point of view not tied to any of the characters, and both chorus and narrator allow the author to comment on the characters' actions and to introduce information about the context in which these actions take place. However, since the information introduced by the chorus in a play is sometimes not consistent with the rest of the information in the play, the chorus in a play is not equivalent to the narrator in a novel.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?

options.optionContent: The narrator in a novel is never deceptive.
The voice of a narrator is sometimes necessary in plays that employ a chorus.
Information necessary for the audience to understand events in a play is sometimes introduced by the chorus.
Information introduced by a narrator in a novel can never be inconsistent with the rest of the information in the novel.
Authors sometimes use choruses in plays to mislead audiences about events in the plays.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is a tempting answer choice. It would be correct if a narrator avoiding deception implied that the narrator never introduced information that conflicts with the rest of the novel. Is that true? Not quite. A narrator can always be straightforward and still introduce information that conflicts with the rest of the novel. Perhaps the author wants to convey that the narrator is unreliable, so the author has the narrator introduce a bunch of information that conflicts with the novel's plot, setting, or characters. For this reason, this answer choice does not strengthen the argument. Moreover, the negation test will confirm that this answer choice is not necessary to the argument. Suppose it was the case that the narrator is sometimes deceptive. Would this weaken the argument? Would this show that the narrator acts like a chorus, and introduces information that conflicts with the novel? Not necessarily. A narrator could be deceptive without introducing information that conflicts with the novel. The narrator could deceive the reader by, for instance, withholding information about the novel's plot, setting, or characters. Therefore, this answer choice is not necessary to the argument and is incorrect.

This answer choice may entice some, as it uses the weak, wiggly language (“sometimes”) that is often found in correct answers to Strengthen with Necessary Premise questions. However, it doesn't strengthen the argument, and it isn't necessary to the argument. We don't need to know that narrators are sometimes necessary in plays to establish that narrators and choruses are not the same. The argument consistently specifies that narrators are used in novels and choruses are used in plays, so there is no use in asserting that narrators are necessary for plays.

This answer choice may appeal to some, as it uses the weak, wiggly language (“sometimes”) that is often found in correct answers to Strengthen with Necessary Premise questions. Even so, it doesn't strengthen the argument, and it isn't necessary to the argument. We know that both narrators and choruses introduce information about the context in which characters' actions take place. This is a trait narrators and choruses share. This answer choice just presents a stronger version of that trait—that sometimes this information is “necessary” to understand a play. But this conclusion wants to establish that choruses and narrators are different. Rather than focus on a difference between narrators and choruses, this just gives more information about a trait narrators and choruses share.

This answer strengthens the argument by providing a difference between narrators in a novel and choruses in a play. We know choruses sometimes introduce information inconsistent with the play. This answer choice shows that narrators never do that in a novel. Moreover, the negation test will confirm that this answer choice is necessary to the argument. Suppose that narrators sometimes introduced information that was inconsistent with the rest of the novel. In that case, is the conclusion now untrue? Yep. We would have no reason to believe that narrators and choruses were different, as the argument would have listed out a bunch of similarities between the two. Therefore, this answer choice is necessary to the argument and is correct.

Like (B) and (C), this answer choice may allure some test-takers, since it uses the weak language (“sometimes”) often found in correct answers on Strengthen with Necessary Premise questions. However, this doesn't strengthen the argument. Perhaps it would if we knew that authors never used narrators to mislead audiences about the events of a novel. But we do not know that, so this doesn't not present a difference between choruses and narrators.

items.stimulusText: Some of the rare pygmy bears should be moved from their native island to the neighboring island. The bears risk extinction from the loss of habitat on their native island, and since the neighboring island is the only place that has a similar habitat, this move represents the only viable chance of saving these valuable animals.
items.stemText: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning above?

options.optionContent: Some species are more deserving of protection than are other species.
Rare animals should not be moved from one habitat to another unless these habitats are similar to one another.
If a species is in danger of extinction, whatever is most likely to prevent the extinction should be undertaken.
The rarer a species of plant or animal is, the more that should be done to protect that species.
If an animal's original habitat is in danger of being lost, it is permissible to try to find a new habitat for the animal.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This principle would not help justify this argument's conclusion because the argument did not conclude that the pygmy bears were more deserving of being protected than any other species. Instead, the conclusion asserted that the bears definitely should be saved. Just because an animal is more deserving of protection doesn't mean the animal should be protected. Moreover, this answer choice doesn't refer to any of the premises offered in the argument. Any one of these issues would be enough to eliminate (A).

If Rare Animals Should Be Moved, then Similar Habitats. This is the reversal of what we're looking for. “if Similar Habitats, then Rare Animals Should Be Moved” would justify the reasoning in this argument, as a premise asserts that the neighboring island is the only place with a similar habitat to the bears' native island. But as written, (B) can't justify this argument's conclusion—it could only justify concluding that the habitats are similar or that rare animals shouldn't be moved.

If Species in Danger of Extinction, then Should Do Whatever Is Most Likely to Prevent Extinction. This is not exactly what we predicted, but it's close enough. We know the pygmy bears are facing extinction, so this principle applies to the argument's premises. We also know that moving the bears to the nearby island is the “only viable chance” of saving the bears. If moving the bears is the only viable way to prevent the bears' extinction, it is definitely the measure most likely to prevent their extinction. So, this applies to the argument's conclusion as well. This principle would therefore strengthen the reasoning in the argument, and (C) is the correct answer.

An efficient test-taker would quickly eliminate this answer choice once they noticed it didn't mention whether one “should” move an endangered species. Upon closer inspection, this principle wouldn't strengthen the reasoning in this argument because we don't know how rare these pygmy bears are. Are they only somewhat rare? If so, this may not support the idea that we should move the bears to a new island.

An efficient test-taker would quickly eliminate this answer choice once they noticed the weak language used in this answer choice. We need a principle with the strength to support the claim that we should move the bears to a new island. Saying it's “permissible” to try to find a new habitat would only support a conclusion that “we can start looking for a new habitat for the pygmy bears.”

items.stimulusText: The widespread use of encryption software, which makes electronic documents accessible by password only, will bring the writing of biographical history virtually to an end. Public figures' private correspondence and diaries are intended to be confidential when written, but they later become biographers' principal sources. In the future, most such documents are likely to be stored as encrypted text, so the most interesting, revealing material will be unavailable to historians unless they have the necessary passwords.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion drawn in the argument?

options.optionContent: In the future, most private correspondence and diaries of public figures will be stored as encrypted text.
The widespread use of encryption software will cause the writing of biographical history to decline significantly or cease.
Historians will probably not have access to much of the private correspondence and diaries of public figures in the future.
In the future, biographers' access to the most interesting, revealing material will be determined by their knowledge of the necessary passwords.
Public figures' private correspondence and diaries are the most interesting and revealing sources for the writing of biographical history.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This claim is a premise. It supports the subsidiary conclusion (the most interesting, revealing material won't be available to historians without a password), which, in turn, supports the main conclusion.

This accurately conveys the same idea as the argument's main conclusion, so this is the correct answer. The claims that encryption software will “bring the writing of biographical history virtually to an end” and that the software “will cause the writing of biographical history to decline significantly or cease” are identical. On a very predictable question like this, a time-conscious test-taker would be justified in selecting this and moving on to the next question, or giving the remaining answer choices just a cursory glance.

This expresses a similar idea to the argument's subsidiary conclusion. The subsidiary conclusion states that the most interesting, revealing material won't be available to historians unless the historian has a password. That implies that historians will not have as much access to material from public figures in the future. However, this idea supports the main conclusion that encryption software will bring an end to biographical writing.
This is similar to the argument's subsidiary conclusion. That subsidiary conclusion supports the main conclusion that encryption software will bring an end to biographical writing.

This is implied by the argument's premise and subsidiary conclusion. The premise tells us that public figures' private correspondence and diaries will be stored as encrypted text. The subsidiary conclusion tells us that means the most interesting, revealing material won't be available to biographers. So, these ideas, taken together, imply this answer choice. But this is used to support the argument's main conclusion that encryption software will bring an end to biographical writing.

items.stimulusText: Unlike stars, planets do not generate light, but only reflect it. Besides stars, there are many other celestial objects in this galaxy that are not planets. Hence, there are celestial objects in this galaxy that generate light but are not stars.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument fails to consider the possibility that

options.optionContent: this galaxy contains no celestial objects that reflect light other than planets
celestial objects in this galaxy comprise only a minute percentage of all the celestial objects in the universe
celestial objects in this galaxy are not the only celestial objects that generate light
there are numerous features that distinguish stars from planets besides the ability to generate light
planets are not the only celestial objects that do not generate light

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We're looking for an answer choice that will weaken the argument's conclusion. So, does this weaken the conclusion? Nope. If planets are the only celestial objects that reflect light, that strongly supports the claim that some non-star objects in this galaxy generate light. This strengthens rather than weakens the conclusion, so it is incorrect. (Note: if the question stem asked us to identify what the author “takes for granted” or “presumes without justification,” this would be the correct answer. This answer choice expresses an unstated, unsubstantiated belief the author has—not something the author “fails to consider.” Let this serve as a reminder that reading the question stem carefully, and using the question stem to figure out what you're looking for in the answer choices, is a crucial part of answering questions!)

We're looking for an answer choice that will weaken the argument's conclusion. So, does this weaken the conclusion? Not at all. This information is entirely irrelevant to the conclusion. The conclusion is only about the celestial objects in this galaxy, so whether there are a lot of celestial objects outside of this galaxy is immaterial.

We're looking for an answer choice that will weaken the argument's conclusion. So, does this weaken the conclusion? Again, no. This answer choice asserts that celestial objects outside this galaxy generate light. But, as discussed in (B), the argument's conclusion only applies to celestial objects in this galaxy. Facts about celestial objects outside this galaxy won't tell us anything about the objects inside this galaxy, so this information is irrelevant.

We're looking for an answer choice that will weaken the argument's conclusion. So, does this weaken the conclusion? Once again, no. The conclusion discussed whether celestial objects in this galaxy generate or merely reflect light. Whether there are other features to distinguish planets and stars is irrelevant. Those features cannot tell us whether non-star objects in this galaxy generate light.

We're looking for an answer choice that will weaken the argument's conclusion. So, does this weaken the conclusion? Finally, yes. If planets are not the only celestial objects that do not generate light, maybe every non-star object in this galaxy doesn't generate light. This substantially weakens the conclusion that non-star objects in this galaxy generate light, and it does so by pointing out the exclusivity flaw the author commits.

items.stimulusText: Psychologist: We measured the "cognitive plasticity," or the willingness to accept new ideas, of a group of people of both genders and of all ages. The first-born children in the study consistently exhibited less cognitive plasticity than did their siblings. It is reasonable to think that those who are open to new ideas will be adventurous in other ways. Hence, our study suggests that siblings of first-born children will tend to be more adventurous than will the first-borns.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the psychologist's argument?

options.optionContent: Some of the great creative geniuses in history were first-born children.
In most cases, the more younger siblings one has, the greater one's cognitive plasticity.
Other studies have shown a correlation between cognitive plasticity and the willingness to take risks.
A study of business executives shows that several industry leaders have older siblings.
Most of the participants in the study had characterized themselves as more adaptable than other people.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This conclusion asserts that first-born children will be less adventurous than their younger siblings. The argument doesn't assert that first-born children will be more creative than their siblings (and we have no reason to believe that being creative is associated with being unadventurous). Plus, this answer choice is very weak (“some”) and unlikely to strengthen a general conclusion like this one.

First-born children, by definition, have the most younger siblings in their family. If those first-born children also have more cognitive plasticity than their siblings, that directly contradicts the findings in this psychologist's study. Rather than strengthen the argument, this weakens it by casting doubt on the psychologist's study.

This answer choice fixes the problem: the jump from low cognitive plasticity to a lack of adventurousness. This answer choice shows that cognitive plasticity is associated with a willingness to take risks. So, if you have low cognitive plasticity, you'll be less likely to take risks. Being adventurous certainly involves taking risks. So, if you have low cognitive plasticity, you probably won't be very adventurous. This strengthens the psychologist's conclusion and is thus the correct answer.

This conclusion asserts that first-born children will be less adventurous than their younger siblings. It doesn't argue that first-born children will be less successful or less likely to lead industries than their siblings (and we have no reason to believe that being successful is associated with being adventurous). Plus, this answer choice is very weak (“several”) and unlikely to strengthen a general conclusion like this one.

This answer choice raises the possibility that the study did not measure a representative sample of the population. If the people in the study all thought they were more adaptable, there's a chance the study did not include participants with the lowest cognitive plasticity. Without including those participants, it's difficult to draw any conclusions about people with less cognitive plasticity. So, this answer choice weakens the argument by suggesting that the study is flawed. (Now, just because the participants said they were more adaptable doesn't mean they are more adaptable. Still, the possibility that this study's sample was unrepresentative is enough to weaken, at least slightly, this argument. At any rate, raising a potential problem with a premise will certainly not strengthen an argument.)

items.stimulusText: Historians have found that significant intellectual advances generally occur in cities or countries that have a stable political system. But these same historians acknowledge that in ancient Athens, Plato and Aristotle made unparalleled intellectual progress during a period of great political and social unrest.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to reconcile the historians' apparent counterexample with their general rule?

options.optionContent: The political systems that have emerged since the time of Plato and Aristotle have in various ways been different from the political system in ancient Athens.
The citizens of ancient Athens generally held in high esteem people who were accomplished intellectually.
Financial support for intellectual endeavors is typically unavailable in unstable political environments, but in ancient Athens such support was provided by wealthy citizens.
Significant intellectual advances sometimes, though not always, lead to stable political environments.
Many thinkers besides Plato and Aristotle contributed to the intellectual achievements of ancient Athens.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This describes a difference between ancient Athens and other political systems in which intellectual advancements occurred. However, it doesn't describe a difference that would explain why Plato and Aristotle could make intellectual achievements despite the political unrest. Just stating that the systems are different isn't enough to resolve this paradox.

This is tempting, but there are a few unacceptable issues. First, we don't know that Plato and Aristotle were “accomplished intellectually” in ancient Athens. Yes, historians acknowledge that Plato and Aristotle made significant intellectual accomplishments, but we have no idea if the ancient Athenian citizens also recognized those accomplishments. And, even if the citizens did recognize Plato and Aristotle's accomplishments, that doesn't explain how they were able to make those accomplishments during a time of political unrest in the first place.

As expected, this presents a difference between most politically unstable systems and ancient Athens. In most unstable political systems, intellectuals can't find funding. However, wealthy citizens funded Aristotle and Plato in ancient Athens. So Aristotle and Plato didn't rely on certain governments or regimes for their funding—their funding came from wealthy citizens, regardless of the political or social unrest. This resolves the paradox by affirming the general rule that significant intellectual advances occur in politically stable systems while explaining how Plato and Aristotle made intellectual advancements in the politically unstable ancient Athens.

A time-conscious test-taker would likely table or eliminate this answer choice based on its weak language. “[S]ometimes, though not always” is a very wishy-washy claim. We typically need stronger, more informative assertions to resolve a paradox. Moreover, this answer choice just says that some intellectual advancements occur in cities or countries that initially lacked a stable political system. That doesn't explain why Plato and Aristotle made such advancements during great political unrest or why political stability is generally favorable for intellectual advances.

This misses the mark entirely. We need to explain why Plato and Aristotle made intellectual advances in ancient Athens, despite it's instability. Asserting that other thinkers were able to make advancements as well offers little insight into how Plato and Aristotle were able to do so.

items.stimulusText: To establish a human colony on Mars would involve assembling tremendous quantities of basic materials at the site of the colony. But because the costs of transporting such materials through space would be so high, it will not be economically feasible to colonize Mars.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?

options.optionContent: Only if the cost of transporting materials from Earth to Mars decreases will human habitation be established on Mars.
The cost of transporting basic materials through space is not expected to decrease in the near future.
Earth is the only source of the basic materials that would be needed to establish human habitation on Mars.
No significant benefit would result from establishing human habitation on Mars.
Mars is not a practical source of the basic materials required for establishing human habitation there.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice reads: “if Human Habitation on Mars, then Cost of Transporting Materials Decreases.” After taking the contrapositive, it would read: “if Cost of Transporting Materials DOESN'T Decrease, then No Human Habitation on Mars.” This conclusion asserts that it's not economically feasible to colonize Mars, so the necessary condition that there will be no human habitation on Mars applies to this conclusion. Therefore, this would strengthen the argument if a premise asserted that the cost of transporting materials from Earth to Mars won't decrease. But no premises says that. The premise only asserts that the cost of transporting materials is “so high”—not that it won't decrease. Because this answer choice doesn't apply to any of the premises in this argument, it doesn't strengthen it.

When assessing answer choices on a Strengthen with Necessary Premise question, some test-takers find it helpful to ask, “Do we need to know this?” So, do we need to know that the cost of transporting materials through space won't decrease? Not necessarily. Even if the costs of transporting materials through space decreased significantly, it could still be too high to make colonizing Mars economically feasible. (For instance, the transportation cost could drop from $100 billion per pound of material to $50 billion per pound of material, and it would still likely be cost-prohibitive.) So while this may strengthen the argument, it doesn't need to be true to draw the conclusion.

Do we need to know that Earth is the only source of the materials required to colonize Mars? Not necessarily. Even if other planets or moons could provide the materials, it might still be too costly to transport them through space. We could maybe travel from Earth to our moon or to Saturn to get the materials. But doing so would still require transporting the materials through space, which could still make it economically unfeasible to transport these materials to Mars. So while this answer choice strengthens the argument, it doesn't need to be true to draw the conclusion.

This answer choice is irrelevant to the conclusion. The conclusion didn't claim that it's pointless or not worthwhile to colonize Mars. It only argues that it won't be economically feasible to do so. Therefore, asserting that there's no benefit to colonizing Mars does little strengthen the claim that it's not economically viable to do so.

This certainly strengthens this argument, as it shows that assembling the requisite materials on Mars will require transporting the materials through space. Moreover, the negation test will confirm that this answer choice is necessary to the argument. Suppose Mars is a practical source of the basic materials required for establishing human habitations there. In that case, is the conclusion now untrue? Yep. If we can get the materials from Mars, we won't have to transport them there, and it may not be cost-prohibitive to establish colonies there. Therefore, this answer choice is necessary to the argument and is correct.

items.stimulusText: Records reveal that of physical therapy patients who received less than six weeks of treatment, about 31 percent showed major improvement, regardless of whether they were treated by a general practitioner or by a specialist. Of patients who received physical therapy for a longer time, again regardless of whether they were treated by a general practitioner or by a specialist, about 50 percent showed major improvement. Therefore, the choice between seeing a specialist or a general practitioner for necessary physical therapy will not affect one's chances of major improvement.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument

options.optionContent: presumes, without providing justification, that effectiveness of different practitioners in bringing about major improvement cannot differ at all if their effectiveness in bringing about any improvement does not differ
provides no information about the kinds of injuries that require short-term as opposed to long-term treatment
overlooks the possibility that patients are more strongly biased to report favorably on one of the two types of medical professionals than on the other
fails to indicate whether the number of patients surveyed who saw a general practitioner was equal to the number who saw a specialist
overlooks the possibility that specialists and general practitioners each tend to excel at treating a different type of injury

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: When we see “presumes, without providing justification” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” This author only discusses patients making “major improvements.” The author never discusses the percentage of patients who experience “any improvement.” So, we have no reason to think the author agrees with this statement, and we can eliminate it.

This is true, but the author doesn't need to distinguish the types of injuries that require short-term versus long-term physical therapy. Although the premises discuss these time frames (assuming less than six weeks is “short-term” and more than three weeks is “long-term”), the conclusion is about any patient who requires physical therapy. So there may be some injuries that require long-term therapy, and some that require only short-term therapy. The author's point is whatever therapy you need, your chances of making major improvements does not depend on whether you see a general practitioner or a specialist. (Put another way, this answer choice brings up a difference between the types of therapy you may require when we should look for a difference between the types of patients the two practitioners treat.)

When we see “overlooks the possibility” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the conclusion if true?” So, would the possibility that patients may be biased to report favorably on one of the physical therapists weaken this conclusion? Not at all. The premises were not based on the patients' subjective assessments of the practitioner. The premises were based on whether the patients “showed major improvement.” That's an objective fact, which can be corroborated through medical records. This could weaken the argument if the premise and conclusion were about whether the patients liked or had favorable experiences with their physical therapist. However, this argument was about whether the patients actually healed. So this answer choice would not weaken the argument's conclusion, and it is incorrect.

The author doesn't need to establish that the number of patients who saw a general practitioner equaled the number of patients who saw a specialist. The premises were based on the percentage of patients who saw improvements, and the conclusion was about the likelihood that one would improve through physical therapy. Neither requires the group sizes to be exactly the same. Perhaps there would be a small-sample issue if the records were only based on a few patients who saw a general practitioner. But as long as both group sizes were large, studies based on unequal group sizes would be acceptable in this argument.
