When we see “overlooks the possibility” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the conclusion if true?” So, would the possibility that specialists and general practitioners excel at treating different injuries weaken this conclusion? Yes, absolutely. In that case, one's chances of improving through physical therapy would depend on whether they saw the practitioner who excelled at treating their type of injury. Whether you were able to anticipate this as a potential difference between the two physical therapists, or you knew you needed to look for some relevant difference between them, we can conclude that this is an error in the argument's reasoning.

items.stimulusText: The differences in distance from Earth between the stars in any one distant galaxy are negligible compared to the vast distance to the galaxy itself. Thus, if two stars are in the same distant galaxy, any significant difference in the apparent brightness of those stars results from differences in how brightly each is actually burning. Therefore, we should be able to determine how a star's relative actual brightness correlates with other characteristics by studying stars in the same distant galaxy.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption the argument requires?

options.optionContent: If two stars are in two different galaxies, it is not possible to determine whether or not they are approximately the same distance from Earth.
If any two stars are in the same distant galaxy, differences in the elements each is burning will be detectable from Earth.
The stars in our own galaxy are not all approximately the same distance from Earth.
There are stars in distant galaxies that have characteristics, other than brightness, discernible from Earth.
If there are significant differences in how far away two stars are from Earth, then those stars will differ significantly in apparent brightness.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This argument is about two stars in the same distant galaxy. We don't need to know anything about two stars in two different distant galaxies to draw this argument's conclusion.

This answer choice says that we can observe differences in at least one characteristic—the elements the star is burning—in “any two stars” in the same distant galaxy. This claim strengthens the argument's conclusion by showing that we can observe at least one characteristic other than brightness in two distant stars. If this answer choice were true, we'd at least be able to figure out how brightness correlates with which element the star is burning. But does this answer choice need to be true to draw the argument's conclusion? Let's turn to the negation test to check. Suppose it wasn't true that differences in the elements burning in any two stars in the same distant galaxy were detectable from Earth. Or, put another way, suppose that there were some stars in the same distant galaxy in which we couldn't detect differences in the elements burning. Would that weaken this conclusion? Not necessarily. This conclusion didn't assert we'd be able to determine how brightness correlates to every trait in every star in distant galaxies. Even if we couldn't observe differences in the elements burning in some stars, we may be able to observe this difference in most stars. And those observations would allow us to develop a general impression of how brightness correlates to elements burning. Moreover, even if we couldn't observe differences in the elements burning in some stars, we still may be able to detect other differences in these stars, and figure out how those differences correlate to brightness. Since negating this answer choice doesn't weaken this conclusion, this answer choice is not necessary and incorrect.
This argument is about two stars in the same distant galaxy. We don't need to know anything about two stars in our galaxy to draw this argument's conclusion.

This answer choice strengthens this argument. If stars in distant galaxies have detectable characteristics, other than brightness, we can be much more confident that we can determine how brightness correlates to other characteristics. Additionally, the negation test will confirm that this answer choice is necessary to the argument. Suppose there weren't stars in distant galaxies that had characteristics, other than brightness, discernable from Earth. Or, put another way, suppose that brightness was the only trait we could observe in distant stars. In that case, is the conclusion now untrue? Yep. If we couldn't detect any trait other than a star's brightness from Earth, we couldn't determine how the star's brightness correlates with different traits. Therefore, this answer choice is necessary to the argument and is correct.

This argument is about stars in the same distant galaxy. The first premise establishes that these stars will be approximately the same distance from Earth. Therefore, we don't need to know anything about two stars that have a significantly different distances from Earth.

items.stimulusText: A research psychologist used a personality test to classify high school students as "repressors"—people who repress upsetting thoughts and feelings from conscious awareness—or as "sensitizers"—those especially attuned to internal states who freely express distress. The researcher found that, compared to sensitizers, the repressors were less shy and anxious, could better tolerate frustration, and had superior social skills, higher grades, and a greater sense of self-esteem.
items.stemText: Each of the following, if true, contributes to an explanation of the repressors' characteristics mentioned above except:

options.optionContent: Repressors are better able than sensitizers to focus on their work and to avoid distractions.
Repressors are less apt than sensitizers to alienate people by expressing their emotions.
Parents and other caregivers tend to reward repressors more than they reward sensitizers for academic performance and social behavior deemed desirable.
Some psychologists have hypothesized that the desire to maintain social and academic success and self-esteem strengthens repressors' tendency to repress upsetting thoughts and feelings.
Sensitizers tend to focus more than repressors do on the difficulties of succeeding in their projects rather than on factors that are likely to contribute to success.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Repressors' ability to focus on work and avoid distractions—perhaps because they're not constantly, histrionically overreacting to every negative thought—would help explain how they got better grades. This explains the surprising findings, so we should eliminate it.

If repressors don't alienate people by expressing their emotions, this would explain how they had “superior social skills.” So, even if this answer choice doesn't provide the most flattering portrait of people's ability to empathize with others' emotions, it does explain the surprising finding. We'll need to eliminate it.

Getting rewarded more for academic success and desirable social behavior would help explain why repressors have greater self-esteem (they feel good when they get lavishly rewarded), and why they get better grades and social skills (they have more incentive than the sensitizers). This helps explain the surprising finding, so we should eliminate it.

Just because psychologists have hypothesized that the desire to maintain social and academic success is correlated to the repressors' tendency to repress upsetting thoughts and feelings doesn't mean those psychologists are correct. There may be no evidence that corroborates this hypothesis. Further, this answer choice gets the cause and effect backwards. We're looking for reasons why repressors' tendency to repress causes their better social skills and grades. This answer choice describes a possible reason why repressors' desire for better social skills and grades causes their tendency to repress. Therefore, this answer choice does not contribute to an explanation of the surprising findings, and it is correct.

If we know that sensitizers focus more on the negative and consequently can't focus on ways to succeed, we can better understand why sensitizers have worse grades than repressors, have a harder time tolerating frustration, and are more anxious. This contributes to an explanation of the surprising findings, so it is incorrect.

items.stimulusText: A geologist recently claimed to have discovered in clay a previously unknown form of life: "nanobes," one-tenth the size of the smallest known bacteria. However, it is unlikely that nanobes truly are living things. They are probably inanimate artifacts of the clay's microscopic structure, because a nanobe is too small to contain a reproductive mechanism, a prerequisite for life.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?

options.optionContent: No known form of bacteria is complicated enough in structure to engage in a sexual type of reproduction.
Single-celled creatures can combine to form a multicelled structure and then reproduce before they disband into separate single cells again.
The material phenomena that some scientists claim are the fossilized remains of bacteria in meteorites from Mars are approximately the same size as nanobes.
Previous definitions of life were based on research done with inferior microscopes no longer in use.
Animals such as cold-blooded lizards can be physiologically simpler, though still larger, than other animals.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This has no effect on the argument. We know that nanobes are significantly smaller than bacteria, which means nanobes don't have a reproductive mechanism. This answer choice perhaps suggests that nanobes can't engage in sexual reproduction, but that doesn't give us any more information than what we already had.

If you noticed the equivocation between life and lifeform, this should be a very appealing answer choice. This suggests how members of a species can reproduce without each member possessing a reproductive mechanism. If single-celled creatures can combine, Voltron-style, into a multicelled creature, reproduce, and divide back again, perhaps nanobes also can do this. In that case, nanobes could be a lifeform, even if each member is too small to have a reproductive mechanism. Some test-takers may bristle at certain elements of this answer choice. They may point out that we don't know that nanobes are single-celled creatures or that a combination of nanobes would be complicated enough to reproduce. They may also point out that we don't even know that these single-celled creatures lack a reproductive mechanism. All of these objections are valid. But it's worth reviewing our goal on a Weaken question: to make the conclusion less convincing, even if that effect is slight. We don't need to prove that the conclusion is false. So (B) doesn't prove that this conclusion is false. However, it shows that very simple organisms can reproduce, which suggests that maybe the tiny, simplistic nanobes can as well. Therefore, this answer choice weakens the conclusion, and it is correct.

This answer choice states that some scientists claim they found the fossilized remains of bacteria on Martian meteorites, and these remains are approximately the same size as nanobes. It's easy to see the appeal in this answer choice. If bacteria are lifeforms, finding evidence of bacteria that are the same size as nanobes would suggest that nanobes might also be lifeforms. However, that's not quite what this answer choice says. First, this answer choice only says scientists “claim” they found the remains of bacteria. Just because they said it's bacteria doesn't necessarily mean it is bacteria. Second, the answer choice says the remains are the same size as nanobes. But the remains might refer to the remnants of part of a bacterium. Maybe the entire bacterium wasn't fossilized and its size is much larger than a nanobe. So, this answer choice doesn't provide enough information to weaken the argument.

“Previous definitions of life” have no bearing on this argument. Nothing in this argument suggests that only “previous definitions of life” hold that life requires reproductive mechanisms or that nanobes are too small to possess such mechanisms.

This answer choice suggests that an animal's simplicity doesn't necessarily correlate with its size. But, even if that's true, it doesn't necessarily weaken this argument. First, we don't think nanobes are animals, so it's unclear if this even applies to nanobes. Even if we ignore that issue, this answer choice doesn't address the fact that nanobes aren't large enough to have reproductive mechanisms, and that lifeforms require reproduction. So this answer choice may only suggests that nanobes might not be simplest entities, but it doesn't imply that they can reproduce.

items.stimulusText: Devan has never bothered to be kind to me. Nor has he offered help or companionship. So, since he does not meet any of these basic criteria for friendship, he is my enemy.
items.stemText: Which one of the following exhibits flawed reasoning most similar to the flawed reasoning exhibited in the argument above?

options.optionContent: Each officer of this club must be a member of two years standing, or be a committee member, or have special qualifications. Evelyn cannot be an officer, for she has only been a member for one year and is not a committee member.

In order to thrive, this plant needs to be located in a sunny spot and to be watered regularly. So, since this spot is not sunny, and since I did not water this plant regularly, that explains why this plant is not as healthy as it should be.
This book has been widely reviewed and hasn't received even one hostile review. Hence we can conclude that, so far, all the critics have loved this book.

A decision in favor of developing the northern border of the town logically implies that it would be equally acceptable to develop the southern, eastern, or western borders. So, it is possible that at least one of these other borders will also be developed.

If everyone were an author, poet, or academic, then society would come crashing to a halt. But most people are not poets or authors. Nor are there many academics in our society. Therefore, our society will not come crashing to a halt.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is an invalid argument, but not because it ignores a middle ground between two extremes. The premise asserts that officers must have “two years standing” or be a “committee member” or have “special qualifications.” We know Evelyn lacks two years of standing and isn't a committee member, but she could still be an officer if she has special qualifications.

This argument takes the contrapositive of a conditional statement, so it's valid. If plants need sun and water to thrive, and this plant received neither sun nor water, we have a good explanation for why it hasn't thrived.

Like the passage, this answer choice jumps from one extreme to the other. The critics didn't give this book any “hostile” reviews. But that doesn't mean they “loved” the book. They could think the book is pretty good, just OK, or slightly below-average. In other words, this argument ignores the middle ground between “hate” and “love,” just like the passage ignored the middle ground between “friend” and “enemy.” It is the correct answer.

This argument is flawed, but not because it ignores a middle ground between two extremes. Even if it's “acceptable” to develop the southern, eastern, or western borders doesn't mean that it's “possible” that at least one will be developed. This is an equivocation between two related but distinct concepts.

This argument is flawed, but not because it ignores a middle ground between two extremes. This commits a negates-but-doesn't-reverse flaw. We know that society would crash if everyone were an author, poet, or academic. But not everyone is an author, poet, or academic. But that doesn't mean society won't crash. Perhaps society will crash for some other reason. In other words, this argument tries to draw a conclusion by negating a sufficient condition. This is flawed, but not for the same reason as the passage.

items.stimulusText: Journalist: Drivers of sport utility vehicles correctly tend to believe that occupants of such vehicles carry lower risk of serious injury as a result of accidents, and such drivers therefore tend to drive less carefully than they would in more traditional vehicles. Thus, the discovery of powerful cures for certain high-incidence forms of cancer would probably trigger an increase in behaviors such as smoking and overexposure to sun that are known to increase the risks of such cancers.
items.stemText: The journalist's reasoning most closely conforms to which one of the following principles?

options.optionContent: When people believe that there are several measures they could take to reduce the risk associated with a certain activity, generally they will take only the measure that they believe will most reduce that risk.
The development of ways to protect people from the consequences of behaviors that would normally harm them often makes people less careful to avoid such behaviors.

People generally take special care to avoid behaviors that they believe would likely lead to serious injury to them and generally do not take special care to avoid behaviors that they believe will not harm them at all.
People generally exercise more care when performing activities they know to have risky consequences than when performing activities of unknown risk.
Avoiding serious harm to themselves is given a high priority by people in their behavior, but avoiding lesser harms is frequently outweighed by various desires.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The conclusion of this argument is about people engaging in risky behaviors (like smoking), not taking measures that reduce risk. So this principle would not strengthen the reasoning in this argument.

If developing ways to protect people from harmful behavior (like cancer cures) often leads people to be “less careful to avoid such behavior,” we can expect people to be less careful to avoid carcinogens. This strengthens the argument's reasoning by showing that the premise about SUV drivers can apply to other contexts.

This argument's conclusion asserts that people will engage in behaviors they know will harm them (like smoking and overexposure to the sun). This principle asserts that people will avoid such behaviors. So this principle weakens the argument's reasoning. (Some test-takers may argue that this principle might strengthen the conclusion, because it shows that people will engage in behaviors known to increase the risk of cancer because they think the cure will prevent cancer from harming them. However, even if the cure eventually protects these people from cancer, they still would be harmed by getting the cancer in the first place.)

This argument's conclusion asserts that people will exercise less care when engaging in activities they know to be risky. This principle suggests that people will be careful when engaging in those activities. Therefore, this principle weakens the argument, and this answer choice is incorrect.

This argument's conclusion asserts that people will engage in behaviors they know can lead to the serious harm of cancer. This principle asserts that people will make it a priority to avoid that harm. Once again, this principle weakens the argument, making this answer choice incorrect.

items.stimulusText: Filmmaker: Many people feel that independent films have more integrity as works of art than films produced by major studios, since independent films are typically less conventional than major studio films. However, like major studios, all independent filmmakers need to make profits on their films, and this affects the artistic decisions made in creating most independent films. Thus, most independent films do not have absolute integrity as works of art.
items.stemText: The filmmaker's conclusion is properly drawn if which one of the following is assumed?

options.optionContent: A creation has absolute integrity as a work of art if the artistic decisions made in creating it were unaffected by the need to make profits.
If any of the artistic decisions made in creating something were affected by the need to make profits, then that creation does not have absolute integrity as a work of art.
The creations of individuals have more integrity as works of art, on average, than those of groups.
The unconventionality of a creation has no bearing on its integrity as a work of art.
A creation has no integrity as a work of art unless the artistic decisions made in creating it were unaffected by views about what is conventional.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This could validate a conclusion that claimed that a work of art had absolute integrity. But it cannot validate a conclusion that a work of art lacks absolute integrity. Therefore, this answer choice is incorrect.

The filmmaker's conclusion would be valid if we added this to the argument. The filmmaker established that the artistic decisions made by independent filmmakers are affected by profits. Therefore, if this answer choice is true, we must conclude that films made by independent filmmakers do not have absolute integrity as works of art.

An efficient test-taker would eliminate this as soon as they saw it lacked the conclusion's new idea: that independent films “do not have absolute integrity as works of art.” We need to prove that independent films do not have absolute integrity. An answer choice that claims that creations of individuals tend to have more integrity than creations of groups cannot do that. For one, it's not clear whether independent films are the creations of individuals or groups. Second, a relative claim (“more integrity”) cannot prove an non-relative claim (“do not have integrity”).

An efficient test-taker would eliminate this as soon as they saw it lacked the conclusion's new idea: that independent films “do not have absolute integrity as works of art.” While this may strengthen the argument (it shows that the unconventionality of independent films won't affect their integrity), it doesn't prove that independent films completely lack integrity. Perhaps independent films possess some quality other than unconventionality that give them absolute integrity.

An efficient test-taker would eliminate this as soon as they saw it added an idea that the argument did not discuss: that decisions were not “unaffected by views about what is conventional.” Correct answers cannot add new ideas on Strengthen with Sufficient Premise questions. Although the argument asserts that independent films are unconventional, we have no idea if the artistic decisions are affected by what is conventional. Are the filmmakers deliberately trying to make their films unconventional? Unclear. So this cannot validate the conclusion because this does not connect to the argument's premise.

items.stimulusText: If you complete 24 graduate credits and a thesis in our department, you are eligible to receive a master's degree. Roger has completed 24 graduate credits in our department, yet he is not eligible to receive a master's degree. So he must not have finished his thesis yet.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the argument above is most similar to the reasoning in which one of the following?

options.optionContent: If the mayor and the city council had approved the proposed budget, the botanical gardens would be able to open this week. The botanical gardens cannot open this week even though the city council approved the proposed budget. Thus, the mayor must not have approved the proposed budget.
If I see a science fiction movie, I either love it or hate it. I do not hate the movie I am watching now. Therefore, I will probably end up loving the movie, since it is a science fiction movie.

If the government or some other party had bought the processing plant, the local economy would have improved. But the local economy did not improve. Therefore, neither the government nor any other party bought the processing plant.

Books at Falling Embers Bookshop are on sale only if they are either used books or paperbacks. The book I am looking for at Falling Embers is on sale. Therefore, if the book I am looking for is not a paperback, it is a used book.

If Doria owes more money than she can pay back, then she must either get a higher paying job or declare bankruptcy. Doria does in fact owe more than she can pay back, yet she does not want to declare bankruptcy. So, Doria must get a higher paying job.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This has all the key characteristics we're looking for: if Mayor Approve and Council Approve, then Botanical Gardens. NO Botanical Gardens and Council Approve. Conclusion: NO Mayor Approve. This has the same structure as the passage. Like that argument, we satisfy one sufficient condition, but the necessary condition is not satisfied. In both cases, the conclusion asserts that the other sufficient condition must not be satisfied. This is the correct answer.

An efficient test-taker would eliminate this one as soon as they saw it lacked an “and” in the sufficient condition of a premise. Rather, this has an “or” in a necessary condition. An argument cannot have the same structure if it misplaces an important element like that. Its conclusion also features a different strength of language (“probably”) than the passage's conclusion. In addition to having a different structure than the passage, this is also an invalid argument. This author predicts that they probably will love the movie, because they don't currently hate it. However, even if this author only loves or hates these movies, their opinion may change before the movie is over.

An efficient test-taker would eliminate this one as soon as they saw it lacked an “and” in the sufficient condition of a premise. Rather, this has an “or” in the sufficient condition. Moreover, the absolute premise lacks an “and” and the conclusion has an “and.” An argument cannot have the same structure if it misplaces crucial elements like these. While this is a valid argument, its structure is not the same as the argument in the passage.

An efficient test-taker would eliminate this one as soon as they saw it lacked an “and” in the sufficient condition of a premise. Like (B), this has an “or” in a necessary condition. Additionally, the conclusion is a conditional, rather than an absolute, statement. An argument cannot have the same structure if it misplaces important elements like these. While this is a valid argument, its structure is not the same as the argument in the passage.

An efficient test-taker would eliminate this one as soon as they saw it lacked an “and” in the sufficient condition of a premise. Like (B) and (D) before it, this has an “or” in a necessary condition. An argument cannot have the same structure if it misplaces important elements like this. While this is a valid argument, its structure is not the same as the argument in the passage.

sections.directions: Directions: Each question in this section is based on the reasoning presented in a brief passage. In answering the questions, you should not make assumptions that are by commonsense standards implausible, superfluous, or incompatible with the passage. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText: In the previous two years, significantly more rain has fallen in Browning in September than in July. Therefore, this year in Browning more rain will probably fall in September than in July.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument

options.optionContent: contains a premise that presupposes the truth of the conclusion
draws an inference about a future event on the basis of a very limited number of instances of related past events
overemphasizes the possibility that average rainfall statistics could be skewed by large rainfall in one year
concludes that two phenomena are associated merely from the claim that there are many instances in which both phenomena are present
uses evidence drawn from a source whose reliability cannot readily be verified

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: “Presuppos[ing] the truth” of a conclusion refers to circular reasoning, a flaw in which the conclusion merely restates a premise. That is not the case here, as the premise is about the last two years, and the conclusion is about this year.

This describes the flaw perfectly. The author is drawing an inference about a future event (the amount of rainfall over Browning this year) from premises about a “very limited number of instances of related past events” (two past events: the amount of rainfall over Browning in the last two years). This answer choice accurately describes the temporal flaw discussed above by describing the shift from one time period to another. And, if you thought of this as a sampling flaw, the characterization of the premises as “very limited” also references that.

Like many incorrect answer choices to Errors in Reasoning questions, this answer choice misconstrues the conclusion drawn in this argument. The author's conclusion was not about “average rainfall statistics” in Browning or anywhere else. That was not a point the author was trying to make, so there’s no way the author could have “overemphasize[d]” how much abnormal rainfall could skew the average.

When an answer choice uses abstract, nonspecific language like this, try to fill in the vague terms with concrete details from the passage. If you’re unable, or find yourself straining, to find something from the passage that aligns with a vague term, then there’s a good chance that the answer choice misdescribes the argument and is wrong. In this case, what are the “two phenomena” that conclusion claims are “associated”? The conclusion arguably describes Browning rainfall in June and Browning rainfall in September. Still, the author doesn’t claim these phenomena are “associated” — just that there's probably going to be more rainfall in June than September. Moreover, the premises never assert that there are many instances when both these phenomena are present (we’d probably have to bend the space-time continuum to get rain in June and September at the same time). Since we can’t fill in the vague terms from this answer choice with concrete details from the passage, this answer choice misdescribes the argument.
There’s no reason to believe that we can’t verify the evidence used in this argument. As long as someone or something is keeping track of the rainfall in Browning, we can double-check these figures.

items.stimulusText: Educator: Few problems faced in daily life can be solved most effectively, if at all, by applying knowledge from any single academic discipline in isolation. Thus, schools should not require students to take courses in individual academic disciplines but should instead require them to take interdisciplinary courses.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the educator's argument?

options.optionContent: Problems faced in daily life usually can be solved effectively using only common sense.
Most teachers are able to teach courses in a single academic discipline more effectively than they can teach interdisciplinary courses.
Students who take only courses in individual academic disciplines are rarely able to combine knowledge from those disciplines.
Most students who are required to take courses that cover only single disciplines can effectively solve many problems faced in daily life.
Most interdisciplinary courses are not designed specifically to teach students how to solve problems faced in daily life.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: It's unclear whether interdisciplinary or single-subject courses would be better at helping students acquire the common sense to solve problems. Perhaps neither would. This answer choice doesn't address the educator's central comparison between interdisciplinary and single-subject courses, and therefore doesn't strengthen the argument.

This answer choice describes a downside to interdisciplinary courses that this author overlooks: they're more challenging to teach than single-subject courses. We're looking for an answer choice that strengthens the argument by fixing a problem; this answer choice weakens the argument by stating a problem.

This answer choice eliminates a potential benefit of single-subject courses: that students could be better at learning to solve problems by combining knowledge from several single-subject courses. This answer choice shows this is not the case — students usually cannot combine knowledge from several single-subject courses. In that case, interdisciplinary courses are probably a better way to provide students with the knowledge required to solve life's problems. In other words, this answer choice strengthens the argument by patching up a potential weakness in the educator's reasoning.

So students who are required to take single-subject courses usually get good at solving life's problems anyway? That weakens the argument by showing that the educator's prescribed ban on single-subject course requirements isn't necessary to help students solve life's problems.

This presents an arguable drawback of interdisciplinary courses (arguable because a class that's not designed to teach students how to solve life's problems could still equip students with the knowledge required to solve those problems). So, if this answer choice has any effect on the educator's argument at all, it only weakens it.

items.stimulusText: Newspaper columnist: What caused the current recession is a hotly debated question. It is a mistake, however, to assume that answering this question is essential to improving the economy. Corrective lenses, after all, were an effective treatment for myopia long before the cause was known to be genetic.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the conclusion drawn in the newspaper columnist's argument?

options.optionContent: Solving a problem never requires finding the root cause of the problem.
Knowing the cause of the current recession would not necessarily enable people to find a solution to it.
The question of what caused the current recession is subject to considerable debate.
One need not ascertain the cause of the current recession in order to improve the economy.
Long before the cause of myopia was known to be genetic, corrective lenses were being used as an effective treatment for the disease.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is a much broader statement than the second sentence of this argument. The columnist believes there are at least two specific situations in which solving a problem doesn't require finding the root cause, but that doesn't mean that the columnist believes solving a problem never requires finding the root cause. The columnist does not necessarily think this statement is true, so it cannot be the columnist's main point.

This misconstrues the columnist's main point ever so slightly. The columnist states that we don't need to know the cause of the recession to solve it. That doesn't mean that the columnist thinks knowing the cause of the recession wouldn't allow us to solve it.To use a favorite device of this columnist and argue by analogy: if you feel sick, you don't need to know what caused your illness to feel better. Usually, rest and fluids will help you out. But knowing what caused your illness could still help you feel better more quickly — you could take certain medications that could expedite the healing process. Perhaps the same is true of the recession.The columnist concludes we don't need to know the cause, not that it wouldn't help. So, the columnist does not necessarily believe that this answer choice is true, and it cannot be the columnist's main point.

Unlike (A) and (B), the columnist believes this statement is true. But it is not the columnist's main point. The tone doesn't suggest that this sentence is the takeaway point the columnist wants to leave us with. Additionally, none of the columnist's statements help explain why or how there's a hot debate over what caused the recession. Because no premises support this assertion, it is not the columnist's main point.

This is it. This answer choice expresses the same idea as the second sentence, which we've identified as the columnist's main point. It's the takeaway point the columnist wants to leave us with, and it's supported by the central premise in this argument (the analogy to corrective lenses).

This refers to the columnist's only premise in this argument. We can surmise that this is a premise both from the phrase “after all” (a standard premise indicator) and the fact that it supports why the columnist thinks we don't have to figure out what caused the recession before attempting to fix the recession. Because this answer choice refers to a premise and not the main conclusion, it is incorrect.

items.stimulusText: Generally, it is important that people practice what they preach, yet there are exceptions. For instance, it is no more necessary for logicians to be logical in their discussions of logic than it is for physicians to have healthy lifestyles in order to treat people.
items.stemText: A questionable aspect of the reasoning above is that it fails to take into account that

options.optionContent: logicians' being illogical in their discussions of logic constitutes incompetence, whereas physicians' having an unhealthy lifestyle does not
if a physician's health deteriorates badly, the physician may not be able to treat patients effectively
physicians who are incompetent to practice medicine can cause more harm than can logicians who discuss logic illogically
it is more difficult to become logical in one's discussions of logic than it is to modify an unhealthy lifestyle
although it is not necessary for logicians to be logical in order to be competent to discuss logic, it is highly desirable

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice points out a relevant difference between logicians and physicians. A physician having an unhealthy lifestyle wouldn't affect that physician's competency to treat patients. But a logician failing to be logical would make that logician incompetent to discuss logic. That would mean that the logician, unlike the physician, is an example of a person who does need to practice what they preach. The author fails to consider that important difference between physicians and logicians, which makes the author's reasoning very questionable.

This answer choice doesn't really show why a physician might not need to maintain a healthy lifestyle. Maintaining a healthy lifestyle and staying in good health aren't quite the same thing. A physician failing to maintain a healthy lifestyle does not necessarily mean that the physician's health will “deteriorate badly.” (Likewise, physicians’ health can deteriorate even if they maintain healthy lifestyles.) Because this author is discussing physicians maintaining “healthy lifestyles” and not physicians “being healthy,” this answer choice doesn't quite point out why physicians might need to practice what they preach.

This answer choice wants us to believe that this is a relevant difference between physicians and logicians. But, by discussing a physician's incompetence, the answer choice brings up an issue that's irrelevant to the reasoning. This author's point wasn't about physicians being incompetent to practice medicine. It was about physicians who do not maintain a healthy lifestyle. Those are entirely different concepts, so this answer choice does not point out a difference between physicians and logicians that's germane to the reasoning.

The author's point was that logicians don't need to be logical to do their job. Since the author doesn't think that trait is necessary, the author isn't concerned with how easy it is to acquire that trait. To identify a flaw in this reasoning, we should look for an answer choice that shows why logicians need to be logical, not an answer choice that discusses how difficult it may be to become logical.

To identify a flaw in this reasoning, we can look for an answer choice that shows why logicians need to be logical. The problem with this answer choice is that it concedes that the author's whole point is valid. It says that logicians don't have to be logical to do their job.

items.stimulusText: Domesticated animals, such as dogs, have come into existence by the breeding of only the individuals of a wild species that are sufficiently tame. For example, if when breeding wolves one breeds only those that display tameness when young, then after a number of generations the offspring will be a species of dog. Therefore, all animals can, in principle, be bred for domesticity.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.optionContent: Domesticated animals cannot be turned into wild species by breeding only those animals that display some wild characteristics.
In some animal species, wild members mate more frequently than tame members.
In some animal species, no members ever display tameness.
In some animal species, tame members are less fertile than wild members.
In some domesticated animal species, some members are much more tame than other members.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: As fascinating as it is to contemplate reverse-engineering a wolf by breeding dogs, this argument was not about turning domesticated animals back into wild animals. We're looking for a reason why we can't make every wild species into a domesticated one, not why we can't make every domesticated species into a wild one.

Note the conclusion's scope: any animal could, “in principle,” be domesticated. By qualifying the conclusion with the “in principle,” the author only claims that it's theoretically possible to domesticate any wild animal. This answer choice points to reasons why domesticating some species would be difficult or time-consuming — the tame members we have to use are more reluctant to mate. However, even if it would take a long time and involve a great deal of cajoling, we could still theoretically breed these species. So this answer choice doesn't undermine the claim that it's theoretically possible to domesticate any species.

This answer choice points out why we wouldn't be as successful domesticating non-lupine species: unlike wolves, some species don't have tame members. As this author's reasoning went, by focusing on just the tame wolves, we created dogs. The author then concludes that by using only the tame members, we could domesticate any wild species. This answer choice points out that some species don't have tame members. Without the ability to select the animals that display tameness, we couldn't necessarily domesticate those species. Therefore, this weakens the author's reasoning and is correct.

Note the conclusion's scope: any animal could, “in principle,” be domesticated. By qualifying the conclusion with the “in principle,” the author only claims that it's theoretically possible to domesticate any wild animal. Like (B), this answer choice shows why domesticating some species could be difficult or time-consuming — the tame members are less fertile. However, even if it would take a long time and a great many attempts, we could still theoretically breed these species. So this answer choice doesn't undermine the claim that it's theoretically possible to domesticate any species.

This answer choice gives us a fact about the tameness of domesticated species. However, this author concluded we could domesticate any species by using only the tame members of that wild species. The tameness of domesticated animals doesn't matter to the author's argument, so this answer choice doesn't weaken the argument.

items.stimulusText: Surprisingly, a new study has revealed that shortly after a heavy rainfall, pollution levels in Crystal Bay reach their highest levels. This occurs despite the fact that rainwater is almost totally pure and one would therefore expect that it would dilute the polluted seawater.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain why pollution levels in Crystal Bay increase after a heavy rainfall?

options.optionContent: Compared to the total amount of polluted seawater, the amount of rainwater that falls into Crystal Bay is negligible.
Most of the rainwater that eventually reaches Crystal Bay falls on pesticide-treated fields before being carried into the bay.
Most rainwater carried by clouds consists of water that has evaporated from oceans around the world.
The single leading cause of pollution in Crystal Bay is beachgoers' leaving behind their trash and debris, which then blows into the bay.
Other nearby ocean areas experience a pattern of pollutant increase and decrease that is extremely similar to that of Crystal Bay.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Even if rainwater accounts for only a tiny percentage of the total water in Crystal Bay, we'd still expect Crystal Bay's pollution levels to go down when the pure rainwater fell directly to the bay. This answer could explain why Crystal Bay's pollution levels don't fall much after rain, but it doesn't explain why the pollution levels increase.

As predicted, this answer choice shows that rainwater can reach Crystal Bay through means other than direct rainfall. If most rainwater that winds up in Crystal Bay takes a circuitous path through pesticide-treated fields, that would explain why the pollution levels tend to go up following rain. Rather than falling into Crystal Bay as this passage discussed, the rainwater can become less pure and increase Crystal Bay's pollution levels if it instead picks up some pesticides from fields that carry it to the bay.

Even if rainwater is mostly evaporated ocean water, the passage tells us the rainwater is pure. So, if the rainwater falls directly into Crystal Bay, we'd still expect the rain to dilute Crystal Bay and reduce its pollution levels. Therefore, this answer does not explain why Crystal Bay's pollution levels are higher following rainfall.

Even if the primary source of Crystal Bay's pollution is beachgoers' behavior, we'd still expect Crystal Bay's pollution levels to go down if rain fell directly into the bay and diluted the extant pollution. In fact, since beachgoers typically do not go to the beach on rainy days, this answer choice makes Crystal Bay's high post-rain pollution levels all the more inexplicable.

This answer choice shows that there's a similar pattern of high post-rain pollution in other oceans. But identifying a pattern is not the same thing as explaining the causes of that pattern. So, this answer choice doesn't address the fundamental mystery the passage presents: why wouldn't the rainfall dilute and reduce the pollution levels in Crystal Bay?

items.stimulusText: Ethicist: This hospital's ethics code states that hospital staff must not deceive patients about their medical treatment. But we know that Dr. Faris administered medication A to a patient and informed him that it would help him sleep. Medication A has no known sleep-inducing properties. So, Dr. Faris is clearly in violation of the ethics code, despite the fact that the patient's sleep did improve after taking medication A.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the ethicist's argument?

options.optionContent: Dr. Faris was aware that medication A had no known sleep-inducing properties.
A committee at the hospital is currently considering revisions to the hospital's ethics code.
Medication A is a pain reliever that can indirectly lead to sleep due to a reduction in the patient's discomfort.
Several other members of the hospital staff prescribed medication A to patients who had trouble sleeping.
Dr. Faris knew that the patient was not taking any other medications that have sleep-inducing properties.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This would strengthen the case against Dr. Faris. In both legal and everyday usage, deception requires the deceiving party to knowingly misrepresent that truth. This answer choice shows that Dr. Faris was fully aware that Medication A isn't known to help patients sleep, which would strengthen the case against Dr. Faris.

The committee changing the hospital's ethics code is immaterial to this argument. This ethicist argues that Dr. Faris violated the current code, as presently constructed. Even if the revisions are made, and even if those revisions change the policy against deception — neither of which is inevitable — that wouldn't make Dr. Faris any less guilty of violating the current code.

This answer choice weakens the case against Dr. Faris by showing that the doctor may have reasonably expected Medication A to help the patient sleep. This argument features an equivocation between the premises and the conclusion. As described by the premises, Dr. Faris's actions might constitute deception, especially if the premises don't explicitly define what would constitute deception. Perhaps to deceive a patient, Dr. Faris would need to knowingly misrepresent the truth. If Dr. Faris had a reasonable expectation that Medication A could indirectly lead to sleep, perhaps Dr. Faris didn't deliberately lie to a patient, which would weaken the case against the doctor.
Sure, and these doctors may also be guilty of violating the hospital's code against lying to patients. A practice being widespread doesn't necessarily exculpate people who engage in the practice.

This is irrelevant to the ethicist's argument. The issue is whether Dr. Faris's claim that Medication A would help a patient sleep constitutes deceiving a patient. The other medications the patient may have been taking at the time and whether Dr. Faris knew about those medications have no bearing on whether Dr. Faris's claims about Medication A were deceptive.

items.stimulusText: Student: My paper was not graded in accordance with the professor's stated criteria. The professor said that she would give A's only to papers whose conclusions were supported by reliable statistical evidence. The professor acknowledges that my conclusions were supported by reliable statistical evidence, but she gave my paper a B.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the student's argument is flawed in that the argument

options.optionContent: discusses the professor's stated criteria in order to draw attention away from the shortcomings of the student's paper
attempts to draw an evaluative conclusion solely on the basis of factual claims
takes a condition that is among the requirements for a particular grade to be a condition that is enough to guarantee that grade
is based on the report of a biased participant in the controversy
fails to make a necessary distinction between the professor's grading criteria and the objective criteria of a paper's quality

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This student draws a conclusion about the professor's stated criteria, so any discussion of those criteria is appropriate. Further, the student never claims the paper lacks shortcomings, so the argument is not an attempt to deflect from the paper's flaws.

This answer choice mischaracterize's the argument's conclusion. The argument's conclusion is factual, not evaluative. Evaluative conclusions are about an entity's worth, value, merit, etc. Whether the professor correctly applied her guidelines can be established without making an “evaluation” about the professor or the guidelines.

This answer choice accurately describes the Sufficient/Necessary flaw in the student's argument. The “condition” that's a “requirement” for an A is the presence of reliable stats in the paper. The student implies the paper unfairly received a B despite featuring reliable stats, which means the student mistakenly believes that the reliable stats are enough to guarantee the A.

The student may be a biased participant in this so-called controversy, but that doesn't render the premises or conclusion inherently flawed. Especially when the central premise — the paper's use of reliable stats — is verified by the teacher. In fact, it would actually be a flaw to assume that because the student has a vested interest, the argument is without merit.

This answer choice, like (A), misconstrues the student's conclusion. The student's argument is about the professor's criteria. It's not about the objective quality of the paper. Because the argument is focused only on the professor's criteria, there's no need to distinguish it from “objective criteria of a paper's quality.”

items.stimulusText: Consumer advocate: Even relatively minor drug-related interactions can still be harmful to patients. For example, aspirin taken with fruit juice is ineffective. People unaware of this suffer unnecessary discomfort or take more aspirin than necessary. The government should, therefore, require drug companies to notify consumers of all known drug-related interactions.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the consumer advocate's argument?

options.optionContent: Providing information on minor drug-related interactions would detract from a patient's attention to serious interactions.
Many drugs have fewer documented drug-related interactions than does aspirin.
Providing information about all drug-related interactions would result in only negligible price increases for consumers.
Current research is such that many drug-related interactions have not yet been identified.
Pharmacists usually draw patients' attention to printed warnings that are provided with drugs.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice points to a significant downside of requiring drug companies to list “all known drug-related interactions.” If every prescription comes with a tome of potential, minor interactions, then consumers may disregard all the warnings, and not pay attention to or heed warnings about potentially catastrophic interactions. So this answer choice weakens the argument by providing a reason why companies shouldn't notify consumers of all known interactions.

This doesn't provide a reason why companies shouldn't notify consumers of all known drug-related interactions. If many drugs have fewer known interactions, then that's no problem. Companies will just have to provide a shorter list of interactions to the consumer. If anything, this may add a reason why companies should notify consumers of all known interactions — a shorter list would probably be cheaper to produce for the company and less overwhelming for the consumer. At any rate, this answer choice does not present a downside to the consumer advocate's recommendation, so it is incorrect.

This strengthens the argument by eliminating a potential drawback of the consumer advocate's mandate. This requirement may make drugs even more expensive, maybe even inaccessible to those who need the drugs. But if the mandate leads to just a negligible cost increase, as this answer choice states, then the consumer advocate's conclusion is more persuasive.

Like (B), this answer just shows that, for many drugs, the list of known interactions isn't extensive. But that's OK. That doesn't provide a reason why drug companies shouldn't notify consumers of all the interactions they know about. If anything, this may explain why companies should inform consumers of all known interactions — a shorter list would likely be less costly for the company and easier to read and follow for the consumer.

This answer choice provides a reason why drug companies should notify consumers of all known interactions: pharmacists can point consumers to — and perhaps better understand — the warnings. This may strengthen the argument by eliminating a drawback of the consumer advocate's position, so this answer choice should be eliminated.

items.stimulusText: Radioactive elements may have been created when the universe began. However, even if this occurred, these elements are clearly still being created in the universe today. Radioactive elements are unstable, so most of them decay within at most a few million years into other, nonradioactive elements. So, if no new radioactive elements had been created after the universe began, almost no radioactive elements would be left in the universe today, but there is an abundance of such elements.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion of the argument?

options.optionContent: Any radioactive elements created when the universe began have probably decayed into other, nonradioactive elements.
Radioactive elements are being created in the universe today.
If no new radioactive elements had been created after the universe began, almost no radioactive elements would be left in the universe today.
It is possible that radioactive elements were created when the universe began.
Due to their instability, most of the universe's radioactive elements decay within at most a few million years into other, nonradioactive elements.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Perhaps this could be inferred from the argument, but this claim is never explicitly made in the passage. The author never definitively claims that radioactive elements were created when the universe began, so the author does not make a definitive statement about what happened to those elements.

This answer choice refers to the argument's main conclusion. It is supported by every other claim in the argument, and it does not support anything else. Moreover, this answer choice does not distort or misrepresent the idea expressed in the argument's main conclusion. So this is the correct answer.

This answer choice refers to the argument's second subsidiary conclusion. It is supported by the first subsidiary conclusion (the second part of the third sentence), but it supports the argument's main conclusion.

This refers to a concession the author makes at the beginning of the argument. The argument does not try to prove anything about the creation of radioactive elements during the universe's formation, so this answer choice has no role in the argument.

This answer choice refers to the first subsidiary conclusion. This claim supports the second subsidiary conclusion (the first part of the last sentence), which in turn is used to support the argument's main conclusion.

items.stimulusText: There is evidence that a certain ancient society burned large areas of land. Some suggest that this indicates the beginning of large-scale agriculture in that society—that the land was burned to clear ground for planting. But there is little evidence of cultivation after the fires. Therefore, it is likely that this society was still a hunter-gatherer society.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?

options.optionContent: Many ancient cultures had agriculture before they began using fire to clear large tracts of land.
Hunter-gatherer societies used fire for cooking and for heat during cold weather.
Many plants and trees have inedible seeds that are contained in hard shells and are released only when subjected to the heat of a great fire.
Hunter-gatherer societies are known to have used fire to move animal populations from one area to another.
Few early societies were aware that burning organic material can help create nutrients for soil.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice has no effect on this argument. Even if some ancient cultures engaged in agriculture before burning wide swaths of land, that isn't necessarily the “large-scale agriculture” this argument discusses. Moreover, even if this were true, it wouldn't show that this ancient society in question was still a hunter-gatherer society.

Sure, hunter-gatherers may need fire for these reasons, but why would they need to burn “large areas of land” to cook or warm themselves? It seems much more practical to use small fires for both of these purposes. In brief, this answer choice may show why this society needed fire, but not the large-scale fires required to burn large tracts of land.

First, we don't know that the areas burned contained these plants with inedible seeds.Second, even if the ancient society burned these plants and trees, this still wouldn't explain why the ancient society had to burn the land to free the edible seeds. Why not just burn the shells? Wouldn't it make more sense to keep the seed-bearing plants and trees intact? Like (B), this answer choice may show why this society needed fire, but not the large-scale fires required to burn large tracts of land.

This answer choice strengthens the argument by showing why hunter-gatherers would need to clear land with fire: to move herds of animals and (presumably) make it easier to hunt them. Unlike (B) or (C), this answer choice points to a purpose a hunter-gatherer society would have not just for fires but for large-scale, land-clearing fires. If we added this back to the argument, the author's conclusion would seem more convincing, and it is the correct answer.

Although this suggests the ancient society was probably not aware of the nutrient-enriching benefit of burning land, it doesn't necessarily undermine the claim that they were burning land for agriculture. A society can do something even it is unaware of all the benefits of doing that thing. This answer choice doesn't explain why a hunter-gatherer society would burn a tract of land. Consequently, it doesn't strengthen the author's conclusion.

items.stimulusText: Professor Shanaz: People generally notice and are concerned about only the most obvious public health problems. Although there is indisputable evidence that ozone, an air pollutant, can be dangerous for severe asthmatics even if found in levels much lower than maximum levels permitted by law, most people are currently well aware that contaminated water presents a much more widespread threat to our community. Hence, there is unlikely to be a widespread, grassroots effort for new, more restrictive air pollution controls at this time.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in Professor Shanaz's argument by the claim that people generally notice and are concerned about only the most obvious public health problems?

options.optionContent: It is a premise offered in support of the claim that contaminated water currently presents a much more widespread threat to the community than does ozone.
It is a premise offered in support of the claim that there is unlikely to be a widespread, grassroots effort for new, more restrictive air pollution controls at this time.
It is used to explain the current public awareness of the severity of the problem of contaminated water.
It is presented as indisputable evidence that ozone can be dangerous for severe asthmatics even if found in levels much lower than maximum levels permitted by law.
It is the main conclusion drawn in the argument.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The statement-in-question is a premise. However, the statement-in-question supports the conclusion that there probably will not be widespread efforts to tighten air pollution regulations. The claim that contaminated water presents a threat is another premise, not supported by anything in this argument.

This is it. The statement-in-question is a premise. And it supports, as this answer choice states, the conclusion that there probably will not be widespread efforts to tighten air pollution regulations. This answer choice correctly identifies the role of the statement-in-question and accurately describes the conclusion of the argument, so it is the correct answer.

The statement-in-question is a principle about public health issues in general. It doesn't offer any specific insight into the contaminated water problem. Rather, the statement is used as a premise to support the conclusion that there probably will not be widespread efforts to tighten air pollution regulations. This answer choice neglects to mention that function, so it is incorrect.

The statement-in-question is used as evidence. However, the statement-in-question supports the conclusion that there probably will not be widespread efforts to tighten air pollution regulations. The claim that ozone can be dangerous for asthmatic people is another premise, not supported by anything in this argument.
The statement-in-question is a premise. The argument's main conclusion is that there probably will not be widespread efforts to tighten air pollution regulations.

items.stimulusText: Psychotherapist: The troubles from which a patient seeks relief through psychotherapy do not have purely internal causes; rather, those troubles result in part from the patient's relationships with other people. Hence, to help the patient heal, the psychotherapist must focus on the need for positive change in those relationships.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption the psychotherapist's argument requires?

options.optionContent: Psychotherapists cannot help change their patients' relationships unless those patients focus on other people's troubles.
At least some psychotherapy patients cannot be healed if a psychotherapist helps them change their relationships with other people.
Those psychotherapy patients who change their relationships with other people will thereby find relief from at least some of their troubles.
No psychotherapist can help a patient heal solely by addressing the internal causes of the patient's troubles.
If a psychotherapist helps patients focus on troubles that are purely internal, then that psychotherapist thereby provides them the relief they seek.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice brings up a new idea: a patient focusing on “other people's troubles.” But the gap in this argument was only about therapists helping their patients and the causes of a patient's troubles. To address that gap, we don't need to establish anything about a patient focusing on “other people's troubles.” Rather than addressing the gap in the argument, this answer choice creates a new gap by introducing a new idea.

This answer choice has the type of weak language (“at least some”) we often see in correct answer choices to this type of question. However, it is not necessary to draw the conclusion.Remember, this argument concludes that therapists need to focus on a patient's relationships to help the patient heal. To reach that conclusion, do we need to know that some patients won't be healed even if the therapist focuses on a patient's relationships? Of course not. In fact, the negation test will confirm that answer choice is not necessary. Suppose it wasn't true that some patients won't be healed even if the therapist focuses on a patient's relationships. Or, better put, suppose all patients were healed when the therapist focuses on a patient's relationships. In that case, is the conclusion now untrue? Definitely not. We'd only strengthen the conclusion if we establish a consistent correlation between healing and focusing on relationships. Therefore, this answer choice is not necessary to the argument and should be eliminated.

This answer choice has the type of weak language (“at least some”) we often see in correct answer choices to this type of question. Plus, this answer choice gets very close to addressing the gap in the argument. But this answer choice leaves out the therapist's role. Remember, this conclusion argues that the therapist will help the patient heal if the therapist focuses on the patient making positive changes in relationships. This answer choice doesn't address how a therapist can help a patient find relief from troubles, so it doesn't strengthen the argument.

This answer choice establishes a link between the conclusion's new idea (a therapist helping a patient heal) and one of the premises (that patient's troubles do not have solely internal causes). By bridging the gap between the two discrete terms, this answer choice strengthens the argument. If a therapist can't help a patient by focusing on the internal causes of their troubles, the therapist will instead need to help patients change their relationships. Moreover, the negation test will confirm that this answer choice is necessary to the argument. Suppose it wasn't true that therapists can't help their patients simply by focusing on the internal causes of the patients' troubles. Or, stated another way, suppose therapists could help patients by addressing the internal causes of the patients' troubles. In that case, is the conclusion now untrue? Yes. A therapist wouldn't have to focus on changing the patient's relationships in that case. Therefore, this answer choice is necessary to the argument and is correct.

This weakens the conclusion and is incorrect. Therapists helping patients heal by focusing on the purely internal troubles would show that therapists don't need to focus on helping their patients make positive relationship changes.

items.stimulusText: Some freelance journalists sell their work to magazines that have lax editorial standards. No self-respecting writer sells his or her work to magazines that have lax editorial standards. Therefore, some self-respecting writers are not freelance journalists.
items.stemText: Which one of the following displays a flawed pattern of reasoning most similar to the one in the argument above?

options.optionContent: Some high school teachers teach biology. No kindergarten teachers teach biology. Therefore, biology is not taught by all teachers.
Most school board members were once teachers. No one who was once a teacher prefers administrative work to teaching. Hence, few school board members prefer administrative work to teaching.
Some students prefer history to mathematics. No member of the Calculus Club prefers history to mathematics. Thus, some members of the Calculus Club are not students.
Some principals are harsh disciplinarians. No adviser to a debate team is a harsh disciplinarian. Hence, some principals are not advisers to a debate team.
Some teachers who let their students leave early are popular. No coaches allow their students to leave before three o'clock. Therefore, some popular teachers are not coaches.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice features a “some” premise, a conditional premise, and a “some” conclusion (“not ... all” can be translated to “some do not”). However, the non-negated term in the conclusion (“biology”) is not the sufficient condition of the conditional premise (“kindergarten teacher”). This makes this argument structurally dissimilar to the passage, which means it does not commit the same flaw. In fact, this argument is valid. If kindergarten teachers do not teach biology, it must be true that some teachers do not teach biology. Since this argument is not even flawed, it is incorrect.

This answer choice features a “most” premise. The argument in the passage did not feature a “most” statement at all, so this answer choice should be eliminated. Obviously, this answer choice cannot make an invalid combination of a “some” premise and a conditional premise if the answer choice does not feature a “some” premise. Moreover, this argument is valid. To validly combine a “most” and a conditional statement, the term shared by both must be the sufficient condition of the conditional statement. When the term shared by both is the “necessary” condition of the “most” statement, we can draw a “most” conclusion with the non-shared terms. Since both criteria are satisfied in the above case, we can validly draw the conclusion that most school board members do not prefer administrative work to teaching. Since this argument is not even flawed, it is incorrect.

This answer choice features a “some” premise, a conditional premise, and a “some” conclusion (“not ... all” can be translated to “some do not”). Moreover, the non-negated term in the conclusion (“members of the Calculus Club”) is the sufficient condition of the conditional premise. This makes this argument structurally similar to the passage. And, it's invalid for the same reason as the argument in the passage. If we take the contrapositive of the second statement (if Prefer History, then NOT Calculus Club), we can more easily see what a valid combination would look like. Remember the rule of combining a “some” statement and a conditional statement: the term shared by the two statements must be the sufficient condition in the conditional statement; (2) the conclusion must be a “some” statement containing the two non-shared terms. Because the first rule is satisfied, we validly could conclude: Students -some- NOT Calculus Club. However, the stated conclusion (Calculus Club -some- NOT Students) reverses and negates both conditions. Although “some” statements are reversible, we cannot validly negate both conditions — in other words, we cannot validly take the “contrapositive” of a “some” statement. The flawed conclusion in the passage also appeared to be the “contrapositive” of a properly drawn conclusion. So this answer choice is flawed for the same reason as the argument in the passage.

This answer choice features a “some” premise, a conditional premise, and a “some” conclusion. However, the non-negated term in the conclusion (“principles”) is not the sufficient condition of the conditional premise (“adviser to the debate team”). This makes this argument structurally dissimilar to the passage, which means it does not commit the same flaw. In fact, this argument is valid. Since this argument is not even flawed, it is incorrect.

This answer choice features a “some” premise, a conditional premise, and a “some” conclusion. However, the non-negated term in the conclusion (“popular teachers”) is not the sufficient condition of the conditional premise (“coach”). This argument is invalid, as it equivocates between “leaving early” and “leaving before three o'clock”. Otherwise, however, it's a valid combination of a “some” statement and a conditional statement. Ignoring that equivocation, if we take the contrapositive of the second premise (“Let Students Leave → NOT Coach”), we can more easily see what a valid combination would look like. Remember the rule of combining a “some” statement and a conditional statement: the term shared by the two statements must be the sufficient condition in the conditional statement; (2) the conclusion must be a “some” statement containing the two non-shared terms. Because the first rule is satisfied, we validly could conclude:Popular -some- NOT Coach. Since this argument is not even flawed, it is incorrect.

items.stimulusText: Selling syndicated reruns of a popular network television program while the program is still running on the network can lead to decreased revenues for that network. The show's producers do earn a great deal of money from the sale of the syndication rights because the stations rerunning the program are assured of a successful show. However, a recent study shows that over 80 percent of the programs that are made available as reruns and as first-run episodes during the same season suffer an immediate ratings drop for their first-run episodes.
items.stemText: The argument depends on assuming which one of the following?

options.optionContent: Programs that are sold into syndication early tend to be long-running hits that are likely to decline soon.
A drop in ratings has a negative effect on the network's revenues.
The price of syndication rights includes some compensation for the network's probable losses.
The audience of a popular program will usually prefer first-run episodes to reruns.
Most programs are never sold into syndication.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice explains the results of the study. It shows why running new and old episodes of the same show may shed viewers — the shows have been on the air forever and are bound to decline in ratings soon. However, this answer choice doesn't strengthen the argument because it doesn't show that a decline in ratings would affect a network's revenues. In other words, this answer choice fails to address the gap between the two discrete concepts in the argument's premise and conclusion. Therefore, this answer choice does not strengthen this argument, much less with a necessary premise.

This answer choice establishes a link between the premises (the study showing a drop in ratings for shows that run new and old episodes simultaneously) and the conclusion's new idea (a network losing revenue). By bridging the gap between the two discrete ideas, this answer choice strengthens the argument. Moreover, the negation test will confirm that this answer choice is necessary to the argument. Suppose it wasn't true that a drop in ratings “had a negative effect on the network's revenues.” Or, stated another way, suppose a drop in ratings didn't negatively impact a network's revenue. In that case, is the conclusion now untrue? Yes. We couldn't conclude that selling syndicated rights and simultaneously airing new and old episodes can decrease the network's revenue. Therefore, this answer choice is also necessary to the argument.

This answer choice has the sort of weak language (“includes”) we often see in correct answers on this type of question. Further, it strengthens the argument by asserting that the network has “probable losses” when it sells syndicated reruns of a show. However, it is not necessary to draw the conclusion.In fact, the negation test will confirm that answer choice is not necessary. Suppose the network did not receive compensation for the probable losses when it sold syndication rights. In that case, is the conclusion now untrue? Is it the case that the network's revenues will not decrease as a result of the sale? Not necessarily. Even if the network received compensation to help offset the losses, it could still lose money following the sale. Since we can draw the argument's conclusion even if we assume this answer choice isn't true, this answer choice is unnecessary and should be eliminated.

This answer choice is irrelevant to the argument. The audience's preference has no bearing on whether networks experience a revenue decrease when they run new and old episodes of a TV show at the same time.

This answer choice is irrelevant to the argument. This argument is about what happens when a network sells the syndication rights to a show. This answer choice just states networks won't sell the most shows' syndication rights. That doesn't tell us anything about the shows whose syndication rights are sold.

items.stimulusText: If a belief is based on information from a reliable source, then it is reasonable to maintain that belief. Furthermore, some beliefs are based on information from a reliable source and yet are neither self-evident nor grounded in observable evidence.
items.stemText: If all the statements above are true, which one of the following statements must be true?

options.optionContent: Beliefs for which a person does not have observable evidence are unreasonable.
Beliefs based on information from a reliable source are self-evident.
All reasonable beliefs for which a person has no observable evidence are based on information from a reliable source.
If a belief is not grounded in observable evidence, then it is not self-evident either.
