Among reasonable beliefs that are not self-evident, there are some beliefs that are not grounded in observable evidence.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice brings up beliefs that are not grounded on observable evidence. To support this answer choice, we would need to use the second sentence from the passage. That sentence is a “some” statement, but this answer choice discusses all beliefs not grounded on observable evidence. That means the conclusion drawn by this answer choice is logically stronger than its support. Therefore, it is incorrect.

The second premise establishes that some beliefs based on reliable sources are not self-evident. Therefore, this answer choice must be false. How could all beliefs based on reliable sources be self-evident if some of those beliefs are not self-evident?

An experienced and decisive test-taker might read three words of this answer choice before eliminating it. The first premise in the passage establishes “reasonable beliefs” as a necessary condition. That is the only mention of reasonable beliefs in this passage. This answer choice attempts to put “reasonable beliefs” as a sufficient condition, which means this answer choice is committing the reverses-without-negating flaw. We cannot conclude anything about “all reasonable beliefs.” We can only make a conclusion about “some” reasonable beliefs.

This answer choice asserts a conditional relationship between a self-evident belief and a belief grounded on observable evidence. From the passage, we can only conclude that some beliefs based on a reliable source and some reasonable beliefs lack both conditions. That doesn't mean that there's a conditional relationship between the two — there could be many self-evident beliefs that are not based on observable evidence.

In its incredibly wordy, difficult-to-parse way, this answer choice expresses the deduction we drew. Let's break it down, piece by piece. This answer choice refers to “reasonable beliefs,” which is synonymous with “beliefs that are reasonable to maintain.” The first part of this answer choice says, “Among reasonable beliefs that are not self-evident.” This tells us these beliefs have two conditions: they're reasonable and NOT self-evident. If we were abbreviating this statement, we could write: Reasonable Beliefs & NOT Self-Evident. Next, the answer choice tells us that some of these beliefs “are not grounded in observable evidence.” If we were to add this to the above, we would get: Reasonable Beliefs & NOT Self-Evident -some- NO Observable Evidence. From the passage, we can validly conclude that there's at least one belief that is (1) reasonable, and (2) not self-evident, and (3) not grounded on observable evidence. Both our initial deduction and this answer choice express that idea. (It would be equally valid to say, “Among beliefs that are not self-evident, there are some that are reasonable and not grounded in observable evidence.”) So this answer choice must be true and is correct.

items.stimulusText:
Situation: A physical therapist wants her patients to derive more enjoyment from the challenge of developing physical skills. She also wants them to spend more time practicing those skills.

Analysis: Success in meeting the first objective will bring about success in meeting the second.
items.stemText: The analysis provided for the situation above could be appropriate for each of the following situations except:

options.optionContent: A math teacher wants her students to understand the mathematical principles taught in her course and wants them to apply these principles routinely in everyday life.
A software manufacturer wants its customers to be more satisfied with its product, and it wants them to place fewer calls to the service representative about how to use the product.
A librarian wants fewer of the books borrowed from the library to be lost or stolen, and he wants more of the library's books to be returned on time.
A hardware retail company wants to construct a new, larger warehouse and wants its employees to help plan how the old warehouse will be expanded to meet any need for more space.
A concert series director wants to present a more varied repertoire and wants to attract new patrons.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: It's reasonable enough to conclude that a math teacher helping her students understand mathematical principles (her first objective) will help her students apply these principles to everyday life (her second objective). Understanding the principles could make it easier for students to apply the principles. Therefore, applying the analysis “success in the first objective success will bring about success in the second objective” to this situation seems logical. It's close enough, at least, to meet the low bar of “could be appropriate” set by the question stem.

It makes some intuitive sense to conclude that a software manufacturer making its customers more satisfied with its products (its first objective) would result in fewer calls to the customer service representatives (its second objective). After all, if the customers are satisfied with the product, they probably know how to use it, and they will probably not need to place as many calls to customer service. Therefore, applying the analysis “success in the first objective success will bring about success in the second objective” to this situation makes sense. It's close enough, at least, to meet the low bar of “could be appropriate” set by the question stem.

It makes some sense to conclude that having fewer books lost or stolen from a library (the librarian's first objective) would result in more books being returned on time (the librarian's second objective). After all, if fewer books are lost or stolen, it's probably the case that they're being returned on time, which would result in a higher percentage of the books being returned. Therefore, it's reasonable enough to apply the analysis “success in the first objective success will bring about success in the second objective” to this situation. It's close enough, at least, to meet the low bar of “could be appropriate” set by the question stem.

Unlike the other answer choices, this one presents two objectives that appear to be, if not mutually exclusive, at least in direct competition. Constructing a new, expansive warehouse would certainly not help “bring about success” in getting employees to plan how to expand the old warehouse. Making the new, large warehouse would obviate the need to expand the old warehouse. Therefore, we cannot apply the “success in the first objective success will bring about success in the second objective” to this situation.

It wouldn't be unfounded to conclude that a concert director introducing a more varied repertoire to the concerns (the first objective) would result in new patrons attending the concerts (the second objective). After all, more variety to the music presented could attract previously uninterested people to attend the concert series. So it's plausible enough to apply the analysis “success in the first objective success will bring about success in the second objective” to this situation. It's close enough, at least, to meet the low bar of “could be appropriate” set by the question stem.

items.stimulusText: Classicist: Our mastery of Latin and Ancient Greek is at best imperfect. The best students of a modern language may so immerse themselves in a country where it is spoken as to attain nearly perfect knowledge; but you cannot travel back in time to spend a year abroad at Plato's Academy.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the classicist's argument by the claim that you cannot travel back in time to spend a year abroad at Plato's Academy?

options.optionContent: It is the main conclusion drawn in the argument.
It points up by example a contrast from which the conclusion is drawn.
It is a mere rhetorical flourish having no logical relation to the argument's conclusion.
It is a premise that guarantees the truth of the argument's conclusion.
It is an ancillary conclusion drawn in the argument.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The statement-in-question is a premise. The first sentence is the main conclusion of this argument

As far as we can tell, “point up” is a Britishism meaning “emphasize.” So this answer choice can be roughly translated to, “It is an example intended to emphasize a contrast that supports the conclusion.” However, an adaptable test-taker could get to this answer choice without knowing this definition of “point up.” We know the statement-in-question draws a contrast with how we master modern language. This contrast is used to support the conclusion. So the phrase “a contrast from which the conclusion is drawn” is an apt description of the statement-in-question. Further, an adaptable test-taker could see how the reference to “Plato's Academy” could accurately be called an “example.” To illustrate the same point, the author could have used several other places where Latin or Ancient Greek was spoken — the Roman Colosseum, Virgil's study, Mycenae. The author just chose Plato's Academy as one example. So, even with the strange phrasing, it's possible to determine that this accurately expresses the role played by the statement-in-question.

The statement-in-question is a premise. The contrast it draws with how we master contemporary languages helps support the main conclusion. So it is inaccurate to say that the statement-in-question has “no logical relation to the argument's conclusion.”

The statement-in-question is a premise. However, this premise does not “guarantee[] the truth of the argument's conclusion.” This argument is flawed, so the conclusion is far from guaranteed. The statement-in-question shows why we can't master ancient languages in the same way we master modern language. But this doesn't guarantee the conclusion's assertion that our mastery of Latin and Ancient Greek is imperfect, as there could be other ways to gain mastery over those ancient languages.

This is a rare appearance of the term “ancillary conclusion” on the LSAT. In the context of law or business, the word ancillary means subordinate, supplemental, or subsidiary. So an “ancillary conclusion” is synonymous with “subsidiary conclusion” or “intermediate conclusion.” You wouldn't need to know that to eliminate this answer choice, however. The statement-in-question is not supported by anything — there's no study cited to disprove the existence of time machines or anything like that — so it cannot be a conclusion at all.

items.stimulusText: For there to be a thriving population of turtles in a pond, conditions at that pond must be beneficial to turtles. The water in Wallakim Pond, unlike that in Sosachi Pond, is acidic. Thus, there must not be a thriving population of turtles at Wallakim Pond.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if assumed, enables the argument's conclusion to be properly drawn?

options.optionContent: If the water in a pond is not acidic, the conditions at that pond are beneficial to turtles.
The most important factor that determines whether a pond will have a thriving turtle population is the acidity of the water.
The water conditions at Sosachi Pond are more beneficial to turtles than are the water conditions at Wallakim Pond.
Wallakim Pond would have a thriving population of turtles if it were not acidic.
The conditions at a pond are beneficial to turtles only if the water in the pond is not acidic.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Establishing that acidic ponds are not beneficial for turtles would justify this conclusion, as Wallakim is an acidic pond. But establishing that non-acidic ponds are beneficial does not tell us anything about Wallakim, and therefore does not support this conclusion.

This answer choice establishes a link between a pond's acidity and its turtle population, so it at least addresses the gap in the argument. However, it doesn't establish that acidity is bad or negatively impacts the turtle population. Even if (B) is true, it could be the case that an acidic pond is actually beneficial to turtle populations. So (B) doesn't ensure the validity of this argument's conclusion.

Even if the waters at Sosachi a more beneficial than the waters at Wallakim, that doesn't establish that the waters at Wallakim are not beneficial to turtles. Both Sosachi and Wallakim could have beneficial conditions for turtles, with Sosachi featuring slightly better conditions.

This answer choice describes a hypothetical about Wallakim Pond — if it was not acidic, it would be beneficial to turtles. One implication of this answer choice is that it's beneficial to turtles if a pond isn't acidic. That's the same conditional relationship that answer choice (A) brings up, so this answer choice is wrong for the same reasons as (A). We know Wallakim is acidic, and establishing that non-acidic ponds are beneficial doesn't tell us anything about Wallakim.

This will ensure the conclusion's validity. We can specify this as: if Beneficial Conditions, then NOT Acidic. If we take its contrapositive and add it to our argument, we can see that we have drawn a valid conclusion: (E) Contrapositive: if Acidic, then NOT Beneficial Conditions. Contrapositive: if NOT Beneficial Conditions, then NOT Thriving Turtle Pop. Wallakim: Acidic. Conclusion: Wallakim: NOT Thriving Turtle Pop.

items.stimulusText: The study of primates is interesting for many reasons, including the fact that only primates have opposable thumbs. The lemurs are lower primates and the only primates indigenous to Madagascar, a large island off the coast of southeastern Africa. Some species of lemurs are the only living lower primates that are diurnal—that is, active primarily during the day. All higher primates are thought to have evolved from a single diurnal species of lower primates.
items.stemText: Which one of the following can be properly inferred from the information above?

options.optionContent: The chimpanzee, a higher primate, evolved from the lemur.
No primates indigenous to Madagascar are diurnal higher primates.
No higher primate is nocturnal.
There are some lemurs without opposable thumbs.
There are no nocturnal lemurs.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We cannot conclude that any higher primates evolved from the lemur. So we cannot conclude that the chimpanzee, or any other higher primate, evolved from the lemur.

This answer choice must be true. The only primate indigenous to Madagascar is the lemur, and we know lemurs are lower primates. Therefore, if a primate is indigenous to Madagascar, it is a lower primate. So it is true that “No primates indigenous to Madagascar are ... higher primates.” They're all lower primates. This answer choice also mentions that these primates indigenous to Madagascar are not diurnal higher primates. That's also true. We know all primates indigenous to Madagascar are lower primates, which means they're not any kind of higher primates, no matter the sleep pattern.

This is not supported. Higher primates may have evolved from a diurnal lower primate (or so we think), but that doesn't mean that they're all diurnal as well. Beyond that, the passage doesn't provide any information about the sleep patterns of higher primates.

We have no idea if some lemurs lack opposable thumbs. The passage states that if a species has an opposable thumb, it must be a primate. That could imply that all primates have opposable thumbs or that some primates lack opposable thumbs. We can't say for sure. And even if we knew that some primates lacked opposable thumbs, we can't conclude that lemurs are among the species that lack opposable thumbs.

This answer choice is too strong. The passage tells us that “some” species of lemur are diurnal. But that doesn't imply that all species of lemur are diurnal. Some, or even most, lemurs could be nocturnal.

items.stimulusText: Professor: Many scientists hypothesize that there is an invisible "light-absorbing medium" in outer space. In support, they argue that the medium's existence would explain the low visibility of other star systems from Earth. But there is actually no reason to believe that the hypothesis is correct, since the low visibility in question is already completely explained by the general theory of relativity.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the professor's argument?

options.optionContent: The low visibility of other star systems from Earth would not be adequately explained by the existence of an invisible light-absorbing medium in outer space, even if there were such a medium.
The hypothesis of an invisible light-absorbing medium in outer space is correct only if it adequately explains the low visibility of other star systems from Earth.
A hypothesis is likely to be correct if there is some phenomenon that it adequately accounts for and that is not adequately accounted for by an existing theory.
Most scientists who posit the invisible light-absorbing medium accept the general theory of relativity.
The general theory of relativity does not depend upon the hypothesis that there exists an invisible light-absorbing medium in outer space.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice might strengthen the argument if true — it refutes the premise supporting the light-absorbing explanation-favoring scientists' hypothesis — but it isn't a necessary assumption. To draw the conclusion that we have no reason to believe in the light-absorbing explanation, we don't need to establish that the light-absorbing explanation can't even explain star dimness. We just need to show that the alternative explanation is enough, by itself, to explain star dimness.

The contrapositive of this answer choice would read, “If the hypothesis of an invisible light-absorbing medium in outer space does not adequately explain the low visibility of other star systems from Earth, then it is not correct.” That answer choice would strengthen this professor's conclusion if the professor established that the light-absorbing explanation didn't explain star dimness. However, the professor never said that. The professor just claimed that there's already the theory-of-relativity explanation that can explain star dimness. As on (A), we don't need to establish that the light-absorbing explanation can't explain star dimness. We just need to show that the theory-of-relativity explanation is enough, by itself, to explain star dimness.
We're looking for assumptions that would help support the conclusion that there's no evidence for the light-absorbing explanation. So we need rules for what makes a hypothesis incorrect, not correct.

This answer choice is irrelevant. Correctness does not depend upon public or even scientific acceptance. The Earth revolved around the sun long before most scientists accepted that theory. So whether or not scientists accept the theory of relativity does not affect whether the theory of relativity fully explains star dimness.

This precisely matches our anticipation that the correct answer would show that the theory-of-relativity explanation and the light-absorbing-medium explanation are mutually exclusive. This answer choice states that the theory-of-relativity explanation doesn't rely on the light-absorbing-medium explanation. This strengthens the argument, as it shows that the theory-of-relativity explanation can stand on its own — it doesn't need a light-absorbing medium to explain star dimness. Moreover, the negation test will confirm that this answer choice is necessary to the argument. Suppose that the general theory of relativity depended on the existence of an invisible light-absorbing medium in outer space. In that case, is the conclusion now untrue? Yep. The professor's belief in the theory of relativity's ability to explain star dimness would be evidence in favor of the existence of a light-absorbing medium, not evidence against its existence. Therefore, this answer choice is necessary to the argument and is correct.

items.stimulusText: Some researchers claim that people tend to gesture less when they articulate what would typically be regarded as abstract rather than physical concepts. To point out that such a correlation is far from universal is insufficient reason to reject the researchers' claim, because some people perceive words like "comprehension" as expressing a physical action, like grasping something, rather than a state of understanding, which is abstract.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately describes the method of reasoning used in the argument?

options.optionContent: appealing to the ambiguity of a word in an attempt to show that a correlation is universal
appealing to a universal psychological generalization in an attempt to support a claim about the use of gestures
citing a psychological fact to try to reconcile a generalization with apparently disconfirming evidence
advocating an explanation for a phenomenon by attempting to demonstrate that other possible explanations are implausible
offering a reason for believing that a widely accepted generalization requires still more supporting evidence

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This misdescribes the argument. The author didn't claim the correlation (between gesturing and concrete words) is universal. In fact, the conclusion is about how the correlation is not universal.

Like (A), this misdescribes the argument. The author never claimed the generalization (that we gesture more when saying concrete words) is universal. In fact, the conclusion is about how the correlation is not universal.

This answer choice is very close to our anticipation (“attempting to explain why potentially inconsistent evidence is not a reason to reject a generalization”) and is worthy of a closer inspection. Some test-takers may take issue with the abstract phrasing here — especially that which doesn't conform to our anticipation, such as the words “psychological fact” and “reconcile.” However, if we can find an analog in the passage that matches these words, we can be confident that this answer choice accurately describes the technique of reasoning in the passage. So, what could be the “psychological fact” this answer choice references? According to this answer choice, the fact will help reconcile a “generalization” and “disconfirming evidence.” We've already identified the generalization as the belief that people gesture more when describing concrete stuff. And the disconfirming evidence would appear to be that this “correlation is far from universal” — not everyone gestures more when describing concrete stuff. What could this psychological fact be then? The last premise describes how some people “perceive” (a psychological phenomenon) words differently. In other words, the psychological fact is that the perception of particular concepts as concrete or abstract is not the same for everyone. So we can find an analog in the passage for “psychological fact,” which means we shouldn't reject (C) for using this term. For many test-takers, “reconcile” is another keyword that may jump out in this answer choice. Whenever the idea of “reconciling” comes up in Logical Reasoning, it usually means using evidence to show how apparently contradictory facts can both be true. That's what happened here. Yes, it seems contradictory to say that the generalization is (1) not universal and (2) real. But the “psychological fact” can show why both sides are true — we all gesture more on concrete stuff, we just disagree on what is concrete. So no matter how we slice it, (C) correctly describes the argumentative technique in this passage, and it is correct.

Another answer choice that misdescribes the argument. The author never discussed “other possible explanations” for a phenomenon. In fact, the argument didn't even explain why we gesture more when describing concrete stuff. Rather, the issue was whether or not the phenomenon is even valid!
This incorrectly characterizes the conclusion of the argument. Our author does not call for additional evidence in their conclusion.

items.stimulusText: According to rational-choice theory, popular support for various political parties can be explained sufficiently in terms of deliberate decisions by individual voters to support the party whose policies they believe will yield them the greatest economic advantage. This theory is opposed by many sociologists on the grounds that a complex phenomenon such as the rise of a political organization cannot be caused by a simple phenomenon.
items.stemText: It can be properly inferred from the statements above that many sociologists believe that

options.optionContent: economically motivated decisions by voters need not constitute a complex phenomenon
a complex phenomenon generally will have many complex causes
political phenomena often have religious and cultural causes as well as economic ones
popular support for political parties is never a complex phenomenon
the decisions of individual voters are not usually influenced by their beliefs about which policies will yield them the greatest economic advantage

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Right away, we get our anticipation. If voting based on personal economic interest was a complex phenomenon, the sociologists couldn't use their principle to undermine rational-choice theory. Because they believe the principle undermines rational-choice theory, the sociologists must believe voting based on rational economic interest is not a complex phenomenon. This is correct.

The sociologists seem to believe complex phenomena have complex causes, but nothing here says they believe each phenomenon has more than one cause. They may believe some phenomena have one complex cause.
Religion and culture were not mentioned in this passage at all! So this answer choice is simply not supported by the passage.
This contradicts the sociologists' premise. The sociologists use the popular support of a political organization support as an example of a complex phenomenon.

Since we know the sociologists oppose rational-choice theory. However, this answer choice subtly but significantly misdescribes what rational-choice theory is. Rational-choice theory holds that popular support for a political party is entirely (“sufficiently”) explained by voters making decisions based on their economic self-interest. The sociologists certainly have issues with that. But even though they don't think popular support for a political party isn't entirely explained by that, they could still think that economic self-interest influences voters' decisions. The sociologists think that considerations of economic self-interest don't entirely cause the rise of political parties, not that those considerations never enter into the equation at all.

items.stimulusText: Scientist: Some consumer groups claim that the economic benefits of genetically engineered foodstuffs may be offset by hidden health risks to humans. However, the risk is minimal. In most cases of deliberate alteration of a plant's genetic structure only a single gene in about 750,000 has been changed. Since the change in the organism's genetic structure is so slight, it cannot have effects significant enough to be worrisome.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the scientist's argument?

options.optionContent: The genetically engineered plants that have been developed so far have few advantages over plants that are not genetically engineered.
Whatever health risks there are in food from genetically altered plants may be somewhat reduced by other factors such as enrichment of the plants' vitamin and mineral content.
Scientists have yet to determine, for each characteristic of some plants and animals used for food, the precise location of the genes that determine that characteristic.
There are plants that are known to be toxic to some animals and whose toxicity is known to be affected by the alteration of a single gene.
Research has shown that those consumers who are most strongly opposed to genetically altered foods tend to be ill-informed on the issue.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is unrelated to the question of GMOs' capacity to cause harm. If they have few advantages but do not cause harm, the scientist's argument is not any weaker.

This answer choice says that even if GMOs were harmful, those harms are mitigated by other factors. Mitigating factors would only strengthen the scientist's claims GMOs' risk is minimal, so this is incorrect.

This answer choice may be tempting, since it makes it seem like scientists don't really understand the food they're genetically engineering. But really, it is so weak that it doesn't have an effect on the argument. Scientists don't know what all 750,000 genes do in just some plants and animals? Even if that were true, they could still only alter the genes they understand, and the risks of altering those genes could be minimal.

Yes! This answer choice presents the same cause (alteration of a single gene) and the same effect (changing the toxicity of the plant). So this answer choice strengthens the claim that altering a single gene might cause harm, which weakens the scientist's claim that changing a single gene is too insignificant to increase the risk of harm. There are a few things that might give us pause about this answer choice. First, it's about plants we know to be toxic, while the passage focused on “foodstuffs,” which are generally not toxic. Second, it discusses the toxicity to animals, not necessarily humans. Finally, it just says that the “toxicity is known to be affected” — it doesn't say that the toxicity is increased. However, these doubts should be erased when we remember how strong the scientists' assertion was. The scientist depends entirely on the claim that changing a single gene is just too minor a change to affect a plant's capacity to cause harm when eaten. This answer choice shows an instance when changing a single gene can affect a plant's ability to cause harm. Even if those plants are not ones we eat or genetically modify, even if the change would only affect nonhuman animals, and even if the change actually makes the plan less toxic, the answer choice still weakens the scientist's argument. It undercuts the scientist's claim that altering a single gene “cannot have effects significant enough” to increase the risk of harm. This answer choice shows it's possible alter a single gene and produce significant effects, so it is correct.

This is irrelevant. People can be ill-informed about a topic generally but correct about one specific fact (or even about the topic in general). Pointing out that someone is ill-informed may make one's argument less convincing, but it doesn't make their beliefs necessarily false. Even if did, this would only strengthen the scientists' argument.

items.stimulusText: A government is justified in interfering with a person's action if the action would increase the likelihood of physical harm to others and the action is not motivated by a desire to help others.
items.stemText: Of the following judgments, which one most closely conforms to the principle above?

options.optionContent: Jerry's hobby, making home movies, does not harm anyone, nor does it increase the likelihood of harm to anyone. He does it because he thinks that it will benefit his children by preserving a record of their childhoods. So the government is unjustified in interfering with Jerry's moviemaking.

It is well known that a property is aesthetically less pleasing when neighboring properties have unkempt lawns. My neighbor often forgets to mow his lawn for several weeks. The city council, therefore, is justified in fining my neighbor for not mowing his lawn more frequently.

Because a motorcyclist who is not wearing a helmet is much more likely to suffer a serious head injury in the event of an accident, the government is justified in requiring motorcyclists to wear helmets.

Because Zabziew Pharmaceutical Corporation's research is motivated by the desire to make profits and not by the desire to benefit customers, it has been of little help to people suffering from serious illness. So the government is justified in suspending Zabziew's license to test new drugs.

To further her own political ambitions, Jill wanted to give a speech advocating the use of violence to achieve political ends. But her speech would most likely have caused a riot and people would have gotten hurt. Hence, the government was justified in preventing her from giving her speech.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: We don't have any principle that leads to the conclusion “Government NOT justified in interfering,” so we cannot choose an answer that draws this conclusion. We only have NOT justified as a sufficient condition, not as a necessary one.

This argument at least leads to a conclusion our principle could justify — the government justified in interfering — but both halves of the sufficient condition are missing. The lawn isn't causing physical harm, and we don't know if the neighbor overgrows his lawn to help others, so this one is incorrect.

Not wearing a helmet is “increasing the likelihood of physical harm,” but not “to others,” so it doesn't meet the first half of our sufficient condition. And the other half is absent as well. We don't know if motorcyclists decline helmets to help others (or — unless they really want to help trauma surgeons practice their craft — how this could feasibly help others).

Here we have a situation in which it's true that the corporation was “not motivated by the intent to help others,” but it's missing the condition “increases the chance of physical harm to others.” The company may be making ineffective drugs, but that doesn't automatically mean they're harmful.

Finally! A situation in which there is an increased chance of physical harm to others (people getting hurt in a riot) and not a desire to help others (making the speech to further her own political ambitions). Both halves of the sufficient condition are present; therefore the conclusion that interference is permissible is fully justified, and (E) is correct.

sections.directions: Directions: Each question in this section is based on the reasoning presented in a brief passage. In answering the questions, you should not make assumptions that are by commonsense standards implausible, superfluous, or incompatible with the passage. For some questions, more than one of the choices could conceivably answer the question. However, you are to choose the best answer; that is, choose the response that most accurately and completely answers the question.

items.stimulusText: The government's tax collection agency has not followed through on its plan, announced a year ago, to crack down on violations of corporate income tax law. Audits are the primary tool for detecting such violations, and over the past year, not a single audit of corporate income tax returns has been completed.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?

options.optionContent: The plan to crack down on violations of corporate income tax law is part of a broad campaign against corporate misconduct.
The number of personal income tax returns audited over the past year is greater than in previous years.
Most audits of corporate income tax returns do not reveal any significant violations.
It generally takes longer than one year to complete an audit of a corporate income tax return.
Over the last five years, fewer audits of corporate income tax returns have been completed than in the preceding five years.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice is irrelevant to the author’s argument. It doesn’t show that the government is trying to crack down on corporate income tax violations, even if it hasn’t completed any audits this year. This answer choice just provides context to the government’s promise to crack down on corporate income tax violations. If the argument concluded that the government is not trying to reduce “corporate misconduct” because it hasn’t completed any audits, this answer choice would weaken the argument. But the argument concludes that the government isn’t trying to cut down corporate income tax violations, making this answer choice irrelevant.

Like (A), this answer choice doesn’t show that the government is trying to crack down on corporate income tax violations, even if it hasn’t completed any audits this year. Instead, this answer choice tells us about “personal income tax”  — not “corporate income tax.” The former addresses whether individuals accurately report the incomes they receive; the latter addresses whether corporations accurately report the incomes they pay their employees. If the argument concluded that the government is not trying to reduce “income tax violations” because it hasn’t completed any audits of corporations, this answer choice would weaken the argument. But the argument concludes that the government isn’t trying to cut down corporate income tax violations, making this answer choice irrelevant.

This answer choice is irrelevant to the author’s argument. It doesn’t show that the government is trying to crack down on corporate income tax violations, even if it hasn’t completed any audits this year. This answer choice tells us about the success rate of audits on corporate income tax returns. But that’s irrelevant to the argument’s conclusion, which addresses whether the government is attempting to crack down on violations of corporate income tax law. Whether these audits would reveal fraud is immaterial to whether these attempts are being made.

This definitely weakens the author’s argument. It shows that the government’s audits on corporate income tax returns take longer than a year. So, even if no audits have been completed this year, the government could still be pursuing these audits and thus attempting to uncover corporate income tax law violations. In other words, (D) shows that the government is trying to crack down on corporate income tax violations, even if it hasn’t completed any audits this year.

This answer choice is irrelevant to the author’s argument, which focuses only on the “past year.” The number of audits over the last “five years” doesn’t tell us anything about the number of audits this past year. Besides, the argument already told us that no audits on corporate income tax returns have been completed this year. Even if this answer choice did tell us about the number of audits completed over the last year, it wouldn’t add any information that could meaningfully affect the author’s argument.

items.stimulusText: Columnist: Making some types of products from recycled materials is probably as damaging to the environment as it would be to make those products from entirely nonrecycled materials. The recycling process for those products requires as much energy as producing them from raw materials, and almost all energy production damages the environment.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the columnist's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument

options.optionContent: uses the word "environment" in one sense in a premise and in a different sense in the conclusion drawn from that premise
treats an effect of energy-related damage to the environment as if it were instead a cause of such damage
fails to consider that the particular types of recycled products that it cites may not be representative of recycled products in general
fails to consider that making products from recycled materials may have environmental benefits unrelated to energy consumption
presumes that simply because one phenomenon follows another phenomenon the earlier phenomenon must be a cause of the later one

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't describe a flaw in this argument's reasoning. The meaning of “environment” doesn't change over the course of the argument. Both times the columnist uses “environment,” it refers to the natural world.

This answer choice describes a type of cause-and-effect flaw, and it's tempting to some test-takers because this argument describes a cause-and-effect relationship between producing energy and damaging the environment. The columnist claims that producing energy causes damage to the environment. This answer choice says the argument is flawed because that cause and effect could be reversed  — implying that damaging the environment could produce energy. But that's not an issue here since producing energy (to make or recycle products) clearly precedes environmental damage. Moreover, this answer choice doesn't address the salient point in the columnist's argument  — whether making products from recycled materials is as environmentally damaging as making products from nonrecycled materials. Therefore, this answer choice does not describe an error in the columnist's reasoning.

When we see “fails to consider” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the author's argument if true?” This answer choice wouldn't weaken the argument. The columnist's conclusion isn't about “recycled products in general.” It's only about “some types of products from recycled materials.” Even if almost all recycled products don't damage the environment as much as nonrecycled products, that wouldn't necessarily hurt the columnist's conclusion. To prove this conclusion, the columnist just needs to show that a couple of recycled products damage the environment as much as nonrecycled products.

When we see “fails to consider” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the author's argument if true?” This would definitely weaken the columnist's conclusion. Suppose that making products from recycled materials can benefit the environment in ways that aren't related to energy consumption. In that case, making some products from recycled materials wouldn’t damage the environment as much as making those products from nonrecycled materials. If using recycled materials cuts down the amount of natural resources we use or the amount of waste we produce, then these recycled products might be significantly better for the environment than products from nonrecycled materials. So, this answer choice describes an error in the columnist's reasoning.

When we see “presumes, without providing justification” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, the columnist doesn't necessarily believe that one thing must cause another simply because the first came before the second. Although the columnist describes a cause-and-effect relationship between producing energy and damaging the environment, the columnist doesn't say that producing energy causes damage to the environment simply because producing energy comes first. In fact, the columnist never describes why they think that producing energy causes environmental damage. The columnist asserts that relationship as a premise, so we have to accept it when evaluating this argument's validity. Besides, this answer choice doesn't address the salient point in the columnist's argument  — whether making products from recycled materials is as environmentally damaging as making products from nonrecycled materials. Therefore, this answer choice does not describe an error in the columnist's reasoning.

items.stimulusText: Physician: We are constantly bombarded by warnings, based on initial studies' tentative conclusions, about this or that food having adverse health effects. If the medical establishment wants people to pay attention to health warnings, it should announce only conclusive results, the kind that can come only from definitive studies. After all, people who are constantly subjected to fire drills eventually come to ignore the fire alarm.
items.stemText: The statement that people who are constantly subjected to fire drills eventually come to ignore the fire alarm plays which one of the following roles in the physician's argument?

options.optionContent: It is presented as an example of the sort of warning referred to in the argument's overall conclusion.
It is a statement that plays no logical role in the argument but that instead serves to impugn the motives of the medical establishment.
It is an analogy offered in support of the argument's overall conclusion.
It is an analogy that forms part of a specific objection to the argument's overall conclusion.
It is an analogy offered to clarify the distinction the physician makes between an initial study and a definitive study.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: The last sentence isn't an example of the type of warning referenced in the argument's main conclusion. The argument's main conclusion addresses warnings about foods from definitive studies, not fire alarms.

The last sentence plays a role in the argument — it's an analogy that supports the argument's conclusion. Moreover, the physician never impugns (challenges) the medical establishment's motives. The physician describes what the medical establishment should do to prevent people from ignoring its warnings.

This is correct! The last sentence is an analogy that supports the argument's main conclusion. After all, the last sentence shows why conclusions from initial studies are bad, supporting the last conclusion's claim that the medical establishment should only publish conclusions from definitive studies.

It's true that the last sentence is an analogy, but it doesn't challenge or undermine the argument's overall conclusion. It supports the argument's conclusion. It shows why conclusions from initial studies are bad, supporting the last conclusion's claim that the medical establishment should only publish conclusions from definitive studies.

It's true that the last sentence is an analogy, but it doesn't challenge or undermine the argument's overall conclusion. It supports the argument's conclusion. It shows why conclusions from initial studies are bad, supporting the last conclusion's claim that the medical establishment should only publish conclusions from definitive studies.

items.stimulusText: A club wanted to determine whether it could increase attendance by changing its weekly meetings from Tuesday to another day. At one Tuesday meeting, the club's president took a survey of all members present. Of those surveyed, 95 percent said that they had no difficulty attending on Tuesdays. On the basis of this survey result, the club's president concluded that the attendance problem was not due primarily to schedule conflicts.
items.stemText: A questionable technique used in the club president's reasoning is

options.optionContent: drawing a conclusion on the basis of circular reasoning
making a generalization on the basis of a sample that is likely to be unrepresentative
treating a generalization that applies to most cases as if it applied without exception
drawing a conclusion on the basis of premises that contradict one another
inferring, solely from the claim that a change is not sufficient to solve a problem, that it is not necessary either

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Circular reasoning is a flaw in which the conclusion merely restates a premise. They typically have this pattern on the LSAT: “X is true. We know this because, even when X doesn't appear to be true, X still must be true because X is always true.” This argument doesn't rely on circular reasoning. The club president's premise is a survey, and the conclusion rules out one explanation for the club's low attendance. The conclusion is not a mere restatement of the premise.

This describes the flaw perfectly! The author makes a generalization about the entire club's membership based on a sample of club members who attended a Tuesday meeting. This sample is likely to be unrepresentative because that sample doesn't include the members who can't attend Tuesday meetings. That's a particular issue in this argument, as the club president draws a conclusion about whether the club's low attendance at Tuesday meetings is due to scheduling issues. Note to the club president: you might want to ask the people who can't attend Tuesday meetings about that!

This is tempting because the club president definitely makes a generalization. The club president assumes that the club's members generally do not have scheduling conflicts with the club's Tuesday meetings. However, the club president does not say this generalization applies “without exception.” The club president's conclusion is just that the club's “attendance problem was not due primarily to schedule conflicts.” This conclusion doesn’t apply to all club members; it allows for some club members to have scheduling conflicts with the Tuesday meetings.

These premises do not contradict each other. The premises assert that the club normally meets on Tuesday, and the president's survey at a Tuesday meeting reveals that 95% of the members say meeting on Tuesday is fine. Both of these premises can be simultaneously true.

The club president doesn't claim that any change is “not sufficient to solve the problem.” The club president doesn't say that changing the meeting to a different date won't cause meeting attendance to increase. The president never considers what would happen if they met on a different day. Because this answer choice misdescribes the argument, it does not describe an error in the club president's reasoning.

items.stimulusText: The railway authority inspector who recently thoroughly checked the tracks testified that they were in good condition. Thus, since the inspector has no bias in the matter, we should be suspicious of the newspaper reporter's claim that the tracks are in poor condition.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the argument above is most similar to the reasoning in which one of the following arguments?

options.optionContent: My pottery instructor says that making pottery will not cause repetitive-motion injuries if it is done properly. So I will probably not get such injuries, for whenever I do pottery I use the proper techniques that my instructor taught me.

Gardner, a noted paleontologist who has no vested interest in the case, assures us that the alleged dinosaur bones are not old enough to be from dinosaurs. So we should be skeptical of Penwick's claim to have found dinosaur bones, for Gardner inspected the bones carefully.

The engineer hired by the company that maintains the bridge has examined the bridge and declared it safe. This engineer is the only one who has given the bridge a close examination recently. Thus, we should consider the bridge safe.

The reporter who recently interviewed the prime minister said the prime minister appeared to be in poor health. But despite the fact that the reporter works for a paper with opposition leanings, we should accept that the prime minister is in poor health. After all, reporters won't let their bias affect them when the truth of their claims will eventually be discovered.
The snowblower salesperson claims that there will be above-average snowfall this winter, but because the salesperson is biased, we can discount that claim.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This conclusion doesn't resemble the claim that “we should be suspicious of person B's claim that X is not true.” This conclusion makes a prediction. It doesn't assert that we should be suspicious of a claim. Moreover, there's no “person B” in this argument. We can eliminate (A) without even evaluating the premises. (If we did evaluate this answer choice's premises, we'd also note that nothing parallels the passage's claims about a “thorough review” or person A's lack of bias.)

This one matches the generic version of our argument! We have a premise that parallels the claim that “Person A said X after a thorough review.” In this answer choice, that's the claim that “Gardner, a noted paleontologist ... assures us that the alleged dinosaur bones are not old enough to be from dinosaurs.” The argument also adds that “Gardner inspected the bones carefully” to parallel the “thorough review” part. We can also find a premise that parallels the claim that “person A has no bias in the matter”  — the assertion that Gardner “has no vested interest in this case.” Finally, the conclusion parallels “we should be suspicious of person B's claim that X is not true.” This conclusion asserts that “we should be skeptical of Penwick's claim to have found dinosaur bones.” This directly contradicts Gardner's claim, so it parallels the idea that “X is not true.” Therefore, (B) is correct.

This conclusion doesn't resemble the claim that “we should be suspicious of person B's claim that X is not true.” This conclusion asserts that a bridge is definitely safe. That's akin to saying “X is true,” which is slightly stronger than “we should be suspicious of person B's claim that X is not true.” That's enough reason to eliminate (C). But if you weren't convinced, you could analyze the premises. The premises don't have anything similar to the claim that “person A has no bias in the matter.” In fact, if the engineer was hired by the company that maintains the bridge, the engineer might have a bias! Moreover, there's no “person B” in this argument.

This conclusion doesn't resemble the claim that “we should be suspicious of person B's claim that X is not true.” This conclusion asserts that the prime minister is in poor health. That's akin to saying “X is true,” which is slightly stronger than “we should be suspicious of person B's claim that X is not true.” That's enough reason to eliminate (D). But if you need more reason to cross off (D), you could examine the premises. The premises don't have anything similar to the claim that “person A has no bias in the matter.” In fact, it says that the newspaper reporter might be biased (since they work for a paper with “opposition leanings”) but that their bias won't affect their claim about the prime minister's health. Finally, there's no “person B” in this argument.

This conclusion doesn't resemble the claim that “we should be suspicious of person B's claim that X is not true.” This conclusion asserts that we can “discount” the claim that there will be above-average snowfall this year. That's akin to saying “X is not true,” which is nearly the opposite of saying, “we should be suspicious of person B's claim that X is not true.” That's enough reason to eliminate (D). If we also evaluated the premises, we'd see that no premise matches the claim that “person A has no bias in the matter.” In fact, the argument asserts that the salesperson is biased. Also, there's no “person B” in this argument.

items.stimulusText: If the proposed air pollution measures were to be implemented, ozone levels in the city's air would be one fifth lower than current levels. Since the ozone in our air is currently responsible for over $5 billion in health costs, we would spend about a billion dollars less on these ozone-related health costs should the proposed measures be adopted.
items.stemText: The argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it

options.optionContent: fails to consider the possibility that other types of pollution not involving ozone might rise, perhaps even producing an overall increase in health costs
presumes, without providing evidence, that ozone-related health costs in the city vary roughly in proportion to ozone levels
provides no explicit reason for believing that the proposed air pollution measures will in fact be adopted
attempts to support its conclusion by making an appeal to emotions
discusses air pollution in order to draw attention away from more significant sources of health-related costs

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: When we see “fails to consider” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the author's argument if true?” This answer choice wouldn't weaken the argument's conclusion. The argument's conclusion doesn't consider “other types of pollution not involving ozone.” Notice that the conclusion only applies to “ozone-related health costs.” So, it doesn't matter if other types of pollution increase health costs. That wouldn't change whether the air pollution measures reduce the “ozone-related health costs.”

When we see “presumes, without providing justification” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, the author definitely believes that ozone-related health costs vary roughly in proportion to ozone levels. This is how the author gets from the premise that air pollution measures will reduce ozone levels by one-fifth to the conclusion that the measures will reduce the $5 billion worth of ozone-related costs by $1 billion. Moreover, this belief would strengthen the author's argument. If the costs vary in proportion to ozone levels, reducing the levels by one-fifth will also reduce the costs by one-fifth. So, this answer choice describes the author's potentially erroneous assumption, making this the correct answer.

The author doesn't have to provide a reason to believe that the city will adop air pollution measure. They would have to provide such a reason if the author concluded that the city will definitely spend one billion dollars less on ozone-related health costs. But the author instead concludes that the city will spend one billion dollars less “should the proposed measures be adopted.” Since the conclusion is conditioned on this hypothetical, the author doesn't have to show that the hypothetical will definitely happen. In other words, if the conclusion is “If X, then Y,” the argument doesn't have to prove that X will happen.

The author never makes an emotional appeal. Emotional appeals are very rare on the LSAT. When they do appear, the author will typically conclude that we should or should not do something by invoking our fear or pity to distract us from the facts. In this case, an emotional appeal might look something like, “Even though there's no proof that the proposed air pollution measures will reduce ozone levels, we should adopt the measures. The current ozone levels disproportionally affect the city's most vulnerable citizens, and any increase in the ozone levels may prove lethal to these individuals whom our government has let down.” The author doesn't do anything like that here. The author sticks to the facts about ozone levels but draws a dubious conclusion about ozone costs.

The author doesn't want to “draw attention away” from health-related costs. Their conclusion is about health-related costs! Besides, the two issues are related, as air pollution is responsible for the costs.

items.stimulusText: Newspaper article: Recently discovered clay tablets from southern Egypt date to between 3300 and 3200 B.C. Though most of the tablets translated thus far are tax records, one of them appears to contain literary writing. Hence, these tablets challenge the widely held belief among historians that the Sumerian civilization in Mesopotamia was the first to create literature.
items.stemText: The argument in the newspaper article requires the assumption that

options.optionContent: most of the recently discovered tablets that have not yet been translated contain literary writing
every civilization that has kept tax records has also kept other written records
historians generally believe that the Sumerians did not create literature earlier than 3300 B.C.
some historians are skeptical about the authenticity of the recently discovered tablets
the Sumerian civilization arose sometime between 3300 and 3200 B.C.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't strengthen the argument. It isn't necessary for the argument, either. It doesn't strengthen the argument because it doesn't tell us when the Sumerians created literature. It just tells us that the Egyptians may have created a lot of literature. But if all this literature came after the Sumerian literature, we can't convincingly argue that the Egyptian tablets challenge historians' belief that the Sumerians were the first to create literature. This also isn't necessary to the argument because we only need one example of Egyptian literature to show that the Egyptians may have created literature before the Sumerians. We don't need a lot of examples, so this answer choice isn't needed to draw the newspaper's conclusion. Finally, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “We found some Egyptian clay tablets from 3300-3200 B.C. Some clay tablets appear to have literary writing. But, it's not true that most of the recently discovered tablets that have not yet been translated contain literary writing. So, the Sumerians may have been the first to create literature.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. There's still a big gap between the premises  — which are all about the Egyptian tablets  — and the conclusion about Sumerians. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (A).

This doesn't strengthen the argument. It isn't necessary for the argument, either. It doesn't strengthen the argument because it doesn't tell us when the Sumerians created literature. It doesn't even tell us that the Egyptians created literature. It just tells a civilization that keeps tax records keeps other kinds of written records, too. But “other kinds of written records” doesn't mean that the country makes literature.  This also isn't necessary to the argument because the newspaper article only needs to establish that Egyptians and Sumerians created literature. We don't need to know about “every civilization that has kept tax records.” This provides information about far more civilizations than just the Egyptian and Sumerian civilization, so this answer choice isn't needed to draw the newspaper's conclusion. Finally, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “We found some Egyptian clay tablets from 3300-3200 B.C. Some clay tablets appear to have literary writing. But, it's not true that every civilization that has kept tax records has also kept other written records. So, the Sumerians may have been the first to create literature.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. There's still a big gap between the premises  — which about Egyptian tablets and civilizations that keep tax records  — and the conclusion about Sumerian literature. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (B).

This answer choice strengthens the argument by telling us that Sumerians didn't create literature older than these Egyptian tablets. These Egyptian tablets were created sometime between 3300 and 3200 B.C. So, this answer choice establishes that historians don't believe that Sumerian literature is older than the Egyptian tablets. This makes us more confident that the Sumerians may not have been the first to create literature. We also need to know this to draw the conclusion that the Sumerians may not have been the first to create literature. If the Sumerian literature was older than the Egyptian tablets, then we could not confidently claim that the Sumerians may not have been the first to create literature. We can also evaluate this answer choice using the backup plan. Here's the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified the answer choice to make this easier to read): “We found some Egyptian clay tablets from 3300-3200 B.C. Some clay tablets appear to have literary writing. But, the Sumerians created literature before 3300 B.C. So, the Sumerians may have been the first to create literature.” This makes sense. Yes, we found old Egyptian clay tablets that may contain literature, but we know that Sumerians created literature older than these tablets. So, the Sumerians were probably the first to create literature, at least as far as we know. Therefore, no matter which approach we used, we can be confident that (C) is the correct answer.

This doesn't strengthen the argument. It isn't necessary for the argument, either. It doesn't strengthen the argument because it doesn't tell us when the Sumerians created literature. In fact, it weakens the argument by calling its evidence into question. If we don't think these tablets are genuine, then we don't have good evidence to challenge the historians' belief that Sumerians were the first to create literature. Further, anything that weakens the argument won't be necessary to the argument, either. Additionally, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “We found some Egyptian clay tablets from 3300-3200 B.C. Some clay tablets appear to have literary writing. But, it's not true that some historians are skeptical about the authenticity of the recently discovered tablets. So, the Sumerians may have been the first to create literature.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. There's still a big gap between the premises  — which about Egyptian tablets  — and the conclusion about Sumerian literature. Plus, what follows the “But” seems consistent with the premises that came before it, making the paragraph sound awkward. No matter which approach we used, we can confidently cross off (D).

This answer choice strengthens the argument. If the Sumerian civilization rose between 3300 and 3200 B.C., then it almost certainly didn't create literature that's older than the supposed literary writing on the Egyptian tablets. For this reason, some test-takers believe (E) is the correct answer. However, this answer choice isn't needed to draw the newspaper's conclusion. Even if the Sumerian civilization arose before 3300 B.C., it still could have created literature after the Egyptians. Perhaps the Sumerian civilization arose before 3400 B.C. but created literature in 3100 B.C. In that case, we could still conclude that the Sumerians may not have been the first to create literature. Finally, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan: “We found some Egyptian clay tablets from 3300-3200 B.C. Some clay tablets appear to have literary writing. But, it's not true that the Sumerian civilization arose sometime between 3300 and 3200 B.C. So, the Sumerians may have been the first to create literature.” This doesn't sound like a valid argument. There's still a gap between the last premise — which tells us when the Sumerian civilization was formed — and the conclusion  — which tells us when the Sumerian civilization created literature. The Sumerian civilization could arose before 3300 B.C. and created literature older than the literary writing found on the Egyptian tablets. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (E).

items.stimulusText: Climatologist: The waters off the Pacific coast of North America have warmed about 4 degrees over the past 15 years. Some scientists claim that this trend is a symptom of a more general, global warming caused by human-generated air pollution. However, this conclusion is far from justified—it is known that there are many natural cycles of ocean temperature changes that last 60 years or more.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion drawn in the climatologist's argument?

options.optionContent: Some scientists have found evidence that the waters off the Pacific coast of North America have grown significantly warmer over the past 15 years.
The warming of the waters off the Pacific coast of North America is not a symptom of a more general, global warming caused by human-generated air pollution.
The conclusion that the warming of the waters off the Pacific coast of North America is a symptom of a more general, global warming caused by human-generated air pollution is far from justified.
The warming of the waters off the Pacific coast of North America may be the result of a natural cycle of ocean temperature changes.

If the warming of the waters off the Pacific coast of North America is due to a natural cycle of ocean temperature changes, then it is not a symptom of a more general, global warming caused by human-generated air pollution.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This omits the climatologist's belief that the scientists' conclusion near these warming waters is “far from justified.” While this answer choice is true, it doesn't capture the climatologist's main point.

This is tempting, but it's stated with more bold language than the climatologist's conclusion. The climatologist concludes that the scientists' conclusion is “far from justified.” That means the climatologist thinks the scientists didn't provide enough evidence to prove that the 4-degree increase in water temp is a symptom of global warming. So, we can only conclude that the climatologist believes that the 4-degree increase might not be a symptom of global warming. We can't say that the climatologist believes that the 4-degree increase is definitely not a symptom of global warming. Arguing that a conclusion isn't justified isn't the same as arguing that a conclusion is false.

It captures the climatologist's belief that the scientists' conclusion — that the 4-degree increase in Pacific water temp is a symptom of global warming  — is “far from justified.” The climatologist supports this belief by referencing an alternative explanation  — natural cycles that can change ocean temperatures. This answer choice captures the main idea the climatologist wants to convince us of, so we can select (C) and move on to the next question.

This is tempting, but it reflects a premise the climatologist relies on, not the climatologist's main conclusion. The climatologist concludes that the scientists' conclusion is “far from justified.” That means the climatologist thinks the scientists didn't provide enough evidence to prove that the 4-degree increase in water temp is a symptom of global warming. The climatologist supports this conclusion by referencing an alternative explanation  — natural cycles that can change ocean temperatures. So, the climatologist uses the premise that the increased water temps may be caused by a natural cycle of ocean temperature changes to support the conclusion that the scientists' conclusion isn't justified.

This does not express a claim the climatologist necessarily believes. This claim implies that the warmer Pacific temps cannot caused by natural cycles and global warming. The climatologist never says or implies that. The climatologist only says that the scientists' conclusion that the warmer temps are caused by global warming isn't justified. The climatologist supports this conclusion by referencing an alternative explanation  — natural cycles that can change ocean temperatures. Even though the climatologist references an alternative explanation, that doesn't mean the climatologist thinks the two explanations are mutually exclusive. The climatologist could argue that, in some cases, a temperature increase could be caused by natural cycles but compounded by global warming.

items.stimulusText:
Robin: Archaeologists can study the artifacts left by ancient cultures to determine whether they were nomadic or sedentary. If the artifacts were made to last rather than to be quickly discarded, the culture was likely sedentary.

Kendall: But what artifacts a people make is determined largely by the materials available to them.
items.stemText: Their statements commit Robin and Kendall to disagreeing over whether

options.optionContent: the distinction that Robin makes between two kinds of cultures is illicit
it is reasonable to assume that a culture whose artifacts were not durable was nomadic
any evidence other than the intended durability of a culture's artifacts can establish conclusively which of the two kinds of cultures a particular culture was
the distinction that Robin makes between the different kinds of cultures is as important as many archaeologists have thought
studying a culture's artifacts can reveal a great deal about the culture

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Robin would obviously disagree that the distinction made between nomadic and sedentary cultures is “illicit.” But we don't know whether Kendall would agree that it's erroneous to classify an ancient culture as “nomadic” or “sedentary.” Kendall may think these two classifications are completely acceptable. All we know is that Kendall doesn't think we can infer whether an ancient culture is nomadic or sedentary from the durability of its artifacts. Since we don't know Kendall's opinion on (A), we can eliminate it.

This is close to our anticipation that the correct answer will discuss whether we can infer that an ancient culture was sedentary or nomadic from the durability of its artifacts. Therefore, we can be confident that this answer choice is correct. After all, Robin would agree with this claim. Robin says that we can determine whether ancient cultures were nomadic or sedentary from the durability of their artifacts. Robin says that if the artifacts are durable rather than temporary, then the culture was probably sedentary. Since Robin argues that we can determine whether ancient cultures were sedentary or nomadic, we can infer that Robin would agree that if the artifacts are temporary rather than durable, then the culture was probably nomadic. Kendall points out that the artifacts were largely influenced by which materials were available. So, Kendall doesn't think we can determine whether an ancient culture was nomadic or sedentary from their artifacts. A culture with short-lived artifacts may have just been surrounded by flimsy materials. Therefore, Kendall would disagree with this claim. Since Robin would agree with (B) and Kendall would disagree with it, we can select (B) and advance to the following question.

Neither Robin nor Kendall addresses if we can determine whether a culture was nomadic or sedentary from “evidence other than the intended durability” of its artifacts. Both limit their arguments to the durability of the culture's artifacts. So, we don't know whether Robin or Kendall would agree with this claim. We can eliminate it.

Neither Robin nor Kendall addresses if the distinction between nomadic and sedentary cultures is “as important as many archaeologists thought.” Neither speaker addresses what other archaeologists think. Since we don't know whether Robin or Kendall would agree with this claim, we can cross (D) off.

Robin might agree with this claim since Robin argues that we can determine whether ancient cultures were nomadic or sedentary from the durability of its artifacts. Still, we don't know whether Robin thinks this information tells us “a great deal” about that culture. We don't know whether Kendall would agree with this claim. Kendall doesn't think the durability of the artifacts tells us whether cultures were nomadic or sedentary. But perhaps Kendall believes we can learn other information about the culture from the artifacts. Because we can't infer Kendall's opinion on (E), we can eliminate it.

items.stimulusText: Railroads rely increasingly on automation. Since fewer railroad workers are needed, operating costs have been reduced. This means that we can expect the volume of freight shipped by rail to grow. The chief competitor of railway shipping is shipping by truck, and no reduction in operating costs is predicted for the trucking industry.
items.stemText: Which one of the following most accurately states the argument's overall conclusion?

options.optionContent: The volume of freight shipped by rail can be expected to increase.
Increasing reliance on automation means that fewer railroad workers are needed.
No reduction in operating costs is predicted for the trucking industry.
Operating costs for railroads have been reduced as a result of increased reliance on automation.
The chief competitor of railway shipping is shipping by truck.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: It captures the author's belief that “we can expect the volume of freight shipped by rail to grow.” The author supports this belief, showing that railroads have reduced their operating costs through automation while their main competitor has not. So, this answer choice captures the main idea the author wants to convince us of. We can select (A) and move on to the next question.

This answer choice describes two of the author's premises. It's true that reliance on automation means that fewer railroad workers are needed. However, the author uses this fact to support their prediction that the amount of stuff shipped by rail will probably increase. The author claims that the need for fewer railroad workers will reduce railroad operating costs, which makes it more likely that more people will ship cargo by rail  — especially because railroads' main competitor will probably not reduce its operating costs.

This answer choice describes one of the author's premises. It's true that the trucking industry will probably not reduce its operating costs. However, the author uses this fact to support their prediction that the amount of stuff shipped by rail will probably increase. The author says that railroad operating costs will go down. So, if railroads' main competitor will probably not reduce its operating costs, railroads will have a competitive advantage over the trucking industry. Railroads can offer cheaper shipping; presumably, more people will ship by rail.

This is tempting, since it describes one the author's conclusions. However, this describes a premise/conclusion, not the author's main conclusion. The claim that railroads' operating costs have been reduced is supported by the premise that railroads' use of automation means that fewer railroad workers are needed. However, this claim supports the author's main conclusion that we can expect that more stuff will be shipped by rail. If railroads' operating costs are reduced, more people will probably ship cargo by rail  — especially if railroads' main competitor does not reduce its operating costs.

This answer choice describes one of the author's premises. The trucking industry is indeed railway shipping's chief competitor. However, the author uses this fact to support their prediction that the amount of stuff shipped by rail will probably increase. The author says that railroad operating costs will go down. So, if railroads' main competitor will probably not reduce its operating costs, railroads will have an edge over the trucking industry. Railroads can offer cheaper shipping, so more people will probably ship by rail.

items.stimulusText: In the past, infants who were not breast-fed were fed cow's milk. Then doctors began advising that cow's milk fed to infants should be boiled, as the boiling would sterilize the milk and prevent gastrointestinal infections potentially fatal to infants. Once this advice was widely implemented, there was an alarming increase among infants in the incidence of scurvy, caused by vitamin C deficiency. Breast-fed infants, however, did not contract scurvy.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?

options.optionContent: Boiled cow's milk makes less vitamin C available to infants than does the same amount of mother's milk.
Infants who consume cow's milk that has not been boiled frequently contract potentially fatal gastrointestinal infections.
Mother's milk can cause gastrointestinal infections in infants.
When doctors advised that cow's milk fed to infants should be boiled, they did not know that scurvy was caused by vitamin C deficiency.
When doctors advised that cow's milk fed to infants should be boiled, most mothers did not breast-feed their infants.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This inference must be true!
