Boiled cow's milk must contain less vitamin C (or, at least, provide less vitamin C to infants, as this answer choice states) than breast milk (AKA mother's milk). We know that the infants who got scurvy were fed boiled cow's milk. And we know that the scurvy was caused by vitamin C deficiency. If the kids who consumed breast milk didn't get scurvy, they were not vitamin C deficient. So, the breast milk must have provided more vitamin C to these tots. That would mean the kids who drank boiled cow's milk did not consume as much vitamin C. Because we can point to its support in the passage, we can justifiably select (A) and moooove on.

This inference is tempting because we know that doctors advised boiling because it would “prevent gastrointestinal infections potentially fatal to infants.” Many test-takers believe that it must be true that infants who consume unboiled cow's milk would frequently contract these gastrointestinal infections. However, this inference is not supported by the text. First, we don't know that the doctors were correct that boiling cow's milk reduces the risk of gastrointestinal infections. Perhaps if we knew that there was a dramatic decrease in gastrointestinal infections among infants once most people began boiling their cow's milk, we could infer that the doctors' recommendation was sound. But the passage doesn't provide that information. Moreover, even if people weren't boiling their cow's milk before the doctors made their recommendation, maybe they did something else that reduced the risk of gastrointestinal infection. Finally, even if infants who consumed unboiled cow's milk were at risk of gastrointestinal infection, we don't know that they “frequently” contracted these infections. Perhaps these infections were very rare.

This inference is not supported. According to doctors, unboiled cow's milk can cause gastrointestinal infections in infants. But we weren't told whether breast milk (AKA mother's milk) poses the same risk. We also don't have any data on gastrointestinal infections among infants fed breast milk, so we can't infer that this claim is true.

This inference is not supported. Presumably, if the doctors knew that boiling cow's milk reduces the vitamin C levels in cow's milk and that scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency, they probably wouldn't have recommended boiling cow's milk. (Even then, they may have made the recommendation. They could have figured that the risk of gastrointestinal disease was more dangerous than scurvy. But let's ignore that possibility for now.) Since they made the recommendation, they either did not know that boiling cow's milk reduces its vitamin C levels or they did not know that scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency. So, it's entirely possible that the doctors knew that scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency, but they didn't know that boiling cow's milk reduces its vitamin C levels.

This inference isn't supported. We have no idea what proportion of mothers breast fed their infants. We could make this inference if we learned that “most infants” contracted scurvy, but breast-fed infants did not contract scurvy. However, the passage does not supply that information.

items.stimulusText: The only effective check on grass and brush fires is rain. If the level of rainfall is below normal for an extended period of time, then there are many more such fires. Yet grass and brush fires cause less financial damage overall during long periods of severe drought than during periods of relatively normal rainfall.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would most help to resolve the apparent paradox described above?

options.optionContent: Fire departments tend to receive less funding during periods of severe drought than during periods of normal rainfall.
Areas subject to grass and brush fires tend to be less densely populated than areas where there are few such fires.
Unusually large, hard-to-control grass and brush fires typically occur only when there is a large amount of vegetation for them to consume.
Grass and brush fires that are not caused by human negligence or arson tend to be started by lightning.
When vegetation is destroyed in a grass or brush fire, it tends to be replaced naturally by vegetation that is equally if not more flammable.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This makes the paradox worse! If fire departments receive less funding during a drought, they're probably less equipped to contain the fires  — especially if there are many more fires than usual. We'd expect these fires to spread and cause more financial damage, not less financial damage.

This fact doesn't resolve the paradox because it doesn't tell us about areas experiencing a severe and protracted drought. Remember, the drought conditions are at the heart of this paradox. If this answer choice told us that areas experiencing an extended drought are less densely populated than areas experiencing normal rainfall, it might resolve the paradox. Fewer people would probably mean less property, and less property would probably mean less financial damage. But because this answer choice doesn't tell us anything about places during a prolonged drought, it does not affect the paradox.

As expected, this shows why extended periods of drought could produce more grass and brush fires but less financial damage. If grass and brush fires become uncontrollably large only when there's a lot of vegetation, we wouldn't expect grass and brush fires to cause a lot of damage during extended periods of drought. Common sense tells us there would not be much vegetation during an extended period of drought. So, during a prolonged drought, grass and brush fires wouldn't become uncontrollably large. Common sense also tells us that if these fires aren't uncontrollably large, they probably won't cause as much financial damage. (Yes, we're relying on common sense and outside knowledge, but that's OK on the LSAT  — even if you may have heard otherwise. In fact, Paradox questions are basically impossible to answer if you dogmatically follow the bad advice to “not rely on outside information.”) So, (C) resolves the paradox at hand, making it the correct answer.

This doesn't affect the paradox. It doesn't matter what causes the grass or brush fires. We're just trying to figure out why the fires are more frequent but less damaging during periods of extended drought. Since this answer choice doesn't tell us why fires may be less damaging during these periods, it's incorrect.

This doesn't resolve the paradox. In fact, it might make the paradox worse. If there are more fires during periods of severe drought, the continuously destroyed vegetation would be replaced with progressively more flammable vegetation. With more flammable vegetation, we'd expect to see bigger, more damaging fires during periods of extended drought.

items.stimulusText: Medical researcher: A new screening test detects certain polyps at such an early stage that it is generally unclear whether the polyps are malignant. But the risk that a polyp might be malignant leads doctors, in most cases, to have such polyps surgically removed, which is a dangerous process. Yet some of those polyps turn out not to be malignant. Thus, the new screening test can prompt dangerous operations that actually are not medically necessary.
items.stemText: Which one of the following is an assumption that the medical researcher's argument requires?

options.optionContent: A surgical operation that is dangerous is ethically justified only for treating a medical condition that is more dangerous.
Surgical removal of nonmalignant polyps detected by the new screening test is not always medically necessary.
If the new screening test encourages medically unnecessary operations, then probably it either should not be used or its use should be modified.
A polyp detected by the new screening test should be surgically removed if it is malignant.
The screening test is medically useful only when it detects a polyp that requires treatment.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't strengthen the argument. So, it isn't necessary for the argument, either. To get a better sense of why this answer choice doesn't strengthen the argument, let's take the flipside of it. We'll translate it to, “If a dangerous surgical operation does not treat a more dangerous medical condition, the operation is not medically justified.” This doesn't strengthen the argument because we don't know whether the procedure to remove a polyp is more dangerous than the malignant polyp itself. If a premise established that it was, this answer choice would strengthen this argument. But without this key piece of information, we can't say that this would strengthen the argument. And without knowing whether removing polyps poses a greater danger than a malignant polyp, this information isn't necessary, either. Finally, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we used the “if-then” translation of the answer choice and negated that statement): “Doctors can now detect polyps before they know whether the polyps are malignant. Doctors tend to remove these polyps. Removing polyps is dangerous. Some removed polyps are not dangerous. But, even if a dangerous surgical operation does not treat a more dangerous medical condition, the operation can still be medically justified. So, these dangerous operations may be medically necessary.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. We don't have any premises about a “more dangerous medical condition” or a “more dangerous medical operation,” so it's unclear how the “But” statement undermines what comes before it. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (A).

This answer choice strengthens the argument by telling us removing nonmalignant polyps is not always medically necessary. So, this answer choice establishes that some doctors perform dangerous but medically unnecessary operations when they remove nonmalignant tumors. This strengthens the researcher's argument, making us more confident that this new screening test prompts dangerous but medically unnecessary operations. We also need this information to conclude that the new screening test prompts dangerous but medically unnecessary operations. If removing nonmalignant polyps was always medically necessary, we'd have no evidence that doctors perform dangerous but medically unnecessary operations. So, we need to know that some of these operations on nonmalignant polyps are not medically necessary. We can also evaluate this answer choice using the backup plan. Here's the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified and negated this answer choice to make the argument easier to read): “Doctors can now detect polyps before they know whether the polyps are malignant. Doctors tend to remove these polyps. Removing polyps is dangerous. Some removed polyps are not dangerous. But removing nonmalignant polyps is always medically necessary. So, these dangerous operations may be medically necessary.” This makes sense! Yes, we're removing nonmalignant polyps in a dangerous operation. But removing such polyps is medically necessary, so these dangerous operations might be medically necessary. That adds up and sounds like a cogent paragraph. Therefore, no matter which approach we used, we can be confident that (B) is the correct answer.

This doesn't strengthen the argument. That means it isn't necessary for the argument, either. This doesn't strengthen the argument because the argument doesn't conclude that we should not use the new polyp screening test or that we should change the test. So, the “then” part of this answer choice is irrelevant to the conclusion. Plus, we don't know that these new screening tests encourage “medically unnecessary operations.” The researcher concludes that these operations are medically unnecessary. But this conclusion is flawed. The premises didn't tell us which kinds of operations are not medically necessary. Since we don't know whether these tests are medically unnecessary this answer choice might not even apply to the argument. Put another way, when an argument in a Strengthen or Weaken question concludes “X,” the correct answer won't begin with “If X.” The argument didn't prove that “X” is true, so the claim that begins “if X” is true won't add anything to the argument. Finally, this is the argument we'd make if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified and negated the answer choice to make the argument easier to read): “Doctors can now detect polyps before they know whether the polyps are malignant. Doctors tend to remove these polyps. Removing polyps is dangerous. Some removed polyps are not dangerous. But, even if a new screening test encourages medically unnecessary operations, we can still use the test and not modify it. So, these dangerous operations may be medically necessary.” This doesn't make a lot of sense. The part about modifying or not using the test doesn't relate to anything that came before it, so it's unclear how the “But” statement contradicts the previous premises. And the “But” statement discusses medically unnecessary operations, so it doesn't provide good support to a conclusion about medically necessary operations. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (C).

This doesn't strengthen the argument. That means it isn't necessary for the argument, either. This doesn't strengthen the argument because the argument isn't about removing malignant tumors. The argument is only concerned with whether removing nonmalignant tutors is medically unnecessary. Whether doctors should remove malignant tumors doesn't help us establish that removing nonmalignant tumors is medically unnecessary. Alternatively, if we used the backup plan, this is the argument we'd make (note that we simplified and negated the answer choice to make the argument easier to read): “Doctors can now detect polyps before they know whether the polyps are malignant. Doctors tend to remove these polyps. Removing polyps is dangerous. Some removed polyps are not dangerous. But, even if a malignant polyp is detected, it should not necessarily be surgically removed. So, these dangerous operations may be medically necessary.” This doesn't make any sense. The “But” statement is about malignant polyps, not nonmalignant polyps. Plus, if that statement suggests that we don't have to remove all malignant polyps, that might weaken the conclusion removing nonmalignant polyps may be medically necessary. This argument is a real stinker. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (D).

This doesn't strengthen the argument. That means it isn't necessary for the argument, either. To get a better sense of why this answer choice doesn't strengthen the argument, let's take the flipside of this statement. We'll translate it to, “If a screening test does not detect a polyp that requires treatment, then the screening test is not medically useful.” This doesn't strengthen the argument because the conclusion doesn't assert that the screening test is not medically useful. The conclusion asserts that the operation is not medically necessary. These are two different concepts. Even if the test isn't medically useful, the operation the test prompts might be medically necessary. Alternatively, if we used the backup plan, this is the argument we could construct (note that we used the “if-then” translation of the answer choice and negated it to make the argument easier to read): “Doctors can now detect polyps before they know whether the polyps are malignant. Doctors tend to remove these polyps. Removing polyps is dangerous. Some removed polyps are not dangerous. But, even if a screening test does not detect a polyp that requires treatment, then the screening test can still be medically useful. So, these dangerous operations may be medically necessary.” This doesn't make any sense. The “But” statement suggests that the screening test for polyps may be medically useful. But that doesn't mean the dangerous operations are necessary. The screening tests could be useful for other reasons. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently cross off (E).

items.stimulusText: Psychologist: Most people's blood pressure rises when they talk. But extroverted people experience milder surges when they speak than do introverted people, for whom speaking is more stressful. This suggests that the increases result from the psychological stress of communicating rather than from the physical exertion of speech production.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the psychologist's argument?

options.optionContent: Medications designed to lower blood pressure do not keep the people who take them from experiencing blood-pressure fluctuations when speaking.
In general, the lower one's typical blood pressure, the more one's blood pressure will increase under stress.
Introverted people who do not have chronically high blood pressure often sense the rises in blood pressure that occur when they speak in conversation.
Deaf people experience increased blood pressure when they sign, but no change when they move their hands for other reasons.
Extroverted people are more likely to have chronically high blood pressure than are introverted people and are more likely to take medication to lower their blood pressure.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't address the conclusion's claim that the increase in blood pressure is caused by the stress of speaking and not by the physical exertion required to speak. It just shows that medications do not completely eliminate the increase in blood pressure. If the answer choice said that people who take medications that lower stress do not experience blood pressure increases while speaking, it would be an example of “no cause, no effect” and would strengthen the argument. But this answer choice does not say that, so we can confidently eliminate it.

This answer choice is tempting to some because it affirms the relationship between stress and blood pressure increases. It suggests that stress increases blood pressure. However, that does not necessarily support the argument's conclusion that increased blood pressure while speaking results from the stress of speaking. Stress may increase one's blood pressure, but that doesn't mean people get stressed enough while speaking to have their blood pressure increase. This answer choice also doesn't strengthen the belief that increased blood pressure while speaking does not result from the physical exertion required to speak. Even if stress increases one's blood pressure, the physical act of speaking could increase one's blood pressure, too. So, this answer choice allows for the physical act of speaking to increase people's blood pressure. Finally, this answer choice states that there's a relationship between one's baseline blood pressure and the amount their blood pressure will increase. However, the argument doesn't compare people with low blood pressure to people with high blood pressure. It compares extroverts to introverts. So, the relationship this answer choice describes is not relevant to the researcher's argument.

It's understandable that many test-takers are attracted to this answer choice since it affirms a relationship between introverts and increased blood pressure that the researcher's argument discusses. In a way, this answer choice resembles “same cause, same effect.” However, there are a few issues with this answer choice. First, even if introverts “often sense” that their blood pressure increases while speaking, it doesn't necessarily mean that their blood pressure is actually increasing. And even if their blood pressure is increasing, that doesn't mean their blood pressure is increasing because they're stressed. Their blood pressure might rise from the physical act of speaking or for some other reason. Additionally, this answer choice discusses introverts “who do not have chronically high blood pressure.” But the researcher's argument doesn't compare people with chronically high blood pressure to those with average or below-average blood pressure. It compares extroverts to introverts. So, it's unclear why information about introverts who don't have chronically high blood pressure is relevant to the researcher's argument.

Many test-takers dismiss this answer choice out of hand, figuring that deaf people are irrelevant to the researcher's argument. But, before we do that, we should consider whether this argument presents one of the causal argument strengtheners we look for (elimination of an alternative cause; same cause, same effect; no cause, no effect). This tells us that deaf people experience increased blood pressure when they sign. Signing is how deaf people communicate, and we have no reason to believe that deaf people do not experience the same “psychological stress of communicating” that non-deaf people experience while speaking. So, if deaf people's blood pressure increases while experiencing the psychological stress of communicating, this answer choice presents an example of “same cause, same effect.” It affirms the relationship between the stress of communication and increased blood pressure. This answer choice also tells us that deaf people's blood pressure does not increase while moving their hands for other reasons. If a deaf person moves their hand for reasons other than signing, they're not experiencing the “psychological stress of communicating.” There's no stress and no corresponding increase in heart rate. Therefore, this answer choice also presents an example of “no cause, no effect.” If we take away the stress of communicating, we take away increased blood pressure. This last point is the most salient one. Remember, the researcher asserts that the physical exertion required to speak does not cause an increase in blood pressure. However, it would be difficult for the researcher to test that conclusion with people who communicate vocally. When these people speak, they will always feel the stress of communication and physically exert themselves. It would be hard for the researcher to isolate one of those variables with vocal communicators. But deaf people (or anyone else who communicates through non-vocal means) provide a way to isolate one of these variables. Deaf people do not experience the physical exertion required to speak. If their blood pressure still increases when they communicate, that suggests that the increase is due to the stress of communication and not the physical exertion required to speak. In a way, we can think of this answer choice as strengthening the researcher's anti-causal claim. In other words, the answer choice strengthens the argument by weakening the causal relationship between physical exertion and increased blood pressure. This answer choice provides an example of “effect without the cause”  — deaf people do not experience the physical exertion required to speak while communicating, but their blood pressure increases all the same.

This answer choice weakens the argument, as it provides an alternative reason why extroverts experience “milder surges” in their blood pressure while speaking. This answer choice suggests that these milder surges are not because extroverted people are less likely to feel stressed while communicating  — it could be because extroverts are more likely to be on medication that suppresses their blood pressure.

items.stimulusText: One should only buy a frying pan that has a manufacturer's warranty, even if it requires paying more, and even if one would never bother seeking reimbursement should the pan not work well or last long. Manufacturers will not offer a warranty on a product if doing so means that they will need to reimburse many customers because the product did not work well or last long.
items.stemText: The conclusion of the argument is strongly supported if which one of the following is assumed?

options.optionContent: Most people who buy a frying pan with a manufacturer's warranty would seek reimbursement should the pan fail to work well or last long.
All of the frying pans currently on the market that are covered by a manufacturer's warranty work at least as well at the time of purchase as any of the frying pans not covered by a warranty.
The more a frying pan costs, the more likely it is to be covered by a manufacturer's warranty.
The most expensive frying pans are the ones most likely to work well for many years.
Most frying pan manufacturers' warranties provide for full customer satisfaction.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This argument is flawed because it assumes that frying pan manufacturers would not offer a warranty on a bad frying pan. But there are some ways a manufacturer could offer a warranty on a bad frying pan. Perhaps the warranty is extremely limited (e.g., the warranty only lasts for two days), preventing most consumers from taking advantage of the warranty. Or, perhaps the manufacturer knows that most people are too lazy or busy or just don't care enough to take advantage of a frying pan warranty. In that case, the manufacturer wouldn't have to reimburse all the customers who aren't happy with their frying pan. This answer choice strengthens the argument by eliminating one way a manufacturer could offer a warranty on a bad frying pan. It shows that most people would actually take advantage of the warranty if they weren't happy with their frying pans. The frying pan manufacturer would actually have to reimburse all the unhappy customers who purchased a frying pan with a warranty. That supports the author's belief that a manufacturer would not offer a warranty on a bad frying pan. Offering a warranty on a bad frying pan would mean that the manufacturer would “need to reimburse many customers,” and we know manufacturers wouldn't offer a warranty if they had to do that. So, a frying pan warranty seems like evidence of the frying pan's quality. You could also select (A) using the backup plan. This is the argument we'd construct if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified the premise, conclusion, and answer choice to make the argument easier to read): “If manufacturers thought a warranty would mean they'd have to reimburse many customers, they would not offer the warranty. Plus, most people who buy a frying pan with a warranty would seek reimbursement if they weren't happy with the frying pan. So, one should only buy frying pans with a warranty.” This makes some sense. The first sentence suggests that if manufacturers thought they'd have to reimburse many unhappy customers, they wouldn't offer a warranty. The second sentence adds that frying pan manufacturers would have to reimburse their customers if the customers weren't happy with their frying pan. The two sentences together suggest that frying pan manufacturers probably wouldn't offer a warranty on a frying pan that wouldn't satisfy their customers, which supports the last sentence's recommendation. No matter our approach, we can confidently select (A).

This says that frying pans with warranties work as well or better than frying pans without warranties  — at the time of the purchase. This makes it sound like we may as well buy frying pans with warranties, right? A lot of test-makers think so. Unfortunately, this line of reasoning is incorrect. This answer choice doesn't tell us that frying pans with warranties will continue to work as well or better than frying pans without warranties. If frying pans without warranties last longer or perform better long-term, maybe we should buy those instead. Plus  — and this is the important takeaway point  — this answer choice doesn't address the argument's reasoning. It doesn't show how a manufacturer's warranty provides evidence that the manufacturer is willing to put its money where its proverbial mouth is to stand behind the quality. Instead, the answer choice just introduces a new fact that seems to directly support the conclusion (but, for the reason mentioned above, doesn't actually support the conclusion). The correct answers to some relatively easy Strengthen questions will add a new fact that directly supports the conclusion. But the correct answers on harder Strengthen questions  — the ones you might actually need our help on  — will almost never do that. Instead, the correct answer on harder Strengthen questions will address the argument's reasoning by fixing a problem with that reasoning. You could also eliminate (B) with the backup plan. This is the argument we'd construct if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified the premise, conclusion, and answer choice to make the argument easier to read): “If manufacturers thought a warranty would mean they'd have to reimburse many customers, they would not offer the warranty. Plus, frying pans with warranties work as well or better than frying pans without warranties at the time of purchase. So, one should only buy frying pans with a warranty.” This doesn't make a ton of sense. The claim that frying pans with warranties only work as well as warranty-less frying pans “at the time of purchase” does not provide strong evidence that warranties guarantee long-term quality. Plus, it doesn't relate to the first sentence's claim, which makes the argument sound disjointed and awkward. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently eliminate (B).

This is irrelevant to the argument. It doesn't show why a warranty would guarantee a quality frying pan. And we can't assume that a frying that costs more must be of higher quality. You could also eliminate (C) with the backup plan. This is the argument we'd construct if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified the premise, conclusion, and answer choice to make the argument easier to read): “If manufacturers thought a warranty would mean they'd have to reimburse many customers, they would not offer the warranty. Plus, the more a frying pan costs, the more likely it'll be covered by a warranty. So, one should only buy frying pans with a warranty.” This doesn't sound like a cogent argument. The second sentence makes it sound like a warranty will make a frying pan more expensive, which sounds like a reason we shouldn't buy frying pans covered by warranties. Plus, the second sentence doesn't relate to the first sentence's claim, which makes the argument sound disjointed and awkward. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently eliminate (C).

This is irrelevant to the argument. The argument didn't assert that we should buy the most expensive frying pans. It asserted that we should only buy frying pans with warranties. So, this answer choice doesn't show why a warranty would evidence a frying pan's quality. You could also eliminate (D) with the backup plan. This is the argument we'd construct if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified the premise, conclusion, and answer choice to make the argument easier to read): “If manufacturers thought a warranty would mean they'd have to reimburse many customers, they would not offer the warranty. Plus, the most expensive frying pans will work the best for many years. So, one should only buy frying pans with a warranty.” This doesn't sound very good. The second sentence has nothing to do with the first or third sentences. It sounds like a complete nonsequitur, so this doesn't sound like a cogent paragraph that makes a convincing argument. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently eliminate (D).

This says that frying pans warranties provide for “full customer satisfaction.” Does this strengthen the author's belief that warranties are a mark of the frying pan's quality? No. Even if the warranties cover “full customer satisfaction” (whatever that means), that still doesn't address the argument's central flaw. The author thinks that a warranty will guarantee some level of frying pan quality since manufacturers wouldn't offer a warranty if they thought they'd have to reimburse a bunch of unhappy customers. But we don't know whether unhappy customers will actually take advantage of the warranty and seek reimbursement. If we knew that frying pan customers never took advantage of warranties, we could put a bad frying pan on the market and write whatever we wanted in the warranty. We could say, “If you are not 100% satisfied with your frying pan, we will not only give you a full refund, we will give you full ownership of this frying pan company in perpetuity.” Our warranty wouldn't show that we are 100% confident in our frying pan's quality. Our warranty would only show that we are 100% confident that our customers won't take advantage of the warranty. (E) doesn't strengthen the argument because it doesn't address that central issue in the author's reasoning. You could also eliminate (E) with the backup plan. This is the argument we'd construct if we used the backup plan (note that we simplified the premise, conclusion, and answer choice to make the argument easier to read): “If manufacturers thought a warranty would mean they'd have to reimburse many customers, they would not offer the warranty. Plus, most frying pan manufacturers' warranties provide for full customer satisfaction. So, one should only buy frying pans with a warranty.” This doesn't sound terrible, but it doesn't sound as cogent or persuasive as the argument we'd construct with (A). The claim that warranties provide for “full customer satisfaction” doesn't address the first sentence's claim about the manufacturers' reasoning in offering a warranty. This makes the argument sound a little awkward. No matter which approach we use, we can confidently eliminate (E).

items.stimulusText: Journalist: When judges do not maintain strict control over their courtrooms, lawyers often try to influence jury verdicts by using inflammatory language and by badgering witnesses. These obstructive behaviors hinder the jury's effort to reach a correct verdict. Whenever lawyers engage in such behavior, therefore, it is reasonable to doubt whether the verdict is correct.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the journalist's argument?

options.optionContent: Court proceedings overseen by judges who are very strict in controlling lawyers' behavior are known to result sometimes in incorrect verdicts.
Lawyers tend to be less concerned than are judges about whether the outcomes of jury trials are just or not.
People who are influenced by inflammatory language are very unlikely to admit at some later time that they were influenced by such language.
Obstructive courtroom behavior by a lawyer is seldom effective in cases where jurors are also presented with legitimate evidence.
The selection of jurors is based in part on an assessment of the likelihood that they are free of bias.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This has no effect on the journalist's argument. The journalist's conclusion doesn't say or imply that the verdicts reached in cases where judges maintain close control over the courtroom are always reliable. The conclusion instead addresses verdicts in cases where lawyers use inflammatory language and badger witnesses, which sometimes occurs when judges don't control their courtrooms.

If lawyers are less concerned about the trustworthiness of verdits, they may be willing to engage in a level of obstructive behaviors that truly undermine the jury's effort to reach the correct verdict. Suppose lawyers are eager to use super inflammatory language and to really badger witnesses (instead of using these techniques sparingly to preserve the trustworthiness of the legal process). In that case, jurors will find it harder to reach valid conclusions. This gives us further reason to doubt jury verdicts when such techniques are used, slightly strengthening the journalists' argument.

This answer choice is irrelevant to the journalist's argument. It doesn't matter whether the jurors influenced by the inflammatory language will admit that they were influenced by it. They don't even have to be aware that they were influenced! To draw this conclusion, the journalist just has to establish that such language always influences jurors' decision-making enough to make their verdicts untrustworthy. (C) doesn't weaken the notion that inflammatory language always makes jurors' verdicts untrustworthy, so it is incorrect.

This definitely weakens the journalist's argument. It presents a counterexample to the conclusion's bold, universal claim: it shows a situation in which lawyers use inflammatory language and badger witnesses but do not meaningfully influence a jury's verdict. If “[o]bstructive courtroom behavior” like inflammatory language and witness badgering isn't effective in cases with legitimate witnesses, it's not necessarily true that it's reasonable to doubt verdicts “whenever lawyers engage in such behavior.” Therefore, (D) makes the journalist's conclusion less convincing, making it the correct answer.

This answer choice is irrelevant to the journalist's argument. The journalist doesn't argue that we can doubt juries' verdicts because the jurors are biased. The journalist argues that we doubt the verdicts because the jurors are susceptible to lawyers' inflammatory language and witness badgering. An unbiased juror can still be influenced by the lawyers' obstructive behavior.

items.stimulusText: Mateo: Global warming has caused permafrost to melt under several arctic villages, forcing all their inhabitants to relocate at great expense. Since pollution from automobiles is a major contributor to global warming, the automotive industry should be required to help pay for the villagers' relocation.
items.stemText: Which one of the following principles, if valid, would most help to justify Mateo's argument?

options.optionContent: Any industry has an obligation to pay for any damage that it should have known would result from its activities.
Manufacturers should be required to produce goods in a way that minimizes harm to people and the environment.
When the use of a product causes damage, governments should not be required to help pay for the damage unless those responsible for manufacturing the product are also required to help pay for them.
Any industry manufacturing a product whose use contributes to costly damage for others should be liable for any damage generated by that product's use.

An industry that contributes to global warming should be required to help pay for resulting damage to specific communities only if it has a general obligation to help pay for all damage produced by global warming.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This principle doesn't quite resemble “if premises, then conclusion.” It's hard to say that the automobile industry “should have known” that automobiles would contribute to global warming, eventually causing permafrost to melt under several arctic villages. Mateo doesn't state that automobile manufacturers should have known they'd cause this damage, either. So, this principle doesn't bridge the gap between Mateo's premises and conclusion.

This principle doesn't really resemble “if premises, then conclusion.” Mateo doesn't conclude that automobile manufacturers “should be required to produce” their cars in a way that “minimizes harm to people and the environment.” Mateo doesn't claim that the automobile industry should try to stop contributing to global warming in any way  — Mateo just wants the automobile industry to pay for the arctic villagers' relocation. Therefore, this principle doesn't bridge the gap between Mateo's premises and conclusion.

This principle doesn't resemble “if premises, then conclusion.” If we translate this, here's what it would look like: “if product causes damages and product manufacturers are not required to pay for damages, then government not required to pay for damages.” However, Mateo's argument doesn't touch on whether the government should be required to pay for the villagers' relocation. Mateo doesn't bring up the government at all! So, this principle doesn't bridge the gap between Mateo's premises and conclusion.

This principle resembles “if premises, then conclusion.” Here's what it looks like: “if manufacturer creates a product that causes costly damage, then manufacturer should be liable for the damage.” This connects Mateo's premises and conclusion. Mateo's premises establish that automobile manufacturers created a product that contributed to global warming, thus causing costly damages to others when global warming forced arctic villagers to relocate. Mateo concludes that automobile manufacturers should be forced to pay for this relocation, which is synonymous with the manufacturers being “liable” for the damages created by the product. So, this principle establishes that if Mateo's premises are true, we have to accept Mateo's conclusion. So this answer choice is correct!

This principle doesn't resemble “if premises, then conclusion.” If we translate this, here's what it would look like: “if industry contributes to global warming should pay for damage to communities, then industry has a general obligation to help pay for all global warming damage.” Experienced test-takers will immediately realize this answer choice is wrong because it places Mateo's conclusion on the “if” side of the “if-then” statement. Remember, we can only make conclusions about the “then” side. Moreover, Mateo's argument doesn't touch on whether the automobile industry has a “general obligation” to pay for global warming-related damages. Therefore, this principle doesn't bridge the gap between Mateo's premises and conclusion.

items.stimulusText: Lindsey: Several people claim that our company was unfair when it failed to give bonuses to the staff. Perhaps they recalled that the company had promised that if it increased its profits over last year's, the staff would all get bonuses. However, the company's profit was much smaller this year than it was last year. Clearly, then, the company acted fairly.
items.stemText: The argument is flawed in that it

options.optionContent: relies on the opinions of certain unnamed people without establishing that those people were well informed on the matter
infers that an opinion is false merely because one potential reason for that opinion has been undermined
dismisses a claim on the basis of certain irrelevant attributes of the people who made the claim
confuses the size of a quantity with the amount by which that quantity has increased
overlooks the possibility that a policy can be fair even when it is not generous

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: Lindsey doesn't rely on the opinions of certain unnamed people when making this argument. If Lindsey relied on the opinions of “several people,” Lindsey would have used their opinions to justify the conclusion. But Lindsey doesn't agree with their opinions. Several people think the company acted unfairly, but Lindsey doesn't think the company acted unfairly at all! More generally, it's only a flaw to rely on people's opinions without establishing that they're “well informed on the matter” if you're using their opinions to prove a factual matter (e.g., “John believes Coke is the most popular soft drink, so Coke must sell more soda annually than any other soft drink”) or when they're clearly speaking outside their area of expertise (e.g., “John is a doctor, so we can trust his opinions on pop music”). This conclusion doesn't express a factual matter, and we don't have a strong reason to believe these people are uninformed about the company's policies. After all, Lindsey concedes that these people might recall one of the company's policies! Clearly, they are at least somewhat informed on the matter at hand.

This answer choice describes the error in Lindsey's reasoning. Lindsey infers that an opinion is false  — several people's opinion that the company acted unfairly by refusing bonuses  — merely because Lindsey undermines one potential reason for that opinion  — the company's promise that it would give out bonuses if this year's profits were bigger than last year's. There could be other reasons the staff were entitled to bonuses! If the company denied bonuses despite those reasons, the company would have acted unfairly. Lindsey ignores any other reason the company's staff may have earned a bonus. Since (B) describes this flaw, we can select it confidently.

Lindsey doesn't dismiss several people's opinions based on their “irrelevant attributes.” Lindsey doesn't bring up any attributes these people possess! Because this answer choice mischaracterizes Lindsey's reasoning, it cannot accurately describe a flaw in Lindsey's argument.

This is a confusing answer choice! Sometimes, it's best to provide an example of what this flaw might look like so we can compare the passage's argument to an argument that actually commits the flaw described by this answer choice. Suppose the argument said this: “Lindsey: Several people claim that our company was unfair when it failed to give bonuses to the staff. Perhaps they recalled that the company had promised that if it increased its profits over last year's, the staff would all get bonuses. However, the company's profit wasfairly small this year. Clearly, then, the company acted fairly.” In this version of the argument, Lindsey confuses the size of a quantity (the company's profits) with the amount the quantity has increased (whether this year's profits increased over last year's). The company promised to give out bonuses if the annual profit increased this year. Even if this year's profits were “fairly small,” they still could have increased over last year's profits, and the staff could still be entitled to a bonus. However, in the real argument from the passage, Lindsey doesn't confuse the size of the company's profits with the amount the profits increased. Lindsey doesn't say that the profits were “small” this year. Lindsey establishes that the profits did not increase this year (“the company's profit was much smaller this year than it was last year”). So, this answer choice does not accurately describe an error in Lindsey's reasoning.

When we see “overlooks the possibility” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the conclusion if true?” If a policy can be fair even if it's not generous, that would strengthen Lindsey's reasoning. Denying bonuses to your staff isn't very generous, but this answer choice would support Lindsey's conclusion that the company's decision was fair. It's not a flaw to overlook information that further supports your argument!

items.stimulusText: It is widely known that the rescue squads serving high mountain areas with treacherous weather save the lives of many mountain climbers every year. However, many experienced climbers believe that the rising annual toll of deaths and injuries among climbers in these regions can be significantly reduced only by completely abolishing the rescue squads.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would most help to justify the apparently paradoxical belief of the experienced climbers?

options.optionContent: It is difficult to recruit and train members for the rescue squads.
The recording of deaths and injuries tends to be more accurate in mountain regions served by rescue squads.
People who commonly take risks with their lives and health do not expect other people to take those risks to rescue them.
Most of the people injured or killed while mountain climbing were not adequately prepared for the dangers they would face.
The lower the risk of climbing a particular mountain is perceived to be, the greater the number of less competent climbers who attempt to climb it.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is irrelevant to the paradox. It doesn't matter if it's difficult to recruit or train members of these rescue squads. Apparently, we still manage to recruit and train members, and they do a pretty good job saving climbers' lives. This answer choice doesn't explain why experienced climbers think we need to get rid of these squads to reduce the number of deaths and injuries on mountains.

This doesn't resolve the paradox. It doesn't explain why experienced climbers think we need to get rid of these squads to reduce the number of deaths and injuries on mountains. It may suggest that the statistics on deaths and injuries in areas without rescue squads are less reliable. But that doesn't show why rescue squads may cause an increase in the number of climber deaths and injuries. Some test-takers are still tempted by this answer choice. It's possible to argue that this answer choice resolves the paradox, but that requires at least a few assumptions. Suppose the statistics on deaths and injuries in areas without rescue squads dramatically undercount the number of deaths and injuries. And suppose that experienced mountain climbers are using these statistics to argue that removing rescue squads is required to reduce climber deaths and injuries. If both of these suppositions are true, then the paradox is resolved. The experienced climbers look at the statistics and see far fewer injuries and deaths in the areas without rescue squads. The experienced climbers then argue that we'd see fewer injuries and deaths elsewhere if the rescue squads stopped servicing those areas. Still, neither the passage nor the answer choices support these assumptions. The statistics on deaths and injuries in areas without rescue squads could actually overestimate the number of deaths and injuries in these areas. Experienced climbers don't have to base their opinions on these statistics. And the experienced climbers may not be this susceptible to flawed logic. Because this answer choice requires unsupported assumptions to resolve the paradox, it does not truly resolve the paradox.

This might explain why the experienced climbers don't would be OK climbing without rescue squads. The experienced climbers know they're taking a risk, and they don't expect rescue squad members to take a risk rescuing them. But that's not the issue we're trying to explain. We're trying to explain why experienced climbers think removing the rescue squads is required to reduce the number of climber deaths and injuries. This answer choice doesn't give us any reason to believe that the number of climber deaths and injuries would go down without rescue squads, so it is incorrect.

If most of the people who are killed or injured while mountain climbing weren't adequately prepared, it seems like they could use a rescue squad to help them out! This answer choice would resolve the paradox if it told us that climbers would prepare themselves more if they knew rescue squads wouldn't be there to support them. But, as written, this answer choice makes the paradox worse.

Finally, this answer choice resolves the paradox. If climbers know that rescue squads can save them if they get into a difficult situation on a mountain, they'll perceive the risk of that mountain as lower. This answer choice tells us that when mountain climbers perceive the risk as lower, more incompetent climbers will attempt to climb a mountain. This explains why experienced climbers think that reducing climber deaths and injuries requires abolishing rescue squads. If there are no more rescue squads, climbers will think that climbing a mountain poses a higher risk. If climbers perceive the risk as high, fewer incompetent climbers will attempt to climb a mountain. And if there are fewer incompetent climbers, we can reasonably expect fewer injuries and deaths on the mountains. Therefore, this answer choice is correct.

items.stimulusText:
Paula: Earthlike planets seem to be the rule rather than the exception, so there probably are intelligent beings on other planets. Furthermore, we can expect our radio telescopes to detect signs of such beings. Alien scientists would have basically the same understanding of mathematics and physics that humans have. Thus they would inevitably discover gravity, electromagnetism, and other fundamental physical phenomena and then develop technologies such as radio communication.

Ashley: That is like saying they would inevitably have the same legal or political systems that humans do. Our science, mathematics, and technology are unique outgrowths of our physiology, cognitive makeup, and environment. Using radio telescopes to search for intelligent life is a waste of time and money.
items.stemText: The dialogue provides the most evidence that Paula and Ashley disagree with each other about whether

options.optionContent: it is probable that there are intelligent alien beings who have developed radio communication
it is probable that there are intelligent alien beings who have the same legal or political systems that humans do
our technology is influenced by our cognitive makeup
there is likely to be intelligent life on other planets
scientists should spend more time and money on the search for intelligent extraterrestrial life

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: It does relate to Paula and Ashley's disagreement over whether aliens would develop the same technology we did. And it uses the weak, easy-to-support language (“probable,” “there are”) we like a Connecting Facts question. Paula says that aliens develop the same technologies we did, and they both agree that we've developed radio communication. However, Ashley says that our technology is unique to ourselves and our environment, implying that aliens would not develop similar technology. She underlines this point by arguing that using radio communication to search for aliens is a waste of time and money, suggesting that aliens won't have radios to communicate with us. It is correct. Paula would agree with this, while Ashley would disagree with it.

We know Ashley would disagree with this claim. However, Paula never discusses whether aliens would share our legal or political systems. The way Ashley poses this idea as absurd suggests no one believes that aliens would share our legal or political systems. Even then, Paula and Ashley wouldn't disagree with each other.

We know that Ashley agrees with this statement  — she says technology is a “unique outgrowth” of our cognitive makeup. Paula never explicitly discusses our cognitive makeup. Paula suggests that technology comes from our understanding of mathematics and physics. Even if that counts as coming from our “cognitive makeup,” Paula and Ashley's opinions would be aligned on this issue.

Paula definitely agrees with this. But Ashley never indicates whether she believes intelligent life exists on other planets. She doesn't say she believes in aliens, but she doesn't rule it out, either. She doesn't think aliens, if they exist, would share much in common with us or be traceable by radio communication.

Neither speaker has an opinion on this. Paula probably supports the amount of money we spend on radio telescopes. But she never says we should spend more money searching for aliens. And Ashley doesn't think radio telescopes are a good use of money, but she doesn't rule out spending more money to look for aliens some other way. Since neither speaker expresses or implies their opinion on this topic, we can eliminate (E).

items.stimulusText: Developer: The builders of the Glen Veil apartment complex will not complete the complex unless a road connecting it to the town of Sierra is built. The completed apartment complex would strengthen Sierra's economy, and a stronger economy would benefit every Sierra resident. Therefore, the residents of Sierra should vote in favor of a local tax to fund construction of the proposed road.
items.stemText: Which one of the following principles, if valid, would most help to justify the developer's reasoning?

options.optionContent: If a construction project is necessary in order to strengthen a town's economy, then the residents of that town should vote in favor of a local tax to fund that construction project.
The residents of a town should not vote in favor of a local tax to fund a construction project unless that construction project will produce results that benefit all of those residents.
Whenever a town funds a construction project, it should do so by means of a tax rather than debt.
Only those residents who will benefit from the results of a construction project should be required to pay a tax to fund that project.
Anyone who would benefit from the results of a construction project should vote in favor of a local tax to fund that project.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This is very tempting! But it slightly misstates the premise. According to the developer, constructing the road isn't necessary to strengthen the town's economy. Constructing the road is necessary to build the apartment building. And the apartment building would strengthen the town's economy. But that doesn't mean we need to build the road to improve the economy. There could be many ways to improve the economy outside the road and apartment complex! (If you're following this “if-then” logic, we have “if Apartment Complex then Road” and “if Apartment Complex then Improved Economy.” We cannot validly conclude that “if Improved Economy then Road,” as this answer choice states.) Since this answer choice mischaracterizes the developer's premise, it cannot connect the developer's premise to their conclusion.

This principle doesn't resemble “if Premises then Conclusion.” Here's what it does look like: “if Should vote to complete project then Project will benefit every resident.” Experienced test-takers will immediately recognize that this claim is backward (it goes “if Conclusion then Premise”). This won't help the developer prove that Sierra residents should vote to fund the road. (The flipside wouldn't help us either, as that is “if Project will not benefit every resident then Should not vote to complete project”  — this would only help us conclude that Sierra residents should not vote to fund the road.)

This principle doesn't resemble “if Premises then Conclusion.” It mischaracterizes the developer's premises and conclusion. Here's what it looks like: “if Fund a project, then Should use tax and not debt.” This principle could be used to make conclusions in situations where we know that a town will fund a project. In those cases, we could conclude that they should use a tax. But we don't know that Sierra will definitely fund a construction project. We need a principle that tells Sierra residents to vote to fund such a project! This principle doesn't compel Sierra residents to vote to fund a project, so it doesn't strengthen the developer's argument.

This principle doesn't resemble “if Premises then Conclusion.” Here's what it looks like: “if Resident required to vote to complete project, then Project benefits resident.” Experienced test-takers will immediately recognize that this claim is backward, more or less (it more closely resembles “if Conclusion then Premise” than “if Premises then Conclusion”). This won't help the developer prove that Sierra residents should vote to fund the road. This premise would only allow us to conclude that residents who were required to vote for the road will benefit from the road. But no premises establish that any of the Sierra residents are required to vote for the road. That's what the developer is trying to prove with the conclusion!

Finally, a principle that gives us “if Premises then Conclusion.” If we translate this, here's what it would look like: “if Project benefits resident, then Resident should vote to fund the project.” This strengthens the developer's argument. The road can benefit every Sierra resident because the road is required to complete the apartment complex, eventually benefiting the residents. So, this principle gets the closest to compelling every Sierra resident to vote to fund the road, just as the developer concludes. Since this principle gets the closest to connecting the developer's premises with the developer's conclusion, (E) is the correct answer.

items.stimulusText: Historian: Because medieval epistemology (theory of knowledge) is a complex subject, intellectual historians have, until recently, failed to produce a definition that would help to determine what should and what should not be included in it. Clearly, the solution is to define medieval epistemology simply as "the epistemological beliefs of the medieval epistemologists." That way, if we want to know whether medieval epistemology includes some epistemological claim, we just ask whether any medieval epistemologists believed it. If any did, it is part of medieval epistemology; if any medieval epistemologists believed the opposite, then that opposite claim is part of medieval epistemology.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would most weaken the historian's argument?

options.optionContent: Medieval epistemologists held some of the same epistemological beliefs as did ancient epistemologists.
The epistemological beliefs of medieval epistemologists depended upon their beliefs about nonepistemological matters.
The writings of most medieval epistemologists include passages that are clearly not about epistemology.
Some medieval epistemologists had epistemological beliefs that contradicted the epistemological beliefs of other medieval epistemologists.
There is much debate as to which medieval thinkers, if any, were epistemologists.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't affect the argument at all. Plus, it uses the weak, wishy-washy language (“some”) we don't like on Weaken questions. Statements expressed with this type of language usually do not meaningfully affect an argument, so answer choices expressed with such language are often wrong on Weaken (and Strengthen/Strengthen with a Sufficient Assumption!) questions. Further, it simply doesn't matter if medieval and ancient epistemologists shared some beliefs. This doesn't present a major downside to the historian's definition of “medieval epistemology.” This answer choice would mean that some beliefs held by ancient epistemologists would be included in “medieval epistemology.” But, the historian never says or implies that medieval epistemology cannot contain any beliefs held by ancient epistemologists. Finally, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Until recently, intellectual historians didn't have a definition of medieval epistemology. We can define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold. If we want to know whether medieval epistemology includes a belief, we'll ask whether any medieval epistemologists believe it. If they do, it's part of medieval epistemology. If any believe the opposite, the opposite claim is part of medieval epistemology. But, medieval and ancient epistemologists share some of the same epistemological beliefs. So, we maybe shouldn't define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold.” This argument doesn't sound very convincing. “Ancient epistemologists” pop up out of nowhere in the “But” statement, and it's unclear why they would present a reason why we “maybe shouldn't” use the historian's definition of medieval epistemology. Whichever approach we use, we can eliminate (A).

This answer choice doesn't affect the argument. It doesn't present a major downside to the historian's definition of “medieval epistemology.” It only suggests that medieval epistemologists' epistemological beliefs are influenced by non-epistemological matters. But, the historian never says or implies that non-epistemological beliefs cannot influence medieval epistemology. Moreover, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Until recently, intellectual historians didn't have a definition of medieval epistemology. We can define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold. If we want to know whether medieval epistemology includes a belief, we'll ask whether any medieval epistemologists believe it. If they do, it's part of medieval epistemology. If any believe the opposite, the opposite claim is part of medieval epistemology. But, medieval epistemologists' beliefs depended on their non-epistemological beliefs. So, we maybe shouldn't define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold.” This argument doesn't sound very persuasive. “Non-epistemological beliefs” show up without any rhyme or reason in the “But” statement. That statement doesn't seem to contradict or present a downside to anything that comes before it, so it's unclear why the “But” statement provides a reason why we “maybe shouldn't” use the historian's definition of medieval epistemology. Whichever approach we use, we can eliminate (B).

This answer choice is irrelevant to the argument. It doesn't matter that most medieval epistemologists also wrote about non-epistemological matters. We wouldn't use those writings to define medieval epistemology. So, (C) doesn't present a major downside to the historian's definition of “medieval epistemology.” Moreover, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Until recently, intellectual historians didn't have a definition of medieval epistemology. We can define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold. If we want to know whether medieval epistemology includes a belief, we'll ask whether any medieval epistemologists believe it. If they do, it's part of medieval epistemology. If any believe the opposite, the opposite claim is part of medieval epistemology. But, most medieval epistemologists sometimes wrote about non-epistemological matters. So, we maybe shouldn't define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold.” This argument doesn't sound very persuasive. The “But” statement doesn't sound like it undermines or presents a downside of the premises that come before it. So, it doesn't provide a reason why we “maybe shouldn't” use the historian's definition of medieval epistemology. Whichever approach we use, we can eliminate (C).

This answer choice is very tempting! If this answer choice were true, then medieval epistemology would contain some “contradictory” beliefs. If one medieval epistemologist thought we know things by experiencing them and another thought we don't know things by experiencing them, then medieval epistemology would hold that we simultaneously do and do not know things by experiencing them. That seems a little confusing! However, let's go back to fundamentals. This answer choice uses the weak, wishy-washy language (“some”) we don't like on Weaken questions. Statements expressed with this type of language usually do not meaningfully affect an argument, so answer choices expressed with such language are often wrong on Weaken (and Strengthen/Strengthen with a Sufficient Assumption!) questions. So, even if this answer choice seems to present a major downside to the historian's definition, its weak language suggests that the downside might not be so bad. If only “some” medieval epistemologists had views that contradicted other medieval epistemologists, medieval epistemology may not have that many contradictions. Maybe there's only like, one contradiction. That's not the end of the world. Especially because the historian concedes that medieval epistemology is a “complex” topic. And it's worth noting that the historian never said or implied that medieval epistemology couldn't contain contradictory views. Alternatively, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Until recently, intellectual historians didn't have a definition of medieval epistemology. We can define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold. If we want to know whether medieval epistemology includes a belief, we'll ask whether any medieval epistemologists believe it. “If they do, it's part of medieval epistemology. If any believe the opposite, the opposite claim is part of medieval epistemology. But, some medieval epistemologists had epistemological beliefs that contradicted those of other medieval epistemologists. So, we maybe shouldn't define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold.” This argument doesn't sound terrible! The “But” statement seemingly presents a downside of the previous claim. It shows that sometimes contradictory claims will become part of medieval epistemology. However, it's only a “some” statement. Saying that a definition “sometimes” produces confusing results is probably not the best reason to throw out the definition.  This isn't the worst answer choice in the world, and it's OK if we keep it as a contender. But this isn't a slam dunk. It features the type of wishy-washy language we want to avoid. So, we definitely need to check the remaining answer choice before selecting (D).

This definitely presents a downside to the historian's definition of medieval epistemology. The historian's definition hinges on finding medieval epistemologists and figuring out their epistemological beliefs. This answer choice presents a reason why that definition isn't workable  — it's hard to tell who was a “medieval epistemologist.” It's possible, according to this answer choice, that no one was a medieval epistemologist! If either fact is true, the historian's definition is yet another definition of medieval epistemology that will not help us “determine what should and what should not be included in” medieval epistemology. Moreover, unlike other tempting answer choices like (D), this answer choice does not feature wishy-washy, weak language. That's another major asset for this answer choice; it should make us feel more comfortable eliminating (D) and selecting (E). Alternatively, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Until recently, intellectual historians didn't have a definition of medieval epistemology. We can define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold. If we want to know whether medieval epistemology includes a belief, we'll ask whether any medieval epistemologists believe it. If they do, it's part of medieval epistemology. If any believe the opposite, the opposite claim is part of medieval epistemology. But, there's much debate as to which medieval thinks, if any, were epistemologists. So, we maybe shouldn't define medieval epistemology as the epistemological beliefs medieval epistemologists hold.” This argument sounds persuasive! The “But” statement presents a major downside of the previous claims. It shows that we may not be able to apply the historian's approach, as we won't be able to figure out “whether any medieval epistemologists” believe a claim. Whichever approach we use, we can confidently select (E).

items.stimulusText: Official: Six months ago, the fines for parking violations on the city's streets were raised to help pay for the parking garage that had just opened. Since then, parking violations on our streets have dropped by 50 percent. Hence, if we want there to be even fewer parking violations, the fines should be raised again.
items.stemText: The reasoning in the official's argument is flawed in that the argument

options.optionContent: takes a possible effect of a reduction to be a possible cause of that reduction
takes for granted that raising fines a second time will reduce parking violations at least as much as it did the first time
fails to take into account the financial benefits the city is now deriving from fines for parking violations
takes for granted that people who park their cars illegally would prefer to park legally
fails to establish that the initial decrease in parking violations was not due to the availability of additional parking spaces

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice suggests that the official confuses an effect for a cause. Although the official commits a causation flaw, this answer choice does not describe the type of causation flaw the official commits. The official assumes that the increase in parking fines caused a reduction in parking violations. The increase in parking fines could not be an “effect” of this reduction, as (A) implies. After all, the increase came before the subsequent (“Since then”) reduction in violation.

When we see “takes for granted” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, the official doesn't necessarily believe that raising fines again will “reduce parking violations at least as much as it did the first time.” The official just says that raising fines again will result in “even fewer parking violations.” Because we don't have any reason to think that the official believes increasing fines will result in the same reduction, this answer choice is incorrect.

When we see “fails to take into account” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Would this weaken the author's argument if true?” The city deriving financial benefits from these fines would not weaken the official's argument. The official doesn't conclude that increasing parking fines will be a net benefit for the city. The official just concludes that it will reduce parking violations even more. This may cause the city to earn less revenue from parking violations (if the increased fines don't offset the reduced number of violations), but that doesn't affect whether there will be fewer violations.

When we see “takes for granted” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and would this strengthen the argument?” In this case, the official doesn't necessarily believe that people who park their cars illegally would prefer to park them legally. The official might assume the opposite  — people would prefer to park their cars illegally, so we need to raise the fines as much as we can to deter them. Moreover, this answer choice would strengthen the argument if true. It may actually weaken the argument. If people who park their cars illegally would prefer to park legally, then fines may not deter them. If you would prefer to park legally but choose to park illegally anyway, there must be an issue with parking legally! Maybe there aren't enough legal spots! In that case, raising fines wouldn't persuade you to park legally  — there'd still not be enough legal spots to park in!

When we see “fails to establish” on an Errors in Reasoning answer choice, the question we should ask ourselves is, “Does the author believe this, and do we need to know this to draw the author's conclusion?  The answer to both questions is “Yes,” making this the correct answer. The author assumes that parking violations decreased due to the decision to increase parking fines. So, the official believes that parking violations did not decrease for some other reason, like the availability of additional parking spaces from the new parking garage. Moreover, to draw the conclusion that raising fines again will result in even fewer parking violations, we need to know that the initial decrease in violations was not due to the availability of additional parking spaces. If the initial decrease was due to the availability of additional parking spaces, then we can't expect that raising the fines again will result in fewer parking violations. Raising the fines didn't reduce the violations the first time, and we're not adding more parking spaces, so we can't expect a subsequent reduction in violations.

items.stimulusText: Consumer advocate: Some agricultural crops are now being genetically engineered to produce important pharmaceuticals. However, this development raises the possibility that the drugs will end up in the general food supply, since if pollen from a drug-producing crop drifts into a nearby field in which an ordinary, non-drug-producing crop of the same species is being grown, the pollen could fertilize that crop and turn it into a drug-producing crop as well.
items.stemText: Which one of the following, if true, would most weaken the consumer advocate's argument?

options.optionContent: As far as scientists know, none of the pharmaceuticals produced by genetically engineered crops would present any danger to public health if they were present in the general food supply.

If pollen from a genetically engineered crop is prevented from drifting into fields in which ordinary crops of the same species are being grown, then there is no risk of the pollen fertilizing the latter crops.
The genetically engineered crops that produce pharmaceuticals are not among the crop species that comprise the largest portions of the general food supply.
In crops genetically engineered to produce pharmaceuticals, the drugs are not present in any part of the plant used for food in ordinary crops of the same species.
If pollen from a drug-producing crop turned an ordinary crop of the same species into a drug-producing crop, it would be possible for scientists to identify the latter crop.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This doesn't affect the argument at all. The consumer advocate doesn't conclude that pharmaceutical drugs in the food supply will pose a public health risk. Their conclusion only states that pharmaceutical drugs might end up in the food supply. So, even if the scientists are correct and these drug-producing crops won't present any danger to public health, that wouldn't weaken the advocate's conclusion. Alternatively, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Scientists now genetically engineer some crops for pharmaceutical use. If pollen from a drug-producing crop drifts into another field, it can fertilize a food crop. The food crop would turn into a drug-producing crop. But, scientists don't think the drug-producing crops will endanger public health in the food supply. So, the drugs will not end up in the food supply.” This argument doesn't sound very convincing. The public health argument in the “But” statement has nothing to do with the conclusion's assertion the drugs won't end up in the food supply. Whichever approach we use, we can eliminate (A).

This doesn't weaken the consumer advocate's argument. Sure, if pollen is prevented from drifting into other fields, then there isn't a risk of turning a food crop into a drug-producing crop. But what if we let our guard down? What if we can't prevent pollen from drifting into other fields? After all, the consumer advocate didn't say that pollen will definitely drift into other fields and fertilize food crops, converting them into drug-producing crops. The consumer advocate just said it “could happen.” Without knowing that we'll always be able to prevent pollen from genetically modified crops from drifting into other fields, we can't say that (B) would weaken the conclusion that there's a “possibility” that drugs end up in the food supply.
