Alternatively, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Scientists now genetically engineer some crops for pharmaceutical use. If pollen from a drug-producing crop drifts into another field, it can fertilize a food crop. The food crop would turn into a drug-producing crop. But, if we prevent pollen from drifting into other fields, then there's no risk of pollen fertilizing food crops. So, the drugs will not end up in the food supply.” This argument isn't awful. Still, the conclusion sounds a bit bolder than the “But” statement would allow. We only know that the drugs will not end up in the food supply if we continuously prevent pollen from drifting into other fields. Who knows if we can do that. This isn't the worst answer choice in the world, and it's OK if we keep it as a contender. But it's far from perfect, too. It doesn't seem like it prevents drugs from entering the food supply. So, we definitely need to check the remaining answer choices before selecting (B). (Upon checking the remaining choices, we’ll see there is a much better option.)

This doesn't affect the argument. The consumer advocate doesn't conclude that most people will consume the pharmaceutical drugs in the food supply. They only claim thats that pharmaceutical drugs might end up in the food supply. Even if the drug-producing crops are random foods very few people eat, they could still be “in” the food supply. Alternatively, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Scientists now genetically engineer some crops for pharmaceutical use. If pollen from a drug-producing crop drifts into another field, it can fertilize a food crop. The food crop would turn into a drug-producing crop. But, the drug-producing corps are not among the most commonly eaten foods. So, the drugs will not end up in the food supply.” This argument doesn't sound very persuasive. The “But” statement doesn't prove that the drugs will not end up in the food supply. It only suggests that few people will each them once they're in the food supply. Whichever approach we use, we can eliminate (C).

This answer choice shows why the drugs won't end up in the food supply! This answer choice says we don't eat the part of the food crops where the drugs would be present. So, even if drug-producing crops fertilize food crops, converting them to drug-producing plants, the drugs still won't enter the food supply. So, if drug-producing carrots only store the drugs in the roots, the drugs won't end up in the food supply. Only carrot, which has no drugs, would enter the food supply. Therefore, this weakens the consumer advocate's conclusion that these drugs could end up in the food supply. Further, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Scientists now genetically engineer some crops for pharmaceutical use. If pollen from a drug-producing crop drifts into another field, it can fertilize a food crop. The food crop would turn into a drug-producing crop. But, the drugs in drug-producing crops are not in any part of the crop used for food. So, the drugs will not end up in the food supply.” This argument sounds pretty good! Yes, the drugs could end up in food crops, but not in the part of the food crop we use for food. So, it's fair to conclude that the drugs will not end up in the food supply. No matter the approach we used, we can confidently select (D).

This doesn't quite weaken the consumer advocate's conclusion. Yes, scientists could identify the drug-producing crops, but could they do so before those crops entered the food supply? Could they always identify these crops and prevent them from entering the food supply. After all, the consumer advocate didn't say that drugs will definitely enter into the food supply. The consumer advocate just said it “could happen.” Without knowing that scientists will always be able to identify the drug-producing crops and prevent them from entering the food supply, we can't say that (E) would weaken the conclusion that there's a “possibility” that drugs end up in the food supply. Alternatively, if we used the backup plan, we could construct this argument (note that we simplified the premises and answer choice and are using the negated form of the conclusion): “Scientists now genetically engineer some crops for pharmaceutical use. If pollen from a drug-producing crop drifts into another field, it can fertilize a food crop. The food crop would turn into a drug-producing crop. But, if a food crop would turn into a drug-producing crop, then scientists could identify the drug-producing crop. So, the drugs will not end up in the food supply.” This argument doesn't seem very persuasive! Knowing that scientists can identify drug-producing crops provides no assurance that the crops won't end up in the food supply. Whichever approach we use, we can eliminate (E).

items.stimulusText: Most of the members of Bargaining Unit Number 17 of the government employees' union are computer programmers. Thus it is certain that some of the government employees who work in the Hanson Building are computer programmers, since _______.
items.stemText: The conclusion of the argument follows logically if which one of the following completes the passage?

options.optionContent: most of the government employees who belong to Bargaining Unit Number 17 but are not computer programmers work in the Hanson Building
most members of the executive committee of Bargaining Unit Number 17 work in the Hanson Building
most of the government employees who work in the Hanson Building are members of Bargaining Unit Number 17
most of the members of Bargaining Unit Number 17 work in the Hanson Building
most of the people who work in the Hanson building are government employees

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This answer choice does not match our anticipation  — that most or all of the Bargaining Unit Number 17 members work in the Hanson Building — so we can eliminate it. Besides, this answer choice wouldn't allow us to make this conclusion. If we symbolized this premise and added it to the argument's premise, here's what we'd get: if BUN17 (most), then Computer Programmers. if BUN17 and NOT Computer Programmers, then Hanson Building. We couldn't combine these to make a valid conclusion. When we have a “most” statement and an “if-then” statement, we can make a valid connection when both the “if” conditions are the same or when the “then” condition of the “most" is the same as the “if” condition of the “if-then.” Neither condition is met here, so we can't make any valid conclusions with this information, much less the conclusion asserted in this argument. So, we can eliminate (A).

This gets really close to our anticipation, but the “executive committee” specification means this answer choice does not match our anticipation — that most or all of the Bargaining Unit Number 17 members work in the Hanson Building. So, we can eliminate (B). Besides, this answer choice wouldn't allow us to make this conclusion. If we symbolized this premise and added it to the argument's premise, here's what we'd get: if BUN17 (most), then Computer Programmers. if BUN17 Executive Committee (most), then Hanson Building. We couldn't combine these to make a valid conclusion. When we have two “most” statements, we can only make a valid connection when the “if” conditions are the same. That's not the case here, so we can't make any valid conclusions with this information, much less the conclusion asserted in this argument. So, we can eliminate (B).

This gets our anticipation — that most or all of the Bargaining Unit Number 17 members work in the Hanson Building  — backward. So, we can eliminate (C). Besides, this answer choice wouldn't allow us to make this conclusion. If we symbolized this premise and added it to the argument's premise, here's what we'd get: if BUN17 (most), then Computer Programmers. if Hanson Building (most), then BUN17. We couldn't combine these to make a valid conclusion, much less the conclusion asserted in this argument. So, we can eliminate (C).

Bingo. This matches our anticipation  — that most or all of the Bargaining Unit Number 17 members work in the Hanson Building — backward. So, we can select (D) immediately. If we symbolized this premise and added it to the argument's premise, here's what we'd get: if BUN17 (most), then Computer Programmers. if BUN17 (most), then Hanson Building. We can combine these to make a valid conclusion. In this case, we have matching “if” statements. So, we can make a “some” conclusion with the “then” parts. That would allow us to draw the conclusion in the passage: Conclusion: Hanson Building  –(some) – Computer Programmers. Therefore, this answer choice provides a premise that would allow the passage's conclusion to follow logically.

This doesn't match our anticipation  — that most or all of the Bargaining Unit Number 17 members work in the Hanson Building  — so we can eliminate (E). Besides, this answer choice wouldn't allow us to make this conclusion. If we added this premise to the argument's premise, here's what we'd get: if BUN17 (most), then Computer Programmers. if Hanson Building (most), then Government Employees. We couldn't combine these to make a valid conclusion, much less the conclusion asserted in this argument. So, we can eliminate (E).

items.stimulusText: Every Labrador retriever in my neighborhood is a well-behaved dog. However, no pet would be well behaved if it were not trained. Thus it is training, not the genetic makeup of the breed, that accounts for these Labrador retrievers' good behavior.
items.stemText: The flawed reasoning in which one of the following is most closely parallel to the flawed reasoning in the argument above?

options.optionContent: All the students at Bryker School excel in their studies. However, students at Bryker School would not excel if they did not have good teachers. Thus, all schools should hire good teachers if they want their students to excel.

Whenever it snows there are relatively more car crashes on the highways. Yet in general, there would not be car crashes unless people were careless. So it is not icy roads, but carelessness, that causes car crashes when it snows.
Every musician I know is a good dancer. Every mathematician I know is a bad dancer. Thus, it is a sense of rhythm, not the ability to count, that is most responsible for good dancing.
All of the good cooks in my country use butter, not margarine, in their cooking. Thus, if you want to be a good cook, you must use butter, not margarine, in your cooking.

All of the students in my algebra class received an A, even though none of them can solve word problems. No student who is unable to solve word problems has an adequate understanding of algebra. It follows that the students in my class received A's not because they did any good work.

answerOptionExplanation.explanation: This conclusion doesn't resemble the claim that “C (and not A) must cause B.” This conclusion is causal  — it implies that good teachers can cause students to excel. But it doesn't rule out another potential cause. So, we can eliminate (A).

This one matches the abstract version of our argument! We have a premise that parallels the claim that “C (and not A) must cause B.” In this answer choice, that's the claim that “it is not icy roads, but carelessness, that causes car crashes when it snows.” So, we have “careless” as our “C,” “icy roads” as our “A,” and “car crashes” as our “B.” The first premise can be translated to “If it snows, then there are more car crashes.” The second premise can be translated to “If there are car crashes, then people are careless.” Although “snow” and “icy road” aren't identical, that's probably OK. After all, “Lab” and “breed” weren't identical in the passage. Given the resemblance between the structure of (B)'s bad reasoning and that in the passage, we can safely select (B) and wrap up this question.

This conclusion resembles the claim that “C (and not A) must cause B.” In this answer choice, that's the claim that “it is a sense of rhythm, not the ability to count, that is most responsible for good dancing.” So, we have “sense of rhythm” as our “C,” “ability to count” as our “A,” and “good dancing” as our “B.” The first premise can be translated to “If one is a musician, then they are a good dancer.” The second premise can be translated to “if one is a good dancer, then one is not a mathematician.” If “sense of rhythm” is implied by “musician,” then our C term comes first. And if “ability to count” is implied by “mathematician,” then our “A” term comes last. In other words, this answer choice mixes up the causes.

This conclusion doesn't resemble the claim that “C (and not A) must cause B.” This conclusion simply makes a recommendation  — it says that you should use butter and not margarine when cooking. The conclusion does not express a cause-and-effect relationship. So, we can eliminate (D). If we did evaluate this answer choice's premises, we'd note that they don't resemble the premises in the passage either. In fact, there's only one premise, which says that “if Good Cook, then Butter and not Margarine.”

This conclusion doesn't resemble the claim that “C (and not A) must cause B.” This conclusion only eliminates a potential cause (good work). It doesn't assert what caused the students to get As. So, we can eliminate (E). (If we did evaluate this answer choice's premises, we'd note that they only sort of resemble the premises in the passage. They establish an “if-then” chain, but there's an “and” condition in the “B” spot. This would be another reason to cross off (E).)

content: David Cay Johnston, "Corporate Risk of a Tax Audit Is Still Shrinking, I.R.S. Data Show" in The New York Times. Copyright 2004 by The New York Times Company.
